ARTICLE B: CURFEW
§ 5-6B-1 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   MINOR. Any person under the age of 18 years, but shall not include any
person who is legally emancipated or certified as an adult.
(1994 Code, § 18-171) (Prior Code, § 5-6B-1)
§ 5-6B-2 CURFEW HOURS.
   No minor shall loiter, idle, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public
streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds,
public places and public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment,
vacant lots or other unsupervised places, to include, but not be limited to:
driving, riding or parking any motorized or nonmotorized vehicle in or upon the
public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public
grounds, public places and public buildings, places of amusement and
entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places, between the hours of
11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, of every night and morning in
the week, except Friday and Saturday nights and the following morning, and
between the hours of 12:00 a.m. Friday and Saturday nights and 6:00 a.m. of the
following morning.
(1994 Code, § 18-171) (Prior Code, § 5-6B-2)
§ 5-6B-3 EXCEPTIONS.
   The following shall constitute valid exceptions to the operation of §
5-6B-2.
   (A)   Accompanied by parent or guardian. At any time, if the minor is
accompanied by his parent, legal guardian or adult person having care and
custody of the minor, or other person who has reached the age of 21 years and
who is specifically approved by the minor’s parent, legal guardian or adult
person having care and custody of the minor, which person shall be responsible
for the acts of the minor.
   (B)   Errand. Until the hour of 12:00 a.m. on any day of the week, if the
minor is on an errand as directed by his parent, legal guardian or adult person
having care and custody of the minor.
   (C)   Legally employed. If the minor is legally employed, for the period
from one-half hour before to one-half hour after work, while going directly
between his home and place of employment. This exception shall also apply if
the minor is in a public place during curfew hours in the course of his
employment. To come under this exception, the minor must be carrying a written
statement from the employer attesting to the place and hours of employment.
   (D)   School, other activities. If the minor is coming directly home from a
school activity or an activity of a religious or other voluntary association,
or an organized team sporting event with an adult coach present. This exception
will apply for one-half hour after the completion of such event. If the event
does not have a fixed, publicly known time at which it will end, the sponsoring
organization must register the event with the Police Department at least 24
hours in advance, informing it of the time such event is scheduled to begin,
the place at which it shall be held, the time at which it shall end and the
name of the sponsoring organization.
   (E)   First Amendment purposes. If the minor is exercising First Amendment
rights protected by the Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion,
speech or assembly, provided the minor first has given notice to the Chief of
Police by delivering a written communication signed by the minor and
countersigned by a parent of the minor which specifies when, where, in what
manner and for what First Amendment purpose the minor will be on the streets at
night during the curfew period.
(1994 Code, § 18-171) (Prior Code, § 5-6B-3)
§ 5-6B-4 VIOLATIONS; PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   (A)   Arrest; Juvenile Court.
      (1)   Taking minor into custody. A police officer who has probable cause
to believe that a minor is in violation of this article shall arrest the minor
and take such minor to the police station. At that time, the minor’s parent,
legal guardian or adult person having the care and custody of the minor shall
be immediately contacted. When the parent, legal guardian or adult person
having care and custody of such minor arrives at the police station, or when
such minor is taken to the residence of such parent, legal guardian or adult
person having the care and custody of the minor, such parent, legal guardian or
adult person having the care and custody of the minor shall be given a copy of
this section and the notice, as provided in subsection (B) below.
      (2)   Appear in Juvenile Court. The minor and parent, legal guardian or
adult person having the care and custody of the minor shall be required to sign
a document (“promise to appear”) evidencing their promise that the minor and
parent, legal guardian or adult person having the care and custody of the minor
will appear before the Municipal Juvenile Court at the date and time that the
minor has been scheduled to appear before the Municipal Juvenile Court. The
minor and parent, legal guardian or adult person having the care and custody of
the minor shall be given a copy of the promise to appear.
      (3)   Refer to Youth and Family Services. If no such parent, legal
guardian or adult person having the care and custody of the minor takes custody
of the minor, the minor may be referred to Youth and Family Services pursuant
to state law, released to a responsible adult or relatives or such other action
as the police officials deem necessary.
   (B)   Charging minor with violation; notice to parent. In the case of a
violation of this article by a minor, the minor shall be charged with violation
of curfew. In addition, the police shall send the minor’s parent, legal
guardian or adult person having the care and custody of the minor, written
notice of the violation, by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by
serving such notice personally on such person, warning them that further
violations may result in the filing of a charge against such parent, legal
guardian or adult person having the care and custody of the minor for a
violation of subsection (C) below.
   (C)   Parental responsibility. No parent, legal guardian or other adult
person having the care and custody of a minor shall permit such minor to
violate the provisions of §
5-6B-2. In any prosecution for violation of the provisions of this article,
conviction of the minor for violation of §
5-6B-2, together with proof that the parent, legal guardian or adult person
having the care and custody of such minor was given written notice of a
previous violation of §
5-6B-2, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the parent,
legal guardian or adult person having the care and custody of such minor
permitted such minor to violate §
5-6B-2.
   (D)   Penalty. The violation of this article shall be punishable by a fine
of up to $200 plus costs for a first offense and a fine of up to $400 plus
costs for second and subsequent offenses.
(Prior Code, § 5-6B-4) (Ord. 2018-02, passed 1-4-2018)
ARTICLE C: TRUANCY
§ 5-6C-1 SCHOOL ATTENDANCE REQUIRED.
   (A)   Parental responsibility. It shall be unlawful for a parent of a minor
who is over the age of six years and under the age of 18 years to neglect or
refuse to cause or compel such minor to attend and comply with the rules of the
school in which the minor is enrolled.
   (B)   Refusal of minor to attend school. It shall be unlawful for any minor,
who is over the age of 12 years and under the age of 18 years and who has not
finished four years of high school work, to neglect or refuse to attend and
comply with the rules of the school in which the minor is enrolled.
(1994 Code, § 18-171.1) (Prior Code, § 5-6C-1) (Ord. 2020-05, passed 5-19-2020)
§ 5-6C-2 EXCEPTIONS.
   The following shall constitute valid exceptions to the operation of §
5-6C-1:
   (A)   Mental or physical disability. If any such minor is prevented from
attending school by reason of mental or physical disability as determined by
the Board of Education;
   (B)   Emergency situation. If any such minor is excused by the school from
attendance;
   (C)   Excused by school and parent. If any such minor who has attained his
or her sixteenth birthday is excused from attending school by written, joint
agreement between the school and the parent, guardian or custodian of the
minor;
   (D)   Observing religious holy days. Exception for minor observing religious
a holy day who receives an excused absence from school; or
   (E)   Home school. If the minor is receiving education by other means
consistent with 70 O.S. § 10-105.
(1994 Code, § 18-171.1) (2003 Code) (Prior Code, § 5-6C-2) (Ord. 2020-05,
passed 5-19-2020)
§ 5-6C-3 VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   Separate offense each day. Each day the minor remains out of school
after a warning has been given to the parent, guardian, custodian, minor or
other person or the child has been ordered to school by the Court shall
constitute a separate offense.
   (B)   Penalty. The violation of this article, for the first offense, shall
be punishable by a fine of not more than $50 plus costs; the second offense
shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $100 plus costs; the third or
subsequent offense shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $250 plus
costs.
(Prior Code, § 5-6C-3) (Ord. 2018-02, passed 1-4-2018; Ord. 2020-05, passed 5-
19-2020)

§ 5-7-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ANIMALS. Any and all types of animals.
   AT LARGE. Off the premises of the owner or custodian of the animals and not
under the immediate control of the owner or custodian.
   CURRENTLY VACCINATED. Properly immunized by or under the supervision of a
licensed veterinarian with an ant rabies vaccine licensed and approved by the
United States Department of Agriculture for use in that animal species. Vaccine
must have been given at appropriate time interval(s) for the age of the animal
and type of vaccine administered.
   DANGEROUS DOG. Any dog that inflicts severe injury on a human being or a
dog, without provocation, or has previously bitten a human being, without
provocation, and thereafter aggressively bites or attacks a human or a dog,
without provocation.
   EXPOSURE TO RABIES. A bite or physical contact with the saliva or other
potentially infectious tissues from an animal confirmed or suspected of being
infected with rabies.
   FOWL. Chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese, guineas and game birds.
   HOME QUARANTINE. Confinement of the animal at the owner’s residence where
the residence has the necessary fencing, shelter and supervision to ensure the
animal will be confined, isolated from the public, observed and has adequate
care. This QUARANTINE also requires an examination by a licensed veterinarian
on the first and last day of confinement.
   KEEP OR HARBOR. To maintain, possess, control and use.
   LAWFULLY ON PRIVATE PROPERTY. A person shall be considered to be lawfully
upon the private property of the owner of a dog when he is on the property in
the performance of any duty imposed upon the persons by the laws of the state,
or its political subdivisions, the City or by the laws of the United States, or
the postal regulations of the United States or when reading meters or making
repairs to any public utility or service located on the premises, or when
working on the property upon the invitation, either express or implied, of the
owners or lessee of such property, or when on the property for any other lawful
purpose.
   LIVESTOCK. Cattle, swine, sheep, horses, mules, donkeys, llamas, alpacas,
goats and fowl.
   NEUTER. To castrate a male animal in order to render it unable to reproduce.
   OWNER. Any person, firm, corporation, organization or department possessing,
harboring, keeping, having an interest in or having control or custody of an
animal.
   PROPER ENCLOSURE FOR A DANGEROUS DOG. While on the owner’s property, a
dangerous dog shall be securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and
locked pen or structure with at least 150 square feet of space for each dog
kept there which is over six months of age, and which is suitable to prevent
the entry of children, and designed to prevent the animal from escaping. Such
pen or structure shall have a secure top and secure sides and shall provide
protection from the elements for the dog.
   SELLER OF RABIES VACCINE. Includes the owner of the business, the manager of
the store and/or the employee selling the vaccine to the purchaser.
   SEVERE INJURY. Any physical injury that results in broken bones or
lacerations requiring multiple sutures or surgery.
   SPAY. To perform an ovarian hysterectomy on a female animal in order to
render said animal unable to reproduce.
   STERILIZATION. To spay or neuter an animal.
   SWINE. An animal of the species Sus Scofa, commonly referred to as a pig,
but does not include a potbellied pig that is kept as a pet and not for human
consumption.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-1) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-2 ANIMAL WELFARE DIVISION.
   The animal welfare division is a part of the City’s Police Department.
Animal welfare officers are authorized to enforce the provisions of this
chapter and have authority to issue citations to persons who violate any
provision of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-2) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-3 DOGS AND CATS REGISTRATION.
   (A)   Registration required. Every person who owns or has charge, care,
custody, possession or control of any dog or cat over the age of six months
shall register it annually with the Police Department.
   (B)   Inoculate dogs and cats. No dog or cat shall be registered until after
it shall have been inoculated by a licensed veterinarian with an approved and
recognized rabies vaccine and a certificate signed by such licensed
veterinarian certifying to such inoculation shall have been presented to the
Police Department showing that the animal has been inoculated, which will
render such animal immune from rabies for the period of registration.
   (C)   Records. The Police Department shall record in a book kept for that
purpose the name and address of the person who owns or has charge of the dog or
cat, a brief description of the dog or cat and the registration number assigned
to it.
   (D)   Tag worn by animal. The Police Department shall furnish the
registrant, at the time of registration, with a tag which will be securely and
visibly attached to the dog or cat which shall indicate the calendar year for
which the license has been issued. All tags shall be valid for the calendar
year in which they are issued regardless of when the tag is obtained.
   (E)   Exception. The provisions of this section shall not apply to dogs or
cats owned by, or in the charge of, nonresidents of the City so long as the
dogs or cats do not remain in the City for more than 15 days.
   (F)   Rabies vaccine sales restrictions. Any seller of recognized rabies
vaccine, who provides for the sale of the vaccine to persons other than
licensed veterinarians, must provide written notice to those individuals prior
to sale of the vaccine that inoculations made other than by a licensed
veterinarian will not be sufficient for registration under this chapter and if
not properly administered may not provide adequate protection from rabies for
the animal. Written notice will be deemed to have been provided to such
purchaser by seller, if seller has posted a placard giving written notice in
type no smaller than three-eighths inch at all checkout counters or at all
public entrances. Failure of such seller to provide such written notice shall
constitute an offense.
   (G)   Limit on dogs and cats. There shall be no more than five dogs or cats,
in any combination thereof, of more than six months of age, per property,
excepting property zoned agriculture.
   (H)   Penalty. A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of
up to $50 plus costs.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-3) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-4 RABIES QUARANTINE.
   (A)   Rabies quarantine procedures.
      (1)   Voluntary impound. Any dog or cat suspected of being afflicted with
rabies, or which has bitten a person, shall immediately be voluntarily
impounded by the owner under the supervision of a licensed veterinarian for a
period of ten days, unless one of the exceptions found in subsection (B) below
is applicable.
      (2)   Seizure and impound. If the animal is not immediately voluntarily
impounded, the animal shall be seized pursuant to warrant by officers of the
Animal Welfare Division and impounded under the supervision of a licensed
veterinarian for a period of ten days, or euthanized to allow for immediate
rabies testing.
      (3)   Violation. Any person who fails to surrender any animal to an
animal welfare officer or to a licensed veterinarian for impoundment pursuant
to the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine of up to $500
plus costs and by term of imprisonment of not more than 30 days.
      (4)   Multiple and severe wounds; euthanasia. If the impounded animal has
inflicted multiple and severe bite wounds or deep punctures or lacerations to
the face, head or neck, it may be subject to immediate euthanasia to allow for
immediate rabies testing.
      (5)   Release. For other impounded dogs or cats, if, upon examination by
a veterinarian at the end of the impoundment, the animal has no signs of
rabies, it may be released to the owner.
      (6)   Stray animals. Any stray dog or cat suspected of being afflicted
with rabies or which has bitten a person shall be subject to being euthanized
to allow for immediate rabies testing.
   (B)   Exceptions.
      (1)   A dog or cat that has an owner, that bites a member of the owner’s
immediate family and the animal is apparently healthy at the time of the bite
may be placed in home quarantine, if the animal welfare officer determines that
the home circumstances are adequate, regardless of vaccination status. The
owner must provide proof of rabies vaccination to the animal shelter after
completion of the ten-day home observation period.
      (2)   A dog or cat that has an owner and is currently vaccinated by a
licensed veterinarian with an approved rabies vaccine and has not inflicted
severe injury on a person may be placed in a home quarantine, until the end of
a ten-day period from the bite, if the animal welfare officer determines that
home circumstances are adequate.
      (3)   Animals in service to the blind or hearing impaired, search and
rescue dogs, or dogs used for police enforcement duties shall be exempt from
any quarantine when a proper record of immunization against rabies is
established. However, the animal must be examined at the end of the ten-day
period by a licensed veterinarian.
      (4)   In other special circumstances, the Communicable Disease Division
(CDD) of the Oklahoma Department of Health will be contacted to determine
whether the animal should be quarantined or euthanized.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-4) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-5 IMPOUNDMENT OF ANIMALS.
   (A)   Authorization to impound. The Animal Welfare Division is authorized to
impound any animal for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or to
protect the animal or the public from harm.
   (B)   Responsibility for charges. The owner of the animal shall be
responsible for the charges incurred for providing veterinarian care for a
neglected or mistreated animal.
   (C)   Redemption of impounded animals.
      (1)   Any impounded dog or cat which has a current license on it shall be
held ten days, during which time the owner of such dog or cat may redeem it
upon payment of the fees as established in §
2-6D-2(B).
      (2)   Any unlicensed or unredeemed animal that is suitable for adoption
may be adopted by any person who follows the procedures identified in §
5-7-6 and pays the fees as established in §
2-6D-2(B). No such animal shall be destroyed or sold unless its owner has been
given at least two days written notice of such impoundment. Such notice shall
be written and shall be either mailed to the owner, if his name and address are
known, or posted at the animal control shelter if the name and address of the
owner are not known.
   (D)   Authority of Animal Welfare Division to destroy. Notwithstanding the
provisions herein, the Animal Welfare Division is authorized to euthanize any
animal which is vicious.
   (E)   Spaying or neutering; refund of certain fees.
      (1)   Any owner who redeems a dog or cat under the terms of subsection
(C) above shall have the impoundment fees charged under subsection (C) above
refunded, exclusive of the license and boarding fees, if the dog or cat is
spayed or neutered within 60 days of the date of redemption for an adult
animal, or in the case of an infant animal, within 30 days of the date a female
animal attained the age of six months and a male animal attained the age of
eight months.
      (2)   A certificate presented to the City, signed by a licensed
veterinarian certifying to the spaying or neutering shall be proof that the dog
or cat has been spayed or neutered.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-5) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-6 ADOPTION REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Dog and cat adoptions.
      (1)   No dog or cat may be released for adoption by the animal shelter
unless said animal has been surgically spayed or neutered.
      (2)   The fee for adopting the dog or cat shall be kept separated in a
manner that ensures the funds will bear interest and the City shall allocate
these fees solely to reduce the costs of spaying or neutering dogs or cats
adopted out of the animal shelter.
      (3)   The City shall maintain accurate records of accounts which fund
spay/neuter programs.
   (B)   Exception. This section shall not be construed to require
sterilization of dogs or cats which are being held by the animal shelter, which
might be claimed by the rightful owner.
   (C)   Other animals. Other animals may be released for adoption without
being sterilized.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-6) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-7 DOGS AND CATS RUNNING AT LARGE.
   (A)   Confinement. Every person who owns, has charge, care, custody,
possession or control of any dog or cat within the City shall confine the dog
or cat to the premises owned or controlled by him. Confinement shall be inside
the residence, or in a yard by means of a substantial fence or similar
enclosure of sufficient strength and height to prevent the dog or cat from
escaping.
   (B)   Tether. The dog or cat may be kept in the yard by use of a tether of
sufficient strength to prevent the dog or cat from escaping from the premises
when the tether is stretched to its full length. The tether must be located in
a manner that the animal has sufficient space to eat, drink and have access to
shelter.
   (C)   Penalty. The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine
of up to $200 plus costs for a first offense, a fine of up to $400 plus costs,
for subsequent offenses.
   (D)   Exemptions.
      (1)   This section shall not apply to a dog or cat that is being walked
and is controlled by means of a leash or a dog or cat that is in a vehicle and
the driver has control of the animal.
      (2)   This section shall not apply to agriculturally zoned property as
defined by the zoning ordinance of the City or at no leash dog areas.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-7) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-8 SHOOTING AUTHORIZED.
   (A)   Shoot with tranquilizer. Animal welfare officers and police officers
are authorized to use a tranquilizer gun to shoot a dog or cat which is
vicious, running in parks or which they are unable to take up and impound.
   (B)   Rabid animals. Police officers may shoot to kill any dog or cat which
is vicious or suspected of rabies and the officers are unable to impound
safely.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-8) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-9 NO LEASH DOG AREAS.
   (A)   Rules. No leash dog areas are city owned property where dogs may be
exercised off leash in the company of their owners if the following rules are
observed.
      (1)   The dogs must have a current license with the City or another
municipality within the state.
      (2)   The owners may only exercise the dogs during daylight hours while
the park is open.
      (3)   The owners must remain with their dogs at all times.
      (4)   Dogs that are aggressive toward other dogs or persons may not be
exercised off leash. Owners and dogs may be banned from the park for violation
of these rules.
   (B)   Designated no leash dog areas. Designated no leash dog areas are as
follows:
      (1)   The undeveloped part of South Government Springs Park bordered on
the south and west by North Boggy Creek, to the east by Tenth Street to the
animal shelter and to the north by the park roads;
      (2)   North Garland detention; and
      (3)   Any city owned and designated dog park.
   (C)   The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to
$200 plus costs.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-9) (Ord 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-10 DANGEROUS DOG.
   No person shall own, possess, keep or harbor any dangerous dog, except as
provided for in this section. The violation of this section shall be punishable
by a fine of up to $500 plus costs.
   (A)   Exceptions.
      (1)   This section shall not apply to any animal owned by the Police
Department or other law enforcement agencies.
      (2)   Dogs shall not be declared dangerous if the threat, injury or
damage was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful
trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner of the dog or if
the dog was being tormented, abused or assaulted or the dog has been tormented,
abused or assaulted in the past or the person injured by the dog was committing
or attempting to commit a crime.
   (B)   Impoundment. When any complaint is filed in the Municipal Court
alleging that a dangerous dog is owned, possessed, kept or harbored, then the
person against whom the complaint is filed, or any other person having control
or custody of the dog alleged to be dangerous, shall immediately deliver the
dog to the animal shelter.
   (C)   Trial.
      (1)   If the Court finds the dog was not dangerous, the dog will be
returned to the owner. If the Court finds that the dog is dangerous and the
defendant is guilty of owning, possessing, keeping or harboring a dangerous
dog, the Court shall determine whether the dog should be euthanized.
         (a)   If the Court determines that the dog should be euthanized and
the Court’s judgment is appealed, then the dog shall not be destroyed until the
appeal is disposed of by the District Court. If the judgment is not appealed,
the dog shall be immediately euthanized.
         (b)   If the Court finds the dog is dangerous but it need not be
destroyed, the dog may be released to the owner upon the dog being registered
as a dangerous dog with the Police Department and upon completion of conditions
specified by the Court.
   (D)   Registration. A dangerous dog must be registered as such with the
Animal Welfare Division of the Police Department. The application for such
registration shall contain the name and address of the owner, the breed, age,
sex, color, any other identifying marks of the dog and the location where the
dog is to be kept. The application fee for such registration shall be $10 and
shall be in addition to any other fee required to register a dog with the City.
   (E)   Conditions imposed by the Court. The Court shall impose conditions as
the Judge sees fit. These conditions may include the following:
      (1)   Confine the dog, at all times, either indoors or outdoors, in a
“proper enclosure”, as defined in §
5-7-1;
      (2)   When not confined, the dog shall be muzzled and restrained by a
substantial chain or leash and under physical restraint of a responsible person
over 16 years of age. The muzzle must not cause injury to the dog or interfere
with its vision or respiration, but must prevent the dog from biting any
person, dog or animal;
      (3)   Display in a conspicuous place on the owner’s premises and on the
dog’s enclosure a clearly visible warning sign stating that there is a
dangerous dog on the property and stating “Beware of Dangerous Dog”. The sign
must include a warning symbol that informs children of the dog’s presence;
      (4)   Maintain, in full force and effect, a policy of liability insurance
such as homeowner’s insurance or surety issued by an insurer qualified under
state statutes in the amount of not less than $250,000 insuring the owner for
any personal injuries inflicted by the dog;
      (5)   Sterilization of dog at the owner’s expense;
      (6)   Microchip the dog at the owner’s expense;
      (7)   Inspections of premises by animal welfare as required. The fee for
such inspections is set forth in §
2-6D-2; and
      (8)   The Court may specify any other conditions it deems necessary.
   (F)   If the owner does not meet the special conditions required by the
Court, the dog will not be released to the owner and it will be euthanized.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-10) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-11 VIOLATION OF CONDITIONS FOR KEEPING DANGEROUS DOG.
   (A)   If the owner of a dangerous animal violates any of the dangerous dog
special conditions imposed by the Court, the dog shall be immediately
confiscated and impounded by the Animal Welfare Division. Upon conviction, the
dog shall be euthanized.
   (B)   Such violation shall be punishable by a fine of up to $500 plus costs,
and/or by a term of imprisonment of up to 30 days.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-11) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-12 REQUIRED DANGEROUS DOG NOTIFICATIONS.
   (A)   The owner must notify Animal Welfare if the custody of the dangerous
dog is to be transferred for any reason. Such written notification shall occur
at least 72 hours prior to transfer and shall contain the name, address and
telephone number of the new owner.
   (B)   The owner must notify Animal Welfare if the owner plans to move his
residence so that the new premises may be inspected and approved prior to the
relocation of the dangerous dog.
   (C)   The owner must notify the Police Department within four hours, that
the dangerous dog is at large or the dog has attacked a person or animal.
   (D)   Failure to notify shall be punishable by a fine of up to $500 plus
costs, and/or a term of imprisonment of 30 days. It could also result in
impoundment of the dog and upon conviction the dog will be euthanized.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-12) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-13 CONCEALMENT OF DOGS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to conceal, or cause to be
concealed, any dog which has bitten or attacked any person or has been
determined to be a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog from any animal
control officer or police officer.
   (B)   The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to
$500 and/or a term of imprisonment of up to 30 days.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-13) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-14 KEEPING DISEASED ANIMALS.
   (A)   Prohibition. No person shall keep any animal which is known or
believed to be infected with a dangerous or communicable disease.
   (B)   Exception. This prohibition does not to any veterinary hospital, zoo,
ranch or other place where such animals are adequately cared for with due
regard for public health and safety.
   (C)   Violation. The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine
of up to $200 plus costs.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-14) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-15 KEEPING OF SWINE PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall keep or maintain swine within the limits of the City,
except in those areas zoned for agricultural purposes or for the hauling or
transportation of swine into or through the City for the purpose of shipment,
processing or sale so long as said swine are not permitted to remain in the
City for a longer period than 24 hours.
   (B)   The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to
$200 plus costs.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-15) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-16 POTBELLIED PIGS.
   (A)   Potbellied pigs may be kept as pets within the city limits if the pigs
are kept for personal enjoyment and not raised for human consumption.
   (B)   Pigs that are not more than 100 pounds or more than 20 inches in
height are presumed to be potbellied pigs. For adult pigs that exceed 100
pounds or 20 inches in height, a veterinarian’s certification that the pig is a
pet and is not raised for human consumption is required for the pig to be
classified as a potbellied pig.
   (C)   The number of potbellied pigs is limited to two per household.
   (D)   The violation of this section shall be punishable by $100 fine.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-16) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021; Ord. 2024-02, passed 2-
6-2024)
§ 5-7-17 KEEPING LIVESTOCK PROHIBITED.
   (A)   Livestock may not be kept except on property zoned A Agricultural or
R-1 Residential Estate or lots one acre or larger.
   (B)   Livestock operations that were in existence prior to August 15, 2007
are allowed to continue but not to expand the number or the type of the
livestock kept.
   (C)   The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to
$200 plus costs. Each separate day a violation continues shall constitute a
separate offense. Livestock kept in violation of this section shall be subject
to abatement by the City.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-17) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-18 LIVESTOCK AT LARGE.
   (A)   Owner responsibility. Every person who owns, has charge, care,
custody, possession or control of livestock shall keep them exclusively upon
his own premises and to restrain them from running at large.
   (B)   Impoundment. Any animal described in subsection (A) above found
running at large shall be impounded by Animal Welfare.
   (C)   Redemption. Such livestock may be redeemed by the owner upon payment
of a fee as provided in §
2-6D-2(A) for each animal, plus a fee as provided in said §
2-6D-2(A) for each day said animal was impounded.
   (D)   Sale. If such livestock is not redeemed within five days, it shall be
sold, provided that the owner of the livestock has been given at least two
days’ notice of such impoundment. Such notice shall be written and shall be
either mailed to the owner, if his name and address is known, or posted at the
animal welfare shelter, if the owner is not known.
   (E)   Authorization to kill. City police officers are authorized to kill
livestock that are at large if the livestock are vicious, uncontrollable or are
endangering the public because they cannot be captured and restrained.
   (F)   Violation. The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine
of up to $200 plus costs. Each separate day a violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-18) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-19 ROOSTERS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   Prohibition. Male chickens over six months of age shall not be kept
except on property zoned A agriculture or R-1 residential estates.
   (B)   Exception. Those properties that had roosters prior to August 15, 2007
and have had roosters continually since the livestock prohibition and remain
grandfathered.
   (C)   Violation. A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine
of up to $500 plus court costs. Each separate day a violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-19) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-20 OUTDOOR SHELTERS.
   (A)   Shelters appropriate to the local climatic conditions for the
particular species of animal are required if the animal is kept outdoors.
   (B)   A shelter for a dog, cat, potbellied pig or other small animal
including fowl shall protect against the cold and the heat. The cold weather
shelter shall include a moisture-proof and windproof structure of suitable size
to accommodate the animal, to allow retention of body heat in the winter. It
shall be made of durable material, and shall be provided with a sufficient
quantity of suitable bedding material to provide insulation and protection
against cold and dampness and to promote retention of body heat. The warm
weather shelter should provide for air ventilation and shading from the sun.
   (C)   The shelter must be maintained in a clean and safe condition. The
property on which animals are kept must be maintained in such a manner as to
prevent waste from accumulating. A suitable method of drainage shall be
provided to rapidly eliminate excess water.
   (D)   All shelters shall comply with all other city and state laws.
   (E)   The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to
$200 plus costs for a first offense and a fine of up to $500 plus costs for
subsequent offenses. Each separate day a violation continues shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-20) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-21 CRUELTY TO ANIMALS.
   (A)   No person shall maliciously or cruelly injure or torture any animal.
   (B)   Animals that have been mistreated may be impounded and the person
responsible shall be responsible for paying for the care and maintenance of the
animal.
   (C)   The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to
$500 plus costs and/or a term of imprisonment of up to 30 days.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-21) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-22 NEGLECT OF ANIMALS.
   (A)   No person shall fail to provide adequate care, water, food or
needlessly extend the suffering of any animal from illness or accident by
failing to provide necessary medical care and/or euthanasia.
   (B)   Animals that have been neglected may be impounded and the person
responsible shall be responsible for paying for the care and maintenance of the
animal.
   (C)   The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to
$500 plus costs. Each separate day a violation continues shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-22) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-23 ANIMALS LEFT IN VEHICLES.
   (A)   No person shall leave an animal unattended in a vehicle when by such
act the animal’s health or safety is endangered.
   (B)   Law enforcement officers, firefighters and animal welfare officers may
enter such vehicle to rescue the animal where its safety or health may be in
jeopardy. Said entry may be made through an unlocked door or by unlocking a
door through an open window or with the use of a mechanical device.
   (C)   These officers or firefighters may use any reasonable force to remove
the animal from said vehicle when the animal’s behavior indicates distress or
the temperature inside of the vehicle is above 85°F or the temperature outside
of the vehicle is above 75°F.
   (D)   The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to
$500 plus costs.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-23) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-24 DUMPING OF ANIMALS.
   (A)   No person shall abandon or dump an animal.
   (B)   It shall not be considered dumping if a feral animal is taken in by a
person solely for the purpose of spaying or neutering and vaccinating the feral
animal and then releasing or returning the animal to the location in which it
was found.
   (C)   The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to
$100 plus costs.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-24) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-25 LOUD ANIMALS.
   (A)   Prohibition. No person shall own, possess, keep or harbor any animal
which by loud, persistent and frequent barking, howling, squealing, hissing,
yelping or other noise causes annoyance or disturbance.
   (B)   Violation. The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine
of up to $100 plus costs for a first offense and a fine of up to $200 plus
costs for subsequent offenses.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-25) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-26 SALE OF DOGS OR CATS.
   (A)   Prohibition. No person shall sell, trade or give away dogs or cats on
any public right-of-way or city park in the limits of the City.
   (B)   Exception. This does not prohibit animal welfare or rescue groups from
conducting adoption events with the permission of the property owner. The City
Manager may authorize adoption events at city parks upon request.
   (C)   Violation. The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine
of up to $100 plus costs.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-26) (Ord. 2021-18, passed 11-2-2021)
§ 5-7-27 CONDITIONAL, LIMITED, HEN WAIVER.
   (A)   The City Marshal may issue a waiver of §
5-7-17 to a allow person who resides on a lot, that is not zoned Residential
Estates (R-1) and is less than an acre, to conditionally allow the resident to
have up to six hens as pets.
   (B)   To qualify for the waiver the resident must have adequate space for
the upkeep and care of the hens. If the property is leased, the renter must
provide a letter from the owner consenting to the keeping of the hens.
   (C)   The property, the shelter or coop and the yard must be maintained
consistent with this chapter. The person seeking the waiver must consent in
writing to the inspections from the City Marshal. The City Marshal will provide
notice of an inspection prior to the inspection.
   (D)   Failure to comply with the conditions will result in the loss of the
conditional waiver and the removal of the hens from the property.
(Prior Code, § 5-7-27) (Ord. 2022-18, passed 7-19-2022)
