§ 6-10-1 INTERPRETATION, EFFECT OF REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Compliance required. No person shall do any act forbidden or fail to
perform any act required in this chapter.
   (B)   Parental responsibility. The parent of any child and the guardian of
any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit the child or ward to violate
any of the provisions of this chapter.
   (C)   Cycles. These regulations are applicable to bicycles, tricycles, quad-
cycles or similar human powered devices, electric assisted bicycles and
motorized bicycles unless otherwise specifically indicated shall apply whenever
a bicycle is operated upon any street or upon any path set aside for the
exclusive use of bicycles, subject to the exceptions herein.
   (D)   Violations that are performed on the above referenced cycles all carry
a fine of $5 plus costs.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004; Ord. 2022-20, passed 8-16-2022)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 11-1201
§ 6-10-2 TRAFFIC LAWS APPLICABLE TO BICYCLES; EXCEPTIONS.
   Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the
rights and be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a
vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to
vehicles or by the traffic ordinances applicable to the driver of a vehicle,
except as to special regulations in this chapter and those provisions of laws
and ordinances which, by their nature, can have no application.
(1994 Code, § 20-362)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 11-1202
§ 6-10-3 ELECTRIC ASSISTED BICYCLE.
   (A)   Electric assisted bicycles are not subject to statutory provisions
relating to financial responsibility, vehicle insurance, drivers licenses,
vehicle registration or certificates of title.
   (B)   No person under 16 years of age may operate a Class 3 electric-
assisted bicycle but such a person may ride as a passenger on a such a bike if
it is designed to accommodate passengers.
   (C)   A person under the age of 18 riding an electric assisted bicycle must
wear a bicycle helmet.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004; Ord. 2021-14, passed 10-5-2021)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 12-701
§ 6-10-4 RESERVED.
   [Reserved]
§ 6-10-5 RESERVED.
   [Reserved]
§ 6-10-6 MANNER OF RIDING ON BICYCLES.
   (A)   Use of seat. No person propelling a bicycle shall ride other than
astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto.
   (B)   Carrying persons. No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at
one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped.
(1994 Code, § 20-364)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 11-1203
§ 6-10-7 RIDING ON SIDEWALKS.
   No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk.
(1994 Code, § 20-365)
§ 6-10-8 SKATEBOARDS, IN-LINE SKATES, COASTERS AND ROLLER SKATES.
   (A)   Riding restricted in certain areas. No person shall ride a skateboard,
in-line skates or roller skates on private or public property where signs are
posted prohibiting such use.
   (B)   Outdoor skate and bicycle motocross parks.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to use the outdoor skate and
bicycle motocross parks without a helmet designed for said use.
      (2)   No motor vehicles may be used at the outdoor skate and bicycle
motocross parks.
      (3)   The fine for a violation of this subsection (B) shall be $25.
   (C)   Use of coasters, roller skates on roadway. No person upon roller
skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device
shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk, and
when so crossing shall be granted all of the rights and subject to all of the
duties applicable to pedestrians. This subsection (C) shall not apply to any
street while set aside as a play street as authorized by ordinance.
   (D)   Clinging to vehicles. No person riding upon any bicycle, coaster,
roller skates, sled or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to any
vehicle upon a roadway.
(Ord. 2018-18, passed 6-5-2018)
§ 6-10-9 RIDING ON ROADWAYS AND BICYCLE PATHS; PASSING OTHER VEHICLES.
   (A)   Due care. Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride
as near to the right side of the roadway as practical, exercising due care in
passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction.
   (B)   Passing other vehicles. No person operating a bicycle shall pass other
vehicles between lanes of traffic traveling in the same direction.
   (C)   Riding two abreast. Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not
ride more than two abreast, except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for
the exclusive use of bicycles.
   (D)   Bicycle paths. Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided
adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the
roadway.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 11-1205
§ 6-10-10 SPEED RESTRICTIONS.
   No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and
prudent under the conditions then existing.
(1994 Code, § 20-368)
§ 6-10-11 RESERVED.
   [Reserved]
§ 6-10-12 CARRYING PACKAGES.
   No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article
which prevents the driver from keeping at least one hand upon the handlebars.
(1994 Code, § 20-370)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 11-1206
§ 6-10-13 PARKING.
   No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway
against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or
against a building or at the curb, in such manner as to afford the least
obstruction to pedestrian traffic.
(1994 Code, § 20-371)
§ 6-10-14 EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   Front lamps. Every bicycle, when in use at any time between one-half
hour before sunset and one-half hour after sunrise shall be equipped with a
lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at
least 1,000 feet to the front.
   (B)   Rear lamp. Every bicycle, when in use any time between one-half hour
before sunset to one-half hour after sunrise shall be equipped with a lamp on
the rear emitting a red light visible from a distance of at least 1,000 feet to
the rear.
   (C)   Reflector. Every bicycle shall be equipped with a red reflector which
shall be visible for 600 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful
lower beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle.
   (D)   Additional reflectors. A bicycle or its rider may have reflectors in
addition to those required above; provided such lights or reflectors shall
comply with the provisions and limitations of 47 O.S. Ch. 12, Art. II.
   (E)   Brake. Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake or brakes which
will enable the operator to stop the bicycle within 25 feet from a speed of ten
mph on dry, level, clean pavement.
   (F)   Sirens. A bicycle shall not be equipped with, nor shall any person use
upon a bicycle, any siren.
(Ord. 2015-36, passed 11-3-2015)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. §§ 12-702—12-704 and 12-707—12-709
CHAPTER 11: MOTORCYCLES
Section
   
6-11-1   Transporting passengers
   
6-11-2   Speed limits
   
6-11-3   Required equipment
   
6-11-4   Use of crash helmet
   
6-11-5   Restriction on motorized scooters
   
6-11-6   Traffic laws applicable to motorized scooters; exceptions
§ 6-11-1 TRANSPORTING PASSENGERS.
   (A)   No person under the age of 16 years shall drive a motorcycle, motor
driven cycle, motorized scooter, motorized bicycle or electric assisted bicycle
on any highway of this state while transporting any other person.
   (B)   The operator of a motorcycle, motor driven cycle, moped, goped,
motorized scooter, motorized bicycle or electric assisted bicycle who has
attained the age of 16 years or older may carry a passenger if the vehicle has
a wheel diameter of 12 inches or greater and is factory designed and equipped
with either a double seating device with double foot rests or a side car
attachment providing a separate seat space within such side car attachment for
each person riding therein so that such person shall be seated entirely within
the body of said sidecar.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 11-1103
§ 6-11-2 SPEED LIMITS.
   No person shall operate any motorcycle at a speed greater than the speed
limit legally posted; provided, however, in no event nor at any time may an
operator under the age of 16 years operate a motorcycle on a highway that has a
minimum speed limit established and posted.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 11-805
§ 6-11-3 REQUIRED EQUIPMENT.
   The following equipment shall be required on all motorcycles, motor driven
cycles, mopeds, gopeds and motorized scooters, except on actual trail rides
conducted outside of public roads and highways:
   (A)   Rearview mirrors. Two rearview mirrors, containing a reflection
surface of not less than three inches in diameter, mounted one on each side of
the vehicle and positioned so as to enable the operator to clearly view the
roadway to the rear of his vehicle;
   (B)   Windshield. A windshield of sufficient quality, size and thickness to
protect the operator from foreign objects. In lieu of such windshield, the
operator shall wear goggles or other protective eyewear that meets American
National Standards Institute standard Z87.1 and provides positive retention of
a face shield of material and design to protect the operator from foreign
objects;
   (C)   Brakes. Brakes adequate to control the movement of same to stop and
hold such vehicles, including two separate means of applying the brakes. One
means shall be effective to apply the brakes to the front wheel and one means
shall be effective to apply the brakes to the rear wheel or wheels. Brake
systems shall comply with 49 C.F.R. § 571.121;
   (D)   Stop lamp. Every motorcycle shall be equipped with at least one stop
lamp mounted on the rear of the motorcycle displaying a red or amber light, or
color between, that is visible from a distance of not less than 500 feet to the
rear in normal sunlight and is actuated on application of brakes;
   (E)   Speedometer. A properly operating speedometer capable of registering
at least the maximum legal speed limit for that vehicle;
   (F)   Fender. A fender over each wheel. All fenders shall be of the type
provided by the manufacturer;
   (G)   Headlamp. At least one lighted headlamp, but not more than two lighted
headlamps, which shall comply with 47 O.S. §§ 12-203, 12-227, 12-228 and 12-
602, and is located at a height of not more than 54 inches nor less than 22
inches;
   (H)   Taillight. At least one taillight, mounted on the rear on the vertical
centerline of the motorcycle which shall emit a red light plainly visible from
a distance of 1,000 feet to the rear; provided that in the case of a
combination of vehicles, only the taillamp on the rear most vehicle need
actually be seen from the distance specified. It should be located at a height
of not more than 60 inches nor less than 15 inches. Either a taillamp or a
separate lamp with a white light shall be so constructed and placed as to
illuminate the rear license plate and render it clearly legible from a distance
of 50 feet to the rear. Any taillamp, together with any separate lamp for
illuminating the rear license plate, shall be lighted whenever the headlamp or
driving lamp is lighted. The operation of a motorcycle upon which the license
plate is surrounded or framed, partially or in whole, by any additional lamp or
lamps or otherwise lighted by any additional lamp or lamps, shall be a
violation of this subsection (H);
   (I)   Reflectors. Every motorcycle shall be equipped with and display at
least one reflector mounted on the motorcycle at a height not less than 15
inches nor more than 60 inches and of such size and characteristics and mounted
so as to be visible at night from all distances within 600 feet to 100 feet
from the motorcycle when directly in front of lawful lower beams of headlights;
   (J)   Horn. A horn, which shall comply with 47 O.S. § 12-401;
   (K)   Turn signal lamps. Every motorcycle of year 2005 and later shall be
equipped with electric flashing turn signal lamps that show to the front and
rear of the motorcycle, shall be located on the same level and as widely spaced
laterally as practicable on the front of the motorcycle and when in use shall
display a white or amber light, or any shade in between, visible from a
distance of not less than 500 feet to the front in normal sunlight, located at
the same level and as widely spaced laterally as practicable on the rear of the
motorcycle and when in use shall display a white or amber light, or any shade
in between, visible from a distance of not less than 500 feet to the front in
normal sunlight, and shall indicate when actuated the intended direction of
turning by flashing the lights showing to the front and rear on the side toward
which the turn is made;
   (L)   Muffler. A muffler or other effective noise suppression system that
shall comply with the requirements of 47 O.S. § 12-402; and
   (M)   Handlebars. Handlebars on motorcycles shall not be higher than eye
level of the operator.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. §§ 12-602—12-606, 12-608 and 12-609
§ 6-11-4 USE OF CRASH HELMET.
   No person under 18 years of age shall operate or ride upon any motorcycle,
motor driven cycle or motorized scooter unless such person is wearing a crash
helmet of a type which complies with standards established by 49 C.F.R. §
571.218.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 12-609
§ 6-11-5 RESTRICTION ON MOTORIZED SCOOTERS.
   No person shall operate a motorized scooter on any roadway with a posted
speed limit of greater than 25 mph.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
§ 6-11-6 TRAFFIC LAWS APPLICABLE TO MOTORIZED SCOOTERS; EXCEPTIONS.
   Every person riding a motorized scooter upon a roadway shall be granted all
of the rights and be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a
vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to
vehicles or by the traffic ordinances applicable to the driver of a vehicle,
except as to special regulations in this chapter and those provisions of laws
and ordinances which by their nature can have no application.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
CHAPTER 12: VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT
Section
   
6-12-1   Purpose
   
6-12-2   Authority to impound
   
6-12-3   Arrest and detention of driver
   
6-12-4   Impoundment of illegally parked vehicles
   
6-12-5   Recovered stolen vehicles
   
6-12-6   Vehicles whose owner is unascertainable
   
6-12-7   Place of impoundment
   
6-12-8   Duration of impoundment
   
6-12-9   Notification of owner
   
6-12-10   Payment of removal costs and storage
   
6-12-11   Right of redemption of vehicle
   
6-12-12   Release of vehicle to other than registered owner
   
6-12-13   Special liens
§ 6-12-1 PURPOSE.
   The impoundment of vehicles under authority of the provisions of this
chapter shall be construed as an enforcement procedure for protection of the
public peace, safety and welfare, and the safeguarding of property, and shall
be used generally for the prevention and removal of traffic hazards, prevention
and abatement of public nuisance arising from traffic law violations,
protection of the public rights in the use of city streets and thoroughfares
from obstructions placed and left in derogation of those rights and for
safeguarding and protecting recovered stolen vehicles.
(1994 Code, § 20-96)
§ 6-12-2 AUTHORITY TO IMPOUND.
   Members of the Police Department are hereby authorized, within the limits
set forth in this chapter, to impound vehicles under the circumstances
hereinafter enumerated. No impoundment shall be valid unless made under order
of an authorized police officer and in strict adherence with the procedures
required in this chapter.
(1994 Code, § 20-97)
§ 6-12-3 ARREST AND DETENTION OF DRIVER.
   Whenever the driver or person in charge of any vehicle is placed under
arrest and taken into custody and detained by police under circumstances which
leave, or will leave, a vehicle unattended on any street or highway, alleyway
or any public property, or on any private property designated for public use,
or any other private property without the property owner’s consent, the vehicle
may be impounded.
(1994 Code, § 20-101)
§ 6-12-4 IMPOUNDMENT OF ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLES.
   (A)   Fire lane. Any vehicle found to be parked in any fire lane or other
access roadway as defined in the International Fire Code may be impounded.
   (B)   Disabled vehicles. A disabled vehicle upon a street or highway may be
impounded under the following circumstances:
      (1)   If left unattended and improperly parked on a street or highway;
      (2)   If left unattended longer than 48 hours on the shoulder of any
highway; and/or
      (3)   If the person in charge of the vehicle is physically incapacitated
to such extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal.
   (C)   Bridge. An unattended vehicle left upon any bridge, viaduct or
causeway or within the structure of a grade separation may be impounded.
   (D)   Traffic hazard or obstruction. A vehicle left unattended upon any
street, alley or thoroughfare and so parked illegally as to constitute a
definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic shall be
impounded.
   (E)   Road construction or improvement locations.
      (1)   When the City plans to construct or improve any street, alley or
right-of-way upon which a car or cars are legally parked, the City shall
install a sign to be conspicuously posted at two locations upon, at or near
such street, alley or right-of-way. Such notice shall state: “Street -
Construction - Improvement, All Vehicles Must Be Removed Immediately!” Such
notice shall be given at least 48 hours prior to the commencement of any
construction or improvement activities.
      (2)   Any vehicle which remains upon any street, alley or right-of-way at
the commencement of any such construction or improvement activities shall be
determined to be parked illegally and shall constitute a traffic hazard, and
shall be impounded.
   (F)   Derelict vehicles.
      (1)   When any derelict vehicle is discovered by the Police Department to
have been parked upon any street in the City for a period of 72 hours, the
Police Department is authorized to impound the vehicle, and if the owner of the
vehicle may be ascertained by reasonable diligence, the owner shall be notified
of the action by the Police Department.
      (2)   When any derelict vehicle is discovered by the Police Department to
have been parked upon any airport property belonging to the City for a period
of 48 hours, the Police Department is authorized to impound the vehicle, and if
the owner of the vehicle may be ascertained by reasonable diligence, the owner
shall be notified of the action by the Police Department.
      (3)   For the purposes of this chapter, a DERELICT VEHICLE shall be
defined as:
         (a)   Abandoned;
         (b)   Interfering with the normal flow of traffic;
         (c)   Interfering with the use of private property;
         (d)   Neglected; and/or
         (e)   Inoperable.
   (G)   Private property.
      (1)   An unattended vehicle found to be in violation of §
6-6-9 may be impounded when the required complaint has been properly made and
filed as provided in this subsection (G).
      (2)   If a violation of the provisions of §
6-6-9 occurs, the owner or legal occupant who complains shall sign a complaint
against the person parking the vehicle on the owner’s or legal occupant’s
property, or if the identity of the person parking the vehicle is unknown, then
the complaint may be filed against the registered owner of the vehicle. The
complaint shall be verified and shall allege that the complaining party is the
owner or legal occupant of the property upon which the vehicle is parked or
standing.
      (3)   Upon filing of the complaint by the property owner or legal
occupant, and if there appears to be proper cause to believe the provisions of
§
6-6-9 have been violated, the Police Department shall cause the vehicle to be
impounded from the property and placed in storage.
   (H)   Parked over water meters.
      (1)   Any vehicle parked in such a way as to obstruct ready access to a
city water meter shall be impounded after notice has been given.
      (2)   Notice shall be given as follows.
         (a)   Notice of the offense and one-hour advance notice of impoundment
and an opportunity to move the vehicle shall be given to the owner or person in
charge of the illegally parked vehicle if such person is present.
         (b)   If the vehicle owner or person in charge of the vehicle is not
present, notice of the offense and impoundment shall be left on the vehicle at
least 12 hours in advance of impoundment.
   (I)   Parked in/upon stormwater drainage facilities or easements.
      (1)   Any vehicle parked in, over or upon stormwater drainage facilities
or easements shall be impounded after notice has been given.
      (2)   Notice shall be given as follows.
         (a)   Notice of the offense and one hour advance notice of impoundment
and an opportunity to move the vehicle shall be given to the owner or person in
charge of the illegally parked vehicle if such person is present.
         (b)   If the vehicle owner or person in charge of the vehicle is not
present, notice of the offense and impoundment shall be left on the vehicle at
least 12 hours in advance of impoundment.
   (J)   Prohibited zone. Any unattended vehicle parked at the street curbing
of any zone where parking is prohibited and where official signs are in place
giving notice thereof in violation of the prohibition may be impounded.
   (K)   Blocking fire exits or hydrants. Any vehicle illegally parked in such
a manner that it blocks a fire escape ladder, device or exit or blocks ready
access to a fire hydrant shall be impounded.
   (L)   Intersection. Any unattended vehicle illegally parked in any street
intersection shall be impounded. A disabled vehicle in an intersection, with
the person in charge of the vehicle being present, shall be moved out of the
intersection and to the nearest available legal parking space at the street
curbing.
   (M)   Handicapped parking spaces. Any vehicle parked in a parking space
which is clearly marked for handicap parking, whether on public or private
property, which vehicle does not have a clearly visible state or city
authorized handicap sticker may be impounded and the owner and/or operator may
be cited for violations pursuant to §
6-6-7.
(Ord. 2015-20, passed 5-4-2015)
Cross-reference:
   Similar provisions, see
Title 9, Chapter 10
Statutory reference:
   Removal of vehicles constituting traffic obstruction authorized, see 47 O.S.
§ 11-1002(b)
§ 6-12-5 RECOVERED STOLEN VEHICLES.
   (A)   Notice to owner of place of retention. Whenever a stolen vehicle is
located by police and the registered owner cannot be found within a reasonable
time not exceeding one hour, or cannot be determined from the registration
papers or other identifying media in the vehicle or from records or information
available from reports of stolen cars, the vehicle may be removed to the
nearest authorized place for holding impounded vehicles and the registered
owner of the vehicle shall be notified of the location of the place for holding
impounded vehicles as soon as possible by the Police Department.
   (B)   Removal by owner or impoundment by city. If the registered owner is
identified, located and notified of the recovery of the stolen vehicle, the
owner shall be given the right to make his own arrangement for the removal of
the vehicle within the period of one hour from the time he is actually notified
of its recovery, and if the owner is unable or unwilling to effect the removal
within the time specified, the vehicle may be impounded.
(1994 Code, § 20-111)
§ 6-12-6 VEHICLES WHOSE OWNER IS UNASCERTAINABLE.
   Any vehicle may be impounded by the police if the owner is unascertainable
at the time and pursuant to other procedures set forth in this chapter.
(1994 Code, § 20-112)
§ 6-12-7 PLACE OF IMPOUNDMENT.
   Every vehicle that is impounded under the provisions of this chapter shall
be removed to the nearest garage or place of safekeeping designated by the City
Council and to no other place.
(1994 Code, § 20-113)
§ 6-12-8 DURATION OF IMPOUNDMENT.
   (A)   Written order for release. Except as otherwise provided, any vehicle
impounded under the authority of this chapter shall be stored and held safely
until a written order for its release, signed by an authorized police officer,
has been issued.
   (B)   Payment of impoundment costs. The order of release shall be
conditioned upon the payment by the person to whom the release is issued of all
impoundment costs and accrued storage charges assessed against the vehicle.
   (C)   Fines and costs paid in full. No order of release of an impounded
vehicle shall be issued until all fines and costs due the City because of all
violations involving the vehicle have been paid.
(1994 Code, § 20-114)
§ 6-12-9 NOTIFICATION OF OWNER.
   The manager or authorized agent of the place holding impounded vehicles
where vehicle has been rightfully impounded shall promptly ascertain the name
and address of the owner of the vehicle and, if reasonably possible, notify him
of the vehicle location.
(1994 Code, § 20-115)
§ 6-12-10 PAYMENT OF REMOVAL COSTS AND STORAGE.
   The owner of a motor vehicle which is in violation of this chapter or the
owner of any vehicle which shall have been lawfully removed from any highway or
other public property may regain possession of the vehicle upon payment of the
reasonable cost of removal and storage of such vehicle.
(1994 Code, § 20-116)
§ 6-12-11 RIGHT OF REDEMPTION OF VEHICLE.
   Presentation of the order of release at the place of impoundment, together
with payment or tender of payment of all impoundment costs and accrued storage
charges due, shall entitle the person presenting the release to obtain
possession of the impounded vehicle.
(1994 Code, § 20-117)
§ 6-12-12 RELEASE OF VEHICLE TO OTHER THAN REGISTERED OWNER.
   (A)   Authority of Police Chief. The Chief of Police, subject to the
provisions of this chapter, is hereby authorized to release, to one other than
the registered owner, vehicles which have been impounded by the Police
Department.
   (B)   Lien holder, proof required. A lien holder claiming an interest in an
impounded vehicle shall submit to the Chief of Police proof of compliance with
the following requirements by written instruments or other suitable documents:
      (1)   Proof of interest;
      (2)   An agreement to save and hold harmless the City, its officers and
employees; and
      (3)   Proof of financial responsibility showing the net worth of the
party seeking the vehicle to be in excess of $50,000, or a surety bond in an
amount no less than double the value of the vehicle sought to be released.
   (C)   Other party, proof required. Any other party claiming an interest in
an impounded vehicle shall submit to the Chief of Police proof of compliance
with the following requirements by written instruments or other suitable
documents:
      (1)   Proof of interest; and
      (2)   Order of replevin.
(1994 Code, § 20-118)
§ 6-12-13 SPECIAL LIENS.
   (A)   Lien for compensation. Every person lawfully in possession of an
impounded vehicle shall have a special lien thereon for the compensation due
him from the owner of such impounded vehicle for all expenses incurred.
   (B)   Foreclosure of lien. Said lien may be foreclosed by a sale of such
abandoned vehicle upon giving notice and in the manner following. The notice
shall contain:
      (1)   The name of the party bringing action and the name of the owner or
any person claiming any interest therein;
      (2)   A full description of the vehicle, giving all available information
as to the make, serial number, license tag with year and the state from which
the tag was issued;
      (3)   A full statement of all the facts;
      (4)   The amount of the claim, giving a full description of the work,
labor, storage or any other costs involved;
      (5)   The date, time and place of the sale; and
      (6)   The notice shall be posted in three public places in the county in
which the vehicle is to be sold at least ten days before the time specified
therein for such sale, and a copy of said notice shall be mailed to the
registered owner as recorded in the Office of the Oklahoma Tax Commission, the
Director of Finance and any other person claiming any interest in the motor
vehicle, at their last known mailing address, by registered mail on the same
date of posting said notice.
   (C)   Sale of vehicle; disposition of funds.
      (1)   Proceedings for such sale shall not be commenced until ten days
after said lien has accrued. After this ten-day period, but before sale, the
said registered owner of the vehicle shall have a right to contest the
impoundment in the Municipal Court.
      (2)   A return of such sale shall be made at the time of sale and shall
contain a statement as to proof of posting and mailing of the notice of sale of
abandoned vehicle.
      (3)   Any funds remaining after the payment of the lien and costs
incurred therein shall be remitted to the owner, if such owner is known, and if
such owner or the address of such owner is not known, to the Director of
Finance to be deposited in the General Fund of the City.
(1994 Code, § 20-119)
CHAPTER 13: LOW SPEED ELECTRICAL VEHICLES, GOLF CARTS, MINIBIKES,
ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES AND MOBILITY DEVICES
Section
   
6-13-1   Low speed electrical vehicles limitations
   
6-13-2   Use of golf carts or go-carts prohibited
   
6-13-3   Minibike limitations
   
6-13-4   Use of all-terrain vehicles
   
6-13-5   Electric personal assistive mobility devices

6-13-7   Rules of the road

6-13-10   Exceptions
   
6-13-11   Traffic laws apply
   
6-13-12   Penalty
§ 6-13-1 LOW SPEED ELECTRICAL VEHICLES LIMITATIONS.
   No person shall operate any low speed electrical vehicle on any street or
highway with a posted speed greater than 35 mph. However, a low speed
electrical vehicle may cross a street or highway with a posted speed greater
than 35 mph.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
§ 6-13-2 USE OF GOLF CARTS OR GO-CARTS PROHIBITED.
   Golf carts or go-carts shall not be operated on the streets and highways.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. §§ 11-1116
§ 6-13-3 MINIBIKE LIMITATIONS.
   (A)   Minibikes shall be prohibited from operating on the streets and
highways, except:
      (1)   Minibikes may be ridden in parades; and
      (2)   Minibikes operated for food vendor services may be operated on
streets with a speed limit of 30 mph or less if the minibike is registered in
accordance with 47 O.S. § 1151(E).
   (B)   All minibikes offered for sale shall bear the following notice to
customers: “This machine is not manufactured or sold for operation on the
public streets or highways. Since it is not provided with equipment required by
state law for street or highway use, all persons are cautioned that any
operation of this vehicle upon a public street or highway will be in violation
of the motor vehicle laws of this state and will subject violator to arrest.”
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 11-1116
§ 6-13-4 USE OF ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES.
   All-terrain vehicles shall not be operated on streets and highways except
under the following circumstances.
   (A)   An all-terrain vehicle may be driven across a street or highway while
the vehicle is traveling upon a regularly traveled trail and needs to continue
travel from one area of the trail to another. If the vehicle comes to a
complete stop, yields the right-of-way to all oncoming traffic that constitutes
an immediate hazard and crosses the street or highway at an angle of
approximately 90 degrees to the direction of the street or highway. The
operator must have a valid driver’s license and it must be driven during
daylight hours. This exception shall not apply to divided highways or streets
with a posted speed limit exceeding 35 mph in the area of crossing.
   (B)   An all-terrain vehicle may be driven on a street or highway to cross a
railroad track. In that event, the all-terrain vehicle may travel for not more
than 300 feet on a public street or highway to cross the track. The operator
must have a valid driver’s license and it must be driven during daylight hours.
(Ord. 2004-28, passed 9-7-2004)
§ 6-13-5 ELECTRIC PERSONAL ASSISTIVE MOBILITY DEVICES.
   (A)   Registration, license not required. “Electric personal assistive
mobility devices”, as defined in §
6-1-2, are not required to be registered pursuant to the Oklahoma Vehicle
License and Registration Act, see 47 O.S. §§ 1101 et seq., and operators are
not required to have a state driver license to operate the device.
   (B)   Where operated. Electric personal assistive mobility devices cannot be
operated on the state highways or turnpikes except they may be operated upon
the sidewalks, walking trails, bikeways and municipal streets of this state.
   (C)   Rules for use. A person operating an electric personal assistive
mobility device shall:
      (1)   Obey all speed limits;
      (2)   Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and human-powered devices at
all times;
      (3)   Give an audible signal before overtaking and passing any
pedestrian; and
      (4)   Wear or equip the electric personal assistive mobility device with
reflectors and a headlight when operating at night.
   (D)   Penalty. The violation of this section shall result in a warning for
the first offense and thereafter the offense carries a maximum fine of $10.
Each act of noncompliance shall be considered a separate offense.
(Ord. 2018-19, passed 6-5-2018)
§ 6-13-6 RESTRICTION ON USE OF ELECTRIC SCOOTERS.
   No person shall operate an electric scooter on any roadway with a posted
speed limit of greater than 25 mph. Electric scooters must be equipped with
lights to be operated on roads.
(Ord. 2021-02, passed 3-16-2021)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 11-805
§ 6-13-7 RULES OF THE ROAD.
   (A)   Every person operating an electric scooter upon a roadway at less than
the normal speed of traffic at the time and place and under the conditions then
existing shall ride as close as is safe to the right hand curb or edge of the
roadway except in the following situations:
      (1)   When overtaking or passing a vehicle proceeding in the same
direction;
      (2)   When preparing for a left turn at an intersection, into a private
road or driveway;
      (3)   When reasonably necessary to avoid conditions and while exercising
due care, including, but not limited to, fixed or moving objects, parked or
moving vehicles, pedestrians or animals, surface hazards; or
      (4)   Anytime it is unsafe to continue along the right hand curb or edge
of the roadway; and when riding in the right turn only lane.
   (B)   Any person riding an electric scooter upon a one-way street or highway
with two or more marked lanes of travel may ride as close is safe to the left
hand curb or edge of the street or highway.
   (C)    No person riding an electric scooter shall pass other vehicles
between lanes of traffic traveling in the same direction.
   (D)   No person riding an electric scooter upon a roadway shall ride more
than two abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the
exclusive use of bicycles or electric scooters. Persons riding two abreast
shall not impede the normal and reasonable flow of traffic, and, on a laned
roadway, shall ride in a single lane.
   (E)   An electric scooter may only carry one person on it.
   (F)   Any person riding an electric scooter on a roadway shall wear a safety
helmet.
(Ord. 2021-02, passed 3-16-2021)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. §§ 11-1203 and 11-1205
§ 6-13-8 PARKING.
   (A)   Electric scooters may be parked in bicycle racks, designated electric
scooter locations, parking spots for motorcycles or on private property for
which the rider has permission from the owner.
   (B)   Electric scooters shall not be left in the right-of-way for longer
than 24 hours, and, if left in the right-of-way, the location must not be in
the roadway or on a sidewalk.
   (C)   Rented electric scooters shall be picked up for maintenance, service,
charging and relocation within 36 hours of the completion of their use by the
rental company or its agents.
(Ord. 2021-02, passed 3-16-2021)
§ 6-13-9 TRAIL SYSTEM AND SIDEWALKS.
   Electric scooters may be used on the City’s trail system and on sidewalks
but scooters must give the right-of-way to pedestrians and persons in
wheelchairs.
(Ord. 2021-02, passed 3-16-2021)
§ 6-13-10 EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   An electric scooter is not required to be registered by the state.
   (B)   The operator of an electric scooter is not required to possess a
driver’s license or to comply with the vehicle insurance or financial
responsibility laws of the state.
(Ord. 2021-02, passed 3-16-2021)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 1-133.3
§ 6-13-11 TRAFFIC LAWS APPLY.
   Every person riding an electric scooter upon a roadway shall be granted the
rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to a driver of a
vehicle, unless excepted by this chapter or by state law.
(Ord. 2021-02, passed 3-16-2021)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 47 O.S. § 11-1202
§ 6-13-12 PENALTY.
   A violation of this chapter section is punishable by a maximum fine of $100
plus costs.
(Ord. 2021-02, passed 3-16-2021)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 7-1-1 OBSTRUCTING STREETS AND SIDEWALKS.
   (A)   Obstructions prohibited; exemption.
      (1)   No person shall in any manner whatsoever obstruct any public
street, alley, parkway, sidewalk, curbing or parking, or direct, place, operate
or maintain any business or any equipment, materials or supplies pertaining
thereto in or upon the same.
      (2)   This section shall not apply to outdoor cafés permitted under
Title 3, Chapter 5.
   (B)   Signboards, structures. No person shall in any manner whatsoever erect
or maintain any sign or signboard, building, structure, billboard or any
equipment pertaining to any business in or upon any of the public streets,
alleys, boulevards, parkways, sidewalks or curbing; provided, however, nothing
herein shall affect the erection or use of overhead signs in compliance with
the sign ordinances of the City.
   (C)   Nuisance declared. All apparatus, equipment, materials or supplies
pertaining to any business; and all curb gasoline filling stations and pumps;
and all signs, billboards and other structures erected or maintained in
violation of this section are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall
be removed as provided herein.
   (D)   Notice to remove obstruction.
      (1)   The Code Official shall provide written notice to the owner,
operator, lessee or person maintaining an obstruction upon any of the public
streets, sidewalks, parking or curbs as herein prohibited. The notice shall
require such person to remove the obstruction within three days of the receipt
of said notice.
      (2)   Upon the failure of such person to remove the obstruction, the City
shall have the authority to abate said nuisance and remove the same at the
expense of the person maintaining it.
      (3)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit any
obstruction or to prevent prosecution for violation of subsection (A) or (B)
above prior to the giving of such notice.
(1994 Code, § 30-1) (2003 Code) (Prior Code, § 7-1-1)
§ 7-1-2 TRACTORS AND MACHINES WITH LUGS; PLANKING REQUIRED.
   No person shall drive any tractor, apparatus, machine or other equipment
having lugs, grousers, corrugations or other equipment which could damage
streets upon or across any paved street without first placing sufficient
planking or other material on the pavement to protect the same against damage
or to fail to remove such protective material from the pavement after its use.
(1994 Code, § 30-2) (Prior Code, § 7-1-2)
Statutory reference:
   Permits for oversize vehicles, see 47 O.S. § 12-405
§ 7-1-3 SNOW AND DEBRIS REMOVAL FROM SIDEWALKS.
   Any person in possession of, or the occupant of, any building or lot shall,
within 12 hours after a snow has fallen, remove all snow from the sidewalks
along the front and sides of said premises or building. Such person shall also
keep the sidewalk clean and free of rubbish, trash and debris.
(1994 Code, § 30-3) (Prior Code, § 7-1-3)
§ 7-1-4 CLOSING PUBLIC WAY OR EASEMENT, PROCEDURE.
   (A)   Notice of date and hearing. Whenever it is desired to close or to
consider the closing to the public use of any public way or easement, the City
Council shall, by motion, fix a date for closing or considering the closing of
such way or easement and which date shall afford sufficient time to give 30
days’ notice. Thereupon, the City Clerk shall, more than 30 days prior to such
date, mail a notice of such date and hearing on the proposed closing of a
public way or easement, to the holders of a franchise or others designated by
the City Council to have a special right or privilege granted by ordinance or
legislative enactment to use the public way or easement. The Clerk shall
certify to the City Council that such notice has been mailed.
   (B)   Fees and costs.
      (1)   Any private person who requests the City to close a public way or
easement to public use shall provide a list containing the names and mailing
addresses of all owners of property lying within 300 feet of the exterior
boundary of the subject property, as certified by a licensed and bonded
abstracting company or title insurance company.
      (2)   The applicant shall also pay to the Director of Finance at the time
of making the request the fee as provided in §
2-6A-7(A).
   (C)   Refund of fee. Should the applicant withdraw his application in
writing, prior to the setting of the hearing by the City Council, the fee
provided in §
2-6A-7(A) shall be refunded to said applicant.
(1994 Code, § 30-4) (2003 Code) (Prior Code, § 7-1-4) (Ord. 2003-06, passed 3-
18-2003)
Statutory reference:
   Vacating streets and alleys, see 11 O.S. § 42-101 et seq.
§ 7-1-5 INSTALLATION OF UTILITY LINES IN PUBLIC STREETS.
   (A)   Approval required; application; fee.
      (1)   No person shall install a gas line, oil line, water line, electric
line or any other conduit or conductor either above or below the streets,
roads, highways and alleys within the corporate limits of the City without the
prior approval of the City Council. Installation should be as approved by the
City Engineer and shall meet all the requirements of the City, including, but
not limited to, this code.
      (2)   Application for such construction shall be submitted to the City
Engineer with an application fee in the amount established in §
2-6A-7(B), which shall be paid to the Finance Director.
   (B)   Exemptions. Public utilities licensed or franchised by the City, and
sewer and water service line construction, are exempt from subsection (A)
above.
(1994 Code, § 30-5) (Prior Code, § 7-1-5)
§ 7-1-6 SIDEWALK PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM.
   (A)   Residential sidewalk repair partnership program. Eligible residential
property owners that desire to install or improve the sidewalks located in the
right-of-way may apply to the City for partnership funds to be used to make
repairs to the sidewalks.
      (1)   To qualify, the property must be located within the city limits and
have or have been developed with sidewalks or the properties on either side of
the subject property have or have been developed with sidewalks. The sidewalk
must be in need of repair or reconstruction due to its condition or because it
does not comply with current sidewalk standards.
      (2)   To be accepted into the program, the property owner must be able to
provide fifty percent (50%) of the cost of the repair or reconstruction or be
willing to have fifty percent (50%) of the cost be assessed against the
property to be paid back as provided for by state law as a sidewalk assessment
or as a lien.
      (3)   Acceptance is contingent on the availability of matching funds and
priority will be given to applications on the basis of the condition of the
sidewalk, the need and the scope of the project. Work that will result in a
general improvement to pedestrian access rather than provide only a localized
benefit will be given priority. Landowners are encouraged to consider making an
areawide application where appropriate.
      (4)   If a property is accepted into the program, an agreement will be
drawn up between the property owner or owners and the City. If the
circumstances warrant, the City may provide more than a fifty percent (50%)
match if the scope of the project involves more than repair or is coupled with
additional municipal objectives.
   (B)   Commercial sidewalk partnership program. Eligible commercial property
owners that desire to install or improve sidewalks in the right-of-way may
apply to the City for partnership funds to be used to install or improve the
sidewalks.
      (1)   To qualify, the property must be the location of an existing
business within city limits which was not required, when developed, to include
sidewalks.
      (2)   To be accepted into the program, the property owner must be able to
provide fifty percent (50%) of the cost for the installation or be willing to
have fifty percent (50%) of the cost be assessed against the property to be
paid back as provided for by state law as a sidewalk assessment or as a lien.
      (3)   Acceptance is contingent on the availability of matching funds and
priority will be given to applications on the basis of what type of street the
property abuts, the need and the scope of the project. Landowners are
encouraged to consider making an areawide application where appropriate.
   (4)   If a property is accepted into the program, an agreement will be drawn
up between the property owner or owners and the City. If the circumstances
warrant, the City may provide more than a fifty percent (50%) match if the
scope of the project is coupled with additional municipal objectives.
   (C)   Ineligibility for program. A property for which a sidewalk development
fee has previously been paid in lieu of construction of a sidewalk shall be
ineligible for the sidewalk partnership program.
(Prior Code, § 7-1-6) (Ord. 2016-03, passed 2-2-2016)
ARTICLE A: CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR
§ 7-1A-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CONTRACTOR. Any person who does street concrete work, other than the owner.
   OWNER. The owner or person in possession or in control of the property in
front of or adjacent to which street concrete work is being done or
contemplated.
   STREET CONCRETE WORK. The construction, alteration, repair or removal of any
pavement, curbing, gutter or driveway within any public right-of-way or
easement.
(1994 Code, § 30-31) (Prior Code, § 7-1A-1)
§ 7-1A-2 STREET CONSTRUCTION PERMIT.
   (A)   Permit required; exceptions.
      (1)   Required. No person shall lay, place, construct, alter, repair,
remove or maintain any concrete, asphalt, hard surfacing, pipe, wire, poles,
lines or other material of any kind or do any ditching, excavating or filling
in any street, alley or public easement in the City without first having
obtained a permit from the City Engineer. This provision applies to all
persons, including, but not limited to, franchisees and license holders.
      (2)   Exceptions. No permit is required:
         (a)   When work is done by or for the City; or
         (b)   For the fencing in of any utility easement or the growing of
shrubs thereon.
   (B)   Application for permit. Application for such permit shall be
accompanied by detailed plans and specifications of the work to be done.
   (C)   Permit fee; exceptions.
      (1)   If the plans and specifications comply with the requirements of
this article, the Engineering Department shall issue the permit upon payment of
a fee as specified in §
2-6A-7(C) to the Director of Finance.
      (2)   No fee shall be required for:
         (a)   Persons authorized to do such work by the state or by a
franchise granted by the City; or
         (b)   Work other than street concrete work.
(1994 Code, § 30-32) (2003 Code) (Prior Code, § 7-1A-2)
Cross-reference:
   Bond requirement for street improvements, see §
2-1-4
§ 7-1A-3 STREET CONCRETE WORK; COMPLETION TIME.
   No person shall fail to complete, or cause to be completed, street concrete
work within a reasonable time, according to the plans and specifications
submitted and according to the permit issued therefor and the requirements of
this article.
(1994 Code, § 30-33)
§ 7-1A-4 CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS.
   All work for which a permit is required by the provisions of this article
shall be accomplished as directed by the City Engineer.
(1994 Code, § 30-34)
§ 7-1A-5 PAVEMENT DESIGN AND PERMITTED USES.
   All pavement constructed in the City shall be in accordance with the
standard construction specifications of the City and comply with the following;
except, however, that pavement on state and federal designated highways and
street improvements funded by state and federal programs shall be designed and
constructed in accordance with the Oklahoma Department of Transportation
requirements.
   (A)   Type I. Type I pavement shall be designated for collector streets in
residential districts and local streets in commercial districts. Type I
pavement shall be a six-inch slab of portland cement concrete on one-half-inch
sand cushion and six-inch compacted subgrade of suitable material or six-inch
compacted stabilized base as directed by the City Engineer. The stabilized base
or subgrade shall extend ten inches beyond the back side of the curb section.
The curb design shall be integral six-inch by eight-inch “barrier” type.
   (B)   Type II. Type II pavement shall be designated for local streets in
residential districts and shall be a five-inch portland cement concrete slab
with all other requirements of type I the same, except the back of curb height
shall be 11 inches.
   (C)   Type III. Type III pavement shall be designated for the same service
classification as type I. Type III pavement section shall be two inches of type
C asphaltic concrete surface course and five inches of fine aggregate
bituminous base (FABB) on a six-inch compacted subgrade or six-inch compacted
stabilized base as directed by the City Engineer. The compacted subgrade or
base and one inch of FABB shall extend ten inches beyond the back side of the
curb. The combined curb and gutter section shall be 30 inches wide with a six-
inch molded curb section as specified for type I; back of curb height shall be
12 inches.
   (D)   Type IV. Type IV pavement shall be designated for the same service
classifications as type II. Type IV pavement section shall be two inches of
type C asphaltic concrete surface course and four inches of FABB. All other
requirements of type IV shall be the same as for type II, except the back of
curb height shall be 11 inches.
   (E)   Type V.
      (1)   Type V pavement is classified as temporary pavement and shall be
six-inch soil asphalt stabilized base of suitable aggregate and soil obtained
from approved sources or a combination of existing road bed material and
additional soil from approved sources. This stabilized base can be mixed in
place or produced off site and then manipulated and stabilized in place. The
surface may be a single bituminous chip and seal surface treatment or a slurry
seal treatment. Four inches of fine aggregate bituminous base may be
substituted for the soil asphalt base or four inches of full depth asphaltic
concrete pavement on a compacted subgrade or stabilized base may be substituted
for the soil asphalt base and surface treatment with approval of the City
Engineer.
      (2)   The intent for application of type V pavement is on street where
the City determines temporary pavement is necessary for the health, safety and
welfare of the community and sufficient funds are not available for
construction of permanent pavement. Type V pavement shall not be approved for
street improvements paid for by assessment of property owners.
   (F)   Type VI. Type VI pavement section shall be a minimum of two inches of
compacted aggregate base on a compacted subgrade of suitable material and a
slurry seal surface treatment. The compacted subgrade shall extend ten inches
beyond the back side of the curb section. The requirements for combined curb
and gutter shall be the same as for type IV pavement, except a five-inch roll
curb section may be substituted for a barrier curb with approval of the City
and back of curb height shall be 11 inches. Type VI pavement shall not be
approved for public right-of-way dedicated after the date of adoption of this
article.
   (G)   Type VII. Type VII pavement shall be designated for collector streets
in commercial districts and streets other than arterials in industrial
districts. Type VII pavement shall be a minimum of seven inches of portland
cement concrete slab. The thickness shall be increased if subgrade conditions
and traffic load necessitate such increase as determined by the City Engineer.
All other requirements for type VII pavement shall be the same as for type I,
except the back of curb height shall be six inches plus the thickness of the
slab.
   (H)   Type VIII.
      (1)   Type VIII pavement shall be designated for the same service
classification as type VII. Type VIII pavement section shall be two inches of
type C asphaltic concrete surface course and a minimum of seven inches of FABB.
The thickness of FABB shall be increased if subgrade conditions and traffic
load necessitates such increase as determined by the City Engineer. All other
requirements for type VIII pavement shall be the same as for type III, except a
minimum of two inches of FABB shall extend ten inches beyond the back of curb.
      (2)   An equivalent thickness of asphaltic concrete may be substituted
for FABB as determined by Oklahoma Department of Transportation design
procedures, except a minimum of two inches of FABB shall always be specified.
   (I)   Pavement design for arterial street. Pavement sections including curb
and combined curb and gutter shall be designed based on subgrade conditions and
projected traffic loads for a service life of a minimum of 30 years using
Oklahoma Department of Transportation established procedures for such design.
(1994 Code, § 30-35) (Prior Code, § 7-1A-5)
ARTICLE B: LIMITED ACCESS FACILITIES
§ 7-1B-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ARTERIAL HIGHWAY. A street or highway especially designed for through
traffic, entrance into which at intersections may be limited by requiring all
entering vehicles to be brought to a complete stop, and the City Council having
jurisdiction thereover may otherwise protect the right-of-way of vehicles
thereon.
   AUXILIARY SERVICE HIGHWAY. A street or highway especially designed to
furnish access to a limited access highway or to an arterial highway.
   EXPRESSWAY. A divided arterial highway.
   FRONTAGE ROAD. A road constructed adjacent and parallel to, but separated
from, the highway and connected thereto at least at each end for service to
abutting property and for control of access.
   LIMITED ACCESS FACILITY. Shall include limited access highways, expressways,
arterial highways, frontage roads and the auxiliary service highway.
   LIMITED ACCESS HIGHWAY. An arterial street or highway especially designed
for through traffic, and over, from or to which neither owners nor occupants of
abutting lands nor other persons have any right or easement of access, light,
air or view.
   PARKWAY. Any street, highway or limited access facility from which trucks,
buses and other commercial vehicles are, or may be, excluded.
   PUBLIC ROAD. A road constructed to connect other public roads or streets,
but not connected to the highway.
(1994 Code, § 30-16) (Prior Code, § 7-1B-1)
§ 7-1B-2 IMPROVEMENT COSTS.
   A system of limited access facilities consisting of the streets and parts of
streets hereinafter described is hereby established, and in recognition of the
general use of the streets and avenues therein included and of the wear and
tear and destruction of the grading, drainage, pavement and improvements
thereof by general traffic, the straightening, widening, draining, paving,
repaving, resurfacing, curbing, guttering and maintaining of the limited access
facilities are hereby declared to be improvements of a general nature and to
the extent that the costs thereof exceed the benefits to the abutting property,
such costs are declared to be costs of improvements of a general nature for the
benefit of the entire city.
(1994 Code, § 30-17) (Prior Code, § 7-1B-2)
Statutory reference:
   Power of city to declare limited access facility, see 69 O.S. § 1331

CHAPTER 2: PARKS AND RECREATION
Section
General Provisions
   
7-2-1   Hours
   
7-2-2   Use of amplifying equipment; permit
   
7-2-3   Glass containers prohibited
Article A: Park and Recreation Board
   
7-2A-1   Board created; members; terms

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 7-2-1 HOURS.
   (A)   Hours parks open to public. City parks shall be open daily to the
public on the following schedule:
      (1)   Between 6:00 a.m. and 10:30 p.m. of any one day from April 1 to
November 1; and
      (2)   From one-half hour before sunrise to one-half hour after sunset of
any one day from November 1 to April 1.
   (B)   Occupancy prohibited during closing hours. It shall be unlawful for
any person, other than city personnel conducting city business therein, to
occupy or be present in city parks during any hours the parks are not open to
the public.
   (C)   Exceptions.
      (1)   Baseball fields, softball fields, football fields and soccer fields
within the city parks, including the spectator and parking areas of said
fields, are excluded from the above closing hours while said fields are being
used for team playing of baseball, softball, football or soccer. This exception
is extended only to teams organized by sports organizations that have filed
with the City an approved schedule of proposed use of the fields.
      (2)   Tennis courts within city parks are excluded from the above closing
hours while the courts are being used for playing tennis.
(1994 Code, § 24-1) (Prior Code, § 7-2-1)
§ 7-2-2 USE OF AMPLIFYING EQUIPMENT; PERMIT.
   (A)   Definition. As used in this section, the term AMPLIFYING EQUIPMENT
shall mean any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice,
music or any other sound. It shall not include standard automobile radios when
used and heard only by the occupants of the vehicle in which the radio is
installed, or warning devices on authorized emergency vehicles, or horns or
other warning devices used only for traffic safety purposes.
   (B)    Permit required. No person, other than law enforcement officers or
authorized governmental agencies, shall install, use or operate any amplifying
equipment in a fixed or movable position or mounted upon any sound truck for
the purposes of giving instructions, directions, talks, addresses, lectures or
transmitting music to any person or assemblage of persons in any public park of
the City without having first obtained a permit therefor from the Director of
Finance.
   (C)   Application for permit; fee.
      (1)   The application for such a permit shall contain the name and
address of the applicant, kind and type of equipment proposed to be used; the
manner in which it will be operated and the purpose or purposes for the
operation of the same; and such other information as shall be required by the
City Clerk. A permit shall be issued to the applicant upon the payment of the
permit fee.
      (2)   The permit fee for the use or operation of any amplifying equipment
in the parks of the City shall be as provided in §
2-6A-5.
   (D)   Disturbing others. No person shall use any amplifying equipment in
such a manner as to disturb other persons in the park or on adjacent property.
(1994 Code, § 24-2) (Prior Code, § 7-2-2)
§ 7-2-3 GLASS CONTAINERS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall be permitted to carry into or possess any glass container
within any municipal park.
(1994 Code, § 24-3) (Prior Code, § 7-2-3)
ARTICLE A: PARK AND RECREATION BOARD
§ 7-2A-1 BOARD CREATED; MEMBERS; TERMS.
   (A)   There is hereby created a board to be known as the Park and Recreation
Board. The Park and Recreation Board shall consist of a total of eight members,
seven members to be appointed by the City Council, and one member of the City
Council to be appointed by the Mayor.
   (B)   The members of the Park and Recreation Board shall hold office for a
term of three years or until their successors are appointed and qualified.
   (C)   Members of the Park and Recreation Board may serve two terms in
succession.
(Prior Code, § 7-2A-1) (Ord. 2013-23, passed 3-19-2013)
Cross-reference:
   Similar provisions, see § D.1.17 of the City Charter
§ 7-2A-2 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The powers and duties of the Park and Recreation Board shall be as follows:
   (A)   To advise and assist the City in the planning of all parks owned and
operated by the City;
   (B)   To advise with and recommend plans for the development of parks;
   (C)   To advise with the City in its overall coordination of the park
programs; to inform and instruct the public on matters involving the city
parks; and
   (D)   To promote the use of parks both by individual initiative and
recreational programs, as appropriate.
(1994 Code, § 24-18) (Prior Code, § 7-2A-2)
§ 7-2A-3 MEETINGS.
   The Park and Recreation Board shall meet at such times as is agreed by the
members thereof, and shall have the authority to make its own rules and
regulations for the purpose of conducting its business and meeting.
(1994 Code, § 24-19)
§ 7-2A-4 DEDICATION FOR PARKS.
   The purpose of this section is to provide a means to assist in funding the
acquisition and maintenance of city parks as a significant quality of life for
the residents of the City and to integrate parks when appropriate into major
city construction projects.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      CITY CONSTRUCTION PROJECT. All city buildings, gateways, parks, plazas,
medians, roads, excluding road overlay projects, and other public areas except
service facilities not normally visited by the public.
      CONSTRUCTION or ALTERATION. Construction, rehabilitation, renovation,
remodeling or improvement as it relates to public works projects.
      CONSTRUCTION COSTS. Any costs related to public work projects, such as
the estimated construction costs of projects proposed for the capital
improvement plan.
      MAJOR CITY CONSTRUCTION PROJECT. A city construction project or city
alteration project where the City’s construction cost is between $250,000 and
$10,000,000.
      PARK. Any city owned greenbelt area or public park.
   (B)   Dedication.
      (1)   At the time of budget allocation for a major city construction
project, the City Council shall consider the dedication of up to one-half of
one percent (½%) of the construction cost as a set aside for the inclusion of
park features for the project.
      (2)   The purpose of this dedication is to provide park features adjacent
to or in close proximity to the city facility that is subject of the project.
If it would be inappropriate to locate park features at that location, the one-
half of one percent (½%) may be used for the maintenance and enhancement of
city parks generally.
(Prior Code, § 7-2A-4) (Ord. 2023-05, passed 4-18-2023)
CHAPTER 3: FISHING, LAKE USE AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT

§ 7-3-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BODY OF WATER. Ponds, lakes, creeks and springs.
   CITY OPERATED RESERVATION. Any naturally occurring or manmade body of water
owned or maintained by the City, and any park or interest in land owned or
maintained by the City which contains or is appurtenant to a natural or manmade
body of water.
   FISHERMAN’S FLOAT. Any device designed to keep a fisherman afloat in an
upright position in the water, ordinarily consisting of a protectively covered
circular tube, of inflated rubber or styrofoam, with a saddle type seat, in
which the fisherman is seated while wearing watertight rubber waders.
   LENGTH LIMIT. The total length of a fish measured from the tip of the snout
to the end of the tail, with fish flat on a ruler, mouth closed and tail lobes
pressed together.
(1994 Code, § 24-100) (Prior Code, § 7-3-1)
§ 7-3-2 RESERVED.
   [Reserved]
§ 7-3-3 STATE LICENSE; HOURS.
   (A)   State license. No person shall fish upon any city operated
reservation, unless such person has a current state fishing license as provided
by state statutes or proof of exemption therefrom.
   (B)   Hours. No person shall fish in any city operated reservation, except
during posted park hours or at such other times as further restricted by any
ordinance, rule or regulation.
(1994 Code, § 24-101) (Prior Code, § 7-3-3)
§ 7-3-4 RESERVED.
   [Reserved]
§ 7-3-5 FISHING REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS.
   The following restrictions shall apply on city owned and/or operated
reservations.
   (A)   Except as provided in the Oklahoma Wildlife Conservation Code, see 29
O.S. §§ 1-101 et seq., no person shall fish, pursue, harass, catch, kill, take
in any manner, use, have in possession, sell or transport all or any portion of
fish without having first procured a state fishing license.
   (B)   Fishing is limited to not more than three rods and reels per person,
with no more than three hooks per line (treble hooks are considered one hook).
No other fishing methods are allowed.
   (C)   No snagging, seining, netting, cast netting or noodling (hand fishing)
allowed.
   (D)   All black bass caught must be released (returned to the water)
immediately after being taken; no harvest is allowed.
   (E)   Channel catfish and blue catfish have a combined daily bag limit of
six; no size limits apply.
   (F)   Crappie have a 37 fish bag limit.
   (G)   Flathead catfish have a ten fish bag limit; minimum length limit of 20
inches.
   (H)   Trout have a bag limit of two per person per day; no size limit
applies.
   (I)   Harvest of all other species must comply with state regulations as
outlined in OAC Title 800:10-1.
   (J)   No person shall deposit unused bait of any character, including, but
not limited to, minnows, small fish, worms, flesh of animals or any other
deleterious matter which might decay, in the waters of any city owned and/or
operated reservation or upon the lands adjacent thereto.
   (K)   No game fish from any city owned and/or operated reservations shall be
used as bait. For the purposes of this section, game fish shall be as defined
in the Oklahoma Wildlife Conservation Code, see 29 O.S. §§ 1-101 et seq.
(Prior Code, § 7-3-5) (Ord. 2011-03, passed 3-1-2011)
§ 7-3-6 BOATS AND FLOTATION DEVICES.
   (A)   Operation of boats. Nonmotorized boats only may be operated on the
city operated reservations at Crosslin Park, Government Springs Park and
Meadowlake Park.
      (1)   Age restriction. No person under the age of 12 may operate any
craft on city operated reservations. They may be a passenger of someone aged 16
or older with parent/guardian permission.
      (2)   Boat size. Boats must be less than 14 feet in length.
      (3)   Safety requirements.
         (a)   Personal flotation device or PFD (life jacket);
         (b)   All boats must carry one wearable USCG approved PFD for each
person on board;
         (c)   All passengers 12 years and younger on boats must wear a United
States Coast Guard approved PFD whenever the vessel is underway; and
         (d)   Life jackets must:
            1.   Be United States Coast Guard (USCG) approved;
            2.   Be in good and serviceable condition; and
            3.   Must be of suitable size for the intended person, and approved
for the activity.
      (4)   Boating hours. Boating hours are from sunrise to sundown. At no
point shall anyone operate any craft on city operated reservations outside of
daylight hours.
   (B)   Fishing from floats. It shall be unlawful for any person to fish from
a fisherman’s float in any city operated reservation.
   (C)   Violations.
      (1)   A violation of any subsection of this section is subject to a fine
of up to $100 plus costs for each violation.
      (2)   Any person convicted of a violation shall be trespassed from
boating on city operated reservations.
(Prior Code, § 7-3-6) (Ord. 2013-42, passed 11-19-2013)
§ 7-3-7 SWIMMING, SCUBA DIVING, ICE SKATING.
   (A)   Swimming and bathing. No person shall swim or bathe in any of the
waters of any city operated reservation.
   (B)   Wading. No person shall wade in any city operated reservation unless
it is incidental to a lawful boat launching or boat retrieval.
   (C)   Scuba diving. No person shall engage in any skin or scuba diving in
any city operated reservation, except with the express permission of the City
or during an emergency situation or salvage operation.
   (D)   Ice skating, sledding. No person shall ice skate or sled on or over
any of the waters of any city operated reservation.
(1994 Code, § 24-106) (Prior Code, § 7-3-7)
§ 7-3-8 RESERVED.
   [Reserved]
§ 7-3-9 CITY WATERWORKS.
   Persons shall be permitted to operate a boat at the city operated
reservation located at the city service center, but only for the purpose of
testing boats and motors. The operation of such boats at the city operated
reservation located at the city service center shall be governed by the laws of
the state.
(1994 Code, § 24-108) (Prior Code, § 7-3-9)
§ 7-3-10 DOMESTIC WATERFOWL.
   (A)   Prohibition. It shall be unlawful to release domestic waterfowl on any
city property.
   (B)   Violation. A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine,
or fee in lieu of fine, in the amount of $100 plus court costs and fees.
(Ord. 2011-03, passed 3-1-2011)
CHAPTER 4: AVIATION; AIRPORT
Section
   
7-4-1   Aviation Advisory Board

§ 7-4-1 AVIATION ADVISORY BOARD.
   (A)   Created. There is hereby created a board to be known and designated as
the City’s Aviation Advisory Board.
   (B)   Appointment; terms; compensation.
      (1)   This Board shall be composed of seven residents to be appointed by
the City Manager and approved by the City Council.
      (2)   The term of each member of this Board shall be three years, with
their terms expiring in March of the applicable year, and any vacancy shall be
filled in the same manner as the original appointment for the remainder of the
term.
      (3)   Members of the Board shall serve without pay.
      (4)   No member shall serve more than two terms in succession. However,
partial terms shall not be considered in determining the term limit.
   (C)   Officers and meetings.
      (1)   The Aviation Advisory Board shall each year elect a Chairman and a
Vice Chairman from among its members.
      (2)   A majority of the Board shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business.
      (3)   The Board shall meet at such times as it may determine or upon the
call of the Chairman.
      (4)   It may adopt any necessary rules and regulations for conducting of
business.
   (D)   Functions.
      (1)   This Board shall serve as an advisory body of the Enid Woodring
Regional Airport.
      (2)   The Board shall conduct studies for the betterment of aviation
generally and shall report, advise and make such recommendations to the City
Manager and the City Council as it may determine wise from time to time.
(Ord. 2008-07, passed 2-21-2008)
§ 7-4-2 LANDING FEES.
   There is hereby levied a fee as provided in §
2-6C-1(A), per scheduled landing at the airport. The charge shall be paid
monthly within 20 days after being billed by the City, and if not paid within
20 days, a penalty fee as provided in §
2-6C-1(A) shall be added.
§ 7-4-3 WOODRING HANGAR RENTAL CHARGES.
   (A)   Fees and charges. There shall be levied and charged the fees as
provided in §
2-6C-1(B) for ground rental for fixed base operations, ground rental for
hangars and hangar space fees at the airport.
   (B)   Monthly payments. All ground and hangar rentals shall be paid monthly
on or before the first of each month.
§ 7-4-4 WOODRING RAMP FEES.
   There is hereby levied a ramp fee, as provided in §
2-6C-1(C), for every aircraft over 5,000 pounds empty of weight that lands at
the airport and uses Woodring amenities but does not purchase at least 70
gallons of fuel from the airport. The charge shall be paid prior to the
aircraft’s departure, and if not paid prior to departure, a penalty fee as
provided in §
2-6C-1(C) shall be added.
CHAPTER 5: RAILROADS
Section
   
7-5-1   Railroad crossings
   
7-5-2   Paving and street improvements
§ 7-5-1 RAILROAD CROSSINGS.
   (A)   Warning bells at crossing. No person controlling, managing or
operating any railroad or line of railroad passing through or into the City
shall cause or permit its train engines or cars to cross any street without
giving notice of its approach by continually ringing the bell for a distance of
not less than 200 feet from the street crossing until the engine shall have
passed over the street.
   (B)   Blocking railroad crossings.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any conductor to permit any railroad
train, car or engine to remain stationary or standing for longer than the space
of 15 minutes on any street crossed by a railroad track, or to obstruct in
anywise any street crossing for a longer time than 15 minutes.
      (2)   Subsection (B)(1) above shall not apply in those instances where a
road, street or public way is blocked as a result of a derailment, wreck or
mechanical failure which renders the train, car or engine totally incapable of
operation.
(1994 Code, §§ 28-2 and 28-3) (Prior Code, § 7-5-1)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to regulate railroad crossings, see 11 O.S. § 22-119
§ 7-5-2 PAVING AND STREET IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   Duties of railways.
      (1)   When a railway occupies any portion of a street with its tracks
running in the general direction of the street, either on or adjacent thereto,
the railway company shall improve the space between its tracks, and two feet on
either side thereof, in the same manner that the remainder of the street is to
be improved, or with such other material as the City may require.
      (2)   Where any railway company occupies an alley with its track or
tracks, the company shall be required to improve, gutter, drain, grade or pave,
chat or gravel such alley in the manner that may be required by the ordinances
of the City. Where any railway company crosses any street that is being or has
been paved, the City Council may require the railway company to pave so much of
the street as may be occupied by its track or tracks and two feet on each side,
and when more than one track crosses the street within a distance of 100 feet,
measuring from inside rail to inside rail, the railway company shall grade,
gutter, drain, curb, pave, chat or gravel, or improve between its tracks in the
same manner as the City may be improving or has improved the other portion of
the street.
   (B)   Noncompliance by railway; improvements by city; lien.
      (1)   If the owners of the railway shall fail or refuse to comply with
any order of the City to make such improvements by paving, chatting, graveling,
macadamizing or building sidewalks as the City directs, or to repair such
paving, graveling, macadamizing or building sidewalks, such work may be done by
the City. The cost and expense of such work done by the City may be charged
against the railway company and may be collected in the district court in the
county in which the improvements have been made, by action at law, in the name
of the City against the railway company. In any such action at law, it shall be
sufficient to declare generally for work or labor done, or material furnished
on the particular street, avenue, alley or highway so improved.
      (2)   In addition to the remedy provided in this subsection (B) for
collection of costs and expenses, the City or anyone authorized by it to do the
work, shall be entitled to a lien upon the property of the railway company.
Such lien shall exist for the full amount of the cost and expense against the
property of the railway company adjacent or contiguous to the improvement or
improvements so made. The lien may be enforced against the property of the
railway company by action in the district court in the county in which the
improvements have been made. In any action to enforce the lien, it shall be
sufficient to declare generally that the lien exists for the amount of the cost
and expense of the work and labor done or material furnished on the particular
improvement.
(1994 Code, §§ 28-4 and 28-5)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, 11 O.S. §§ 36-116 and 36-118

   [Reserved]

   Similar provisions, see
Title 1, Chapter 15

CHAPTER 7: TREES
Section

7-7-4   Planting, distance from curb and sidewalk
   
7-7-5   Sight distance at intersections; obstructing hydrants

7-7A-1   Purpose
   
7-7A-2   Tree Board Established
