§ 8-4-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ALLEY. A narrow passage or way, not designed to be a street or highway,
intersecting a block or tract of land, and so designated on a plat of record or
established by prescription and used primarily for the accommodation of the
abutting or adjoining property.
   AUTHORIZED PRIVATE RECEPTACLE. A litter storage and collection receptacle.
   CARRYOUT SERVICE. Service from a point of collection at ground level not
more than 75 feet from the street from which collection is made and not
obstructed by gates, fences, enclosed porches, garages or similar enclosures.
CARRYOUT SERVICE shall not include service from alleys.
   CHARGING UNIT.
      (1)   Each occupied single-family dwelling.
      (2)   Each unit designed to be occupied and used by one or more reasons
for living and cooking together in a multiple-family dwelling or apartment or
apartment hotel.
      (3)   Each licensed lot or space for a mobile home or trailer coach in a
mobile home park or in a trailer court.
      (4)   Each commercial establishment or premises other than subsection (2)
or (3) of this definition.
   COMMERCIAL HANDBILL. Any printed or written matter, any sample or device,
dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or
otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature:
      (1)   Which advertises for sale any merchandise, produce, commodity or
thing;
      (2)   Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial
establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or
indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; or
      (3)   Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical
performance, exhibition or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is
charged for the purpose of private gain or profit.
   CURBSIDE SERVICE. Service from a point of collection adjacent to and along
the curb or pavement edge of a paved street or adjacent to, and on the street
side of, a roadside ditch of unimproved streets, from which collection is made;
except however, the container shall not interfere with the free movement of
traffic. CURBSIDE SERVICE shall not include service from alleys.
   DISABLED PERSON. An adult person having a physical impairment which prevents
said individual from meeting the physical requirements for curbside service,
i.e., unable to carry the bags to the street.
   GARBAGE. Putrescible, animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the
handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
   HOUSEHOLD HAZARDOUS WASTE. Hazardous waste that is used in the home and is
generally of one of these varieties: paints/lacquers, pesticides/herbicides,
automotive products or household cleaners. Any waste that is flammable,
corrosive, reactive or toxic will be considered HAZARDOUS.
   LITTER. “Garbage”, “refuse” and “rubbish” as defined herein and all other
waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to
create a danger to public health, safety and welfare.
   NEWSPAPER. Any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law,
any newspaper duly entered with the Post Office Department of the United
States, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper
filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general laws and,
in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine
regularly published with not less than four issues per year, and sold to the
public.
   NONCOMMERCIAL HANDBILL. Printed or written matter, any sample or device,
dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet or any
other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of
literature not included in the aforesaid definitions of a “commercial handbill”
or “newspaper”.
   POLYCART. A rollout cart (90 to 105 gallons) used for curbside automated
waste and recycling collection which is made out of stress free molding
technology known as advanced rotational molding.
   PRIVATE PREMISES. Any dwelling house, building or other structure designed
or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether
inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall
include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox
belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling house, building or other structure.
   PUBLIC PLACE. Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other
public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and
buildings.
   REFUSE. All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body
wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, dead animals, abandoned automobiles
and solid market and industrial wastes.
   RUBBISH. Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and
noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin
cans, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials.
   STREET or HIGHWAY. The entire width between the boundary lines of every way
publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for
the purpose of vehicular travel.
   TRASH. Shall extend to the widest sense of that term, and includes, but
without limitation upon any other meaning, refuse, litter, ashes, leaves,
debris, paper, combustible materials, offal, rubbish, waste and useless or
uncared for matter of all kinds, whether solid or liquid in form.
   TREE TRIMMING. Large, heavy trimmings resulting from pruning or shrub
removal if branches or trunks do not exceed four inches in diameter.
   VEHICULAR. Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or
may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively
upon stationary rails or tracks.
   YARD TRIMMINGS. Those materials generated while providing normal maintenance
to the yard area adjacent to a single-family residential unit. This shall
include grass and weed trimmings, leaves and garden wastes, in addition to
other items related to maintenance of other landscaping, but shall not include
tree trimmings, rocks, gravel or dirt.
(Prior Code, § 8-4-1) (Ord. 2009-28, passed 12-1-2009)
§ 8-4-2 MANDATORY USE OF SERVICE; EXCEPTION.
   (A)   Use required. Except as herein otherwise authorized, all noncommercial
refuse accumulated in the City shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by
the City, and not by any other person.
   (B)   Roll-off exemption. The prohibition against collection of refuse by
persons other than the City does not apply to ROLL-OFFS, defined as 20, 30 or
40 cubic yard containers.
(1994 Code, §§ 34-156 and 34-167) (Prior Code, § 8-4-2)
§ 8-4-3 COLLECTION AGENCY.
   All refuse accumulated in the City shall be collected, conveyed and disposed
of by the City under the supervision of the Solid Waste Department, which shall
have the authority to make regulations concerning the days of collection, type
and location of waste containers and such other matters pertaining to the
collection, conveyance and disposal as it shall find necessary, and to change
and modify the same; provided that such regulations are not contrary to the
provisions of this chapter.
(1994 Code, § 34-157) (Prior Code, § 8-4-3)
§ 8-4-4 FEES, BILLING FOR REFUSE COLLECTION AND CONTAINER RENTAL.
   (A)   Dwelling units. The monthly fee for collection and disposal of garbage
and rubbish placed in the polycart for curbside service from dwelling units
shall be as provided in §
2-6E-8 . The monthly fee for collection and disposal of garbage and rubbish
placed in the polycart for carryout service from dwelling units shall be as
provided in §
2-6E-8 .
   (B)   Additional dwelling units. Residential customers may make a request
for the placement of additional polycarts. The monthly fee for the additional
polycarts shall be as provided in §
2-6E-8 . The request for additional polycarts shall be subject to the
following.
      (1)   Additional polycarts shall require a minimum placement period of
six months.
      (2)   Requests for pick up/removal of additional polycarts during the
minimum placement period shall be subject to a fee of $30 per additional
polycart.
   (C)   Commercial units. The monthly fee for collection and disposal of
garbage and rubbish for charging (commercial) units shall be as established in
§
2-6E-8 .
   (D)   Contacts; variance from minimum fee. When commercial refuse
accumulations require collection other than prescribed in subsection (C) above,
the charge for such collections shall be as provided in §
2-6E-8 (D), and the owner or occupant of the premises requesting this extra
service shall be responsible for the additional charges.
   (E)   Container rental rates. Appropriate rental rates for city provided
containers shall be determined by the Public Works Department and billed
monthly to the user in addition to monthly collection charges. The rental rate
for containers shared by more than one charging unit will be proportioned by
the number of charging units sharing such container. Said charge shall reflect
the capital and maintenance cost amortized over the life of the container.
   (F)   Carryout service.
      (1)   Carryout service shall be provided for the disabled person if such
individual provides certification to the Finance Director that he is the head
of household and provides documentation from a recognized agency (Social
Security, Veterans Administration) private insurance company, pension fund or
other disability documentation acceptable to the Finance Director and further
certifies that no other person or member of the household is physically capable
of placing the container for curbside service and further certifies the address
where the applicant resides. If such documentation is approved by the Director
of Finance, the applicant will receive carryout service at curbside rates.
      (2)   Any person making a false or incorrect certification shall be
guilty of an offense and shall further be liable for the monthly charges for
carryout service for the prior months the person received such service at
curbside rates. Certifications must be renewed on July 1 of each year.
      (3)   Carryout service shall not be provided for persons who have not
complied with subsection (F)(1) above.
   (G)   Curbside service. Every person occupying or having control of the
occupancy of any private premises located on a regularly established refuse
route shall be presumed to have requested and authorized curbside service and
shall be billed for such service, regardless of whether the service was
provided by the City, unless such person makes a written request for carryout
service from the customer service department on an authorized city form prior
to July 1, 1983, or any subsequent monthly billing cycle, and provides
documentation required by subsection (F)(1) above.
   (H)   Charging units. Every person occupying or having control of the
occupancy of any charging units located on a regularly established refuse route
shall notify the Customer Service Department the beginning of such occupancy
and request refuse pick up service; however, the failure of any owner, rental
agent or occupant of such premises to make such request shall not prevent in
any way, impair or impede the solid waste superintendent from adding the
address of such premises to the proper refuse collection route records
providing said service, enforcing by appropriate action the regulatory measures
herein prescribed and causing the fee or charge therefor to be paid. Any place
of abode or residence, or any other place or business occupied and/or in
operation shall be prima facie evidence that garbage, refuse and/or trash is
being produced and accumulated in such premises.
   (I)   Change in method of collection. No person receiving curbside or
carryout service shall be allowed to change to the alternate method of service
for a period of six months after the initial service is requested or provided,
unless said person relocates to another address. However, the City Manager may
exempt persons from this provision based on a physical impairment arising or
when the effective and orderly public service is not substantially affected by
the change. Any change in the method of collection hereinabove allowed will
begin on the first day of the month following the month the change is
requested.
   (J)   Billing on water statement.
      (1)   Refuse collection charges shall be billed on the water statements
and shall become due and payable on the same date and time, at the Customer
Services Department of the City, where water bills are rendered, but shall be
shown as a separate item from the water charge or the sewer service charge.
      (2)   The Customer Service Department shall not accept payment for refuse
collection charges without payment of the water bill, nor shall it accept
payment of the water bill without a payment for refuse collection charges,
except where the City has not made city water available to a user of city
refuse collection service; provided, however, that the customer shall have the
right to contest and opportunity to be heard concerning the bill with the
Customer Service Department under this section.
   (K)   Delinquency; penalty; discontinuance of service.
      (1)   A customer failing to pay the refuse collection charge within ten
days from the date the charge becomes due shall be charged a late payment
penalty of ten percent (10%) in addition to the regular bill; and if not paid
within 30 days after such refuse collection bill becomes due, such delinquency
shall be cause for immediate discontinuing or disconnecting of the water
connection or refuse collection service or both.
      (2)   Penalties, charges and fees shall be paid before either or both the
refuse collection service and water service are reestablished. The stoppage of
services for nonpayment of collection charges shall be in addition to the right
of the City to proceed for the collection of unpaid charges through legal
action.
(Prior Code, § 8-4-4) (Ord. 2009-28, passed 12-1-2009; Ord. 2010-12, passed 11-
16-2010)
§ 8-4-5 PRECOLLECTION PRACTICES.
   (A)   Garbage and rubbish. All garbage and rubbish, excluding household
hazardous waste, being placed in containers for collection, shall have drained
from it all free liquids and shall be deposited in the polycart(s) provided by
the City. All hypodermic needles shall be protected by either the original cap
or by the use of cardboard or styrofoam sufficient in size to completely cover
the length of the needle. Broken glass shall be placed in a box or securely
wrapped in sufficient layers of paper to prevent contact during the trash
collection process.
   (B)   Tree trimmings. All tree trimmings, hedge clippings and similar
material shall be cut to lengths not to exceed four feet and separately tied in
bundles not more than two-feet thick before being deposited for collection.
Tree trimmings shall not be placed in the polycart. The homeowner shall notify
the City of the tree trimmings in order to have the refuse removed.
(Prior Code, § 8-4-5) (Ord. 2009-28, passed 12-1-2009)
§ 8-4-6 GARBAGE AND RUBBISH CONTAINERS.
   (A)   Containers required; maintenance.
      (1)   Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, every person owning,
managing, operating, leasing or renting any premises or any place where garbage
or rubbish accumulates, shall provide and at all times maintain in good order
and repair, on any such premises, a city provided polycart, which shall be used
for the automated waste removal system and shall not be removed from the
premises. It is the resident’s responsibility to keep sufficient capacity and
in such sufficient numbers to accommodate and securely keep all the garbage and
rubbish that may accumulate between collections.
      (2)   Any polycart that does not conform to the provisions of this
chapter or that may have ragged or sharp edges or any other defect liable to
hamper or injure the person collecting the contents thereof shall be replaced
with no cost to the resident.
      (3)   Any polycart that is not distributed by the City will not be
collected.
      (4)   The City shall have the authority to refuse collection services for
failure to comply with this chapter.
      (5)   All covers or doors shall be kept closed except when depositing
refuse in the container.
      (6)   If the polycart is damaged, and the resident is determined to be at
fault, the replacement cost of the polycart will be billed to the resident.
   (B)   Size; cleanliness.
      (1)   Each polycart container shall be provided by the City and the
contents shall be bagged appropriately.
      (2)   All polycart containers shall be kept clean and free from
accumulation of any substance remaining attached to the inside of the container
which would attract or breed flies, mosquitoes or any other biting and/or
stinging insects.
   (C)   Plastic bags.
      (1)   Polycart containers shall contain plastic bags securely tied about
the top and of sufficient strength to hold the load when picked up and carried
without supporting the bottom.
      (2)   The occupant of the premises shall be responsible for providing
plastic bags of sufficient strength and mil thickness to hold and maintain the
contents of the plastic bag, and the City shall not be responsible for the
cleaning of trash and garbage resulting from torn and/or ruptured bags
regardless of how the tear or rupture occurred.
   (D)   Businesses, mobile home parks.
      (1)   Unless otherwise exempted by the Public Works Department, business,
industrial, institutional and mobile home parks shall utilize containers
provided by the City and shall be of sufficient capacity and/or quantity to
fully contain all refuse accumulated between collection periods.
      (2)   All covers or doors shall be kept closed except when depositing
refuse in the container.
      (3)   Every person utilizing polycart containers provided by the City
shall have a duty to regularly inspect, secure and notify the City of any
defect in the container which may, by its form, use or location, reasonably
cause damage to any person.
      (4)   The City shall not be liable for any damage or injury to any person
or property based on any user’s failure to inspect, secure or notify the City
of any defect in the container. This requirement may be satisfied by giving
written notice of such defect to the Public Works Department Director, or his
designees.
   (E)   Multi-family dwellings.
      (1)   If it is determined by the City Manager that there are safe
locations for polycarts and polycart services are available, they will be
provided and billed. If it is determined that dumpster services are safer and
more advantageous, they will be provided and billed to the landlord.
      (2)   All covers or doors shall be kept closed except when depositing
refuse in the container.
      (3)   Every person utilizing containers provided by the City shall have a
duty to regularly inspect, secure and correct any defect in the container which
may by its form, use or location reasonably cause damage to any person.
      (4)   The City shall not be liable for any damage or injury to any person
or property based on any users’ failure to inspect, secure or repair any
container. This requirement may be satisfied by giving written notice of such
defect to the Public Utilities Department.
(Prior Code, § 8-4-6) (Ord. 2009-28, passed 12-1-2009; Ord. 2020-08, passed 6-
2-2020)
§ 8-4-7 STORING TRASH.
   (A)   Placement of trash in containers. No person shall place any trash in
any street, alley or other public place, on any private property, whether owned
by said person or not, except in proper polycart containers for collection or
under express approval granted by the City, nor shall any person throw or
deposit any trash in any stream or other body of water.
   (B)   Placement of polycart.
      (1)   The container shall be placed at the curb no later than 7:30 a.m.
on the collection day.
      (2)   The polycart shall be placed at the edge of the resident’s
property, next to the street, wheels above the curb, with the handle facing the
resident’s home.
      (3)   There must be a minimum of ten feet of clearance from other
containers, parked vehicles, street and lampposts, trees, mailboxes and other
obstructions.
      (4)   The resident must remove the container from the curb or street
after it is emptied.
   (C)   Unauthorized accumulations; nuisance. Any unauthorized accumulation of
trash on any premises is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is hereby
prohibited.
   (D)   Depositing on public ways, occupied premises. No person shall cast,
place, sweep or deposit anywhere within the City any trash in such a manner
that it may be carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk,
alley, sewer, parkway or other public place, or into any occupied premises.
   (E)   Violation. The violations of this section shall be punishable by a
fine of up to $100 plus costs, unless the person charged has been previously
convicted once under this section or any of the following sections of this
code: §§
4-3-2,
4-4-2 ,
4-5-8 ,
4-6-8 ,
7-7-2  and
9-9-2  in the last five years, then a violation of this section shall be
punishable by a fine of up to $500 plus costs.
(Prior Code, § 8-4-7) (Ord. 2018-25, passed 9-6-2018)
§ 8-4-8 COLLECTION OF YARD TRIMMINGS AND REFUSE.
   (A)   Yard trimmings.
      (1)   All yard trimmings shall be placed in the weather resistant clear
plastic bags manufactured for the use of yard waste disposal. Said bags shall
be securely tied about the top and of sufficient strength to hold the load when
picked up and carried without supporting the bottom, except in no case shall
such containers, when filled, weigh more than 50 pounds.
      (2)   The occupant of the premises shall be responsible for providing the
appropriate clear plastic bags of sufficient strength to hold and maintain the
contents of the bag and the City shall not be responsible for the cleaning of
debris resulting from torn and/or ruptured bags regardless of how the tear or
rupture occurred.
      (3)   Yard trimmings shall be placed within ten feet of the curb of the
street from which collection is made or at the edge of the roadway where there
is no curb.
      (4)   If the occupant chooses to recycle yard clippings, the occupant may
contact the City and rent a grass clipping polycart for which the sole purpose
is to collect only grass clippings. If the occupant puts nongrass items in the
recycling grass clipping polycart, the occupant will lose the privileges of
renting and using the recycling grass polycart.
   (B)   Refuse.
      (1)   Refuse shall be collected at least once a week in residential areas
and more often as directed by the superintendent of the Solid Waste Department,
and shall be collected from commercial establishments as determined by the
superintendent of the Solid Waste Department.
      (2)   The superintendent of the Solid Waste Department shall authorize
the collection of a reasonable accumulation of refuse from each residence
during a collection period for the standard charge of the use of one polycart.
Additional charges for additional refuse shall be in accordance with the rates
for additional polycarts. If other refuse is collected, additional charges for
such amounts will be charged at the discretion of the superintendent of the
Solid Waste Department. The superintendent of the Solid Waste Department shall
have the authority to refuse to collect unreasonable amounts or to make an
additional charge for such amounts.
      (3)   The removal of any additional refuse may be arranged by contacting
the superintendent of the Solid Waste Department. The items will then be
appropriately removed. These items shall be placed with at least ten feet
clearance from other containers, parked vehicles, street and lampposts, trees,
mailboxes and other obstructions.
      (4)   The removal of wearing material, bedding or other refuse from homes
or other places where highly infectious or contagious diseases have prevailed
should be performed under the supervision and direction of the superintendent
of the Solid Waste Department. Such refuse shall not be placed in polycart
containers for regular collection.
      (5)   Highly inflammable or explosive materials shall not be placed in
polycart containers for regular collection.
      (6)   Collectors of refuse from outside the City who desire to haul over
the streets of the City shall use a watertight vehicle so operated as to
prevent offensive odors escaping therefrom and refuse from being blown, dropped
or spilled.
      (7)   Ownership of refuse materials set out for collection or deposited
in the city landfill shall be vested in the City.
(Prior Code, § 8-4-8) (Ord. 2009-28, passed 12-1-2009)
§ 8-4-9 RESIDENTIAL SOLID WASTE; DISPOSITION.
   When residential refuse accumulations require collection other than
prescribed in §
8-4-4, such as debris, tree limbs, brush or other materials other than refuse,
roofing materials and other solid waste created by or as a result of commercial
or contractual work done to or on the site of the residence, the owner or
occupant may notify the Solid Waste Department of the amount and type of waste
and request an extra trash pick up. Charges for such removal services shall be
as provided by §
2-6E-8.
(Prior Code, § 8-4-9) (Ord. 2009-28, passed 12-1-2009)
§ 8-4-10 REMOVAL OF CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS.
   (A)   Solid waste container required. Any person, firm or corporation having
secured a building permit from the City shall furnish and place on said
premises, a solid waste container of suitable size and capacity to contain all
debris which will result from said construction activities. The solid waste
container shall be placed on the building site prior to the accumulation of any
construction debris, or when it is deemed appropriate by the Code Official.
   (B)   Location within subdivision. Solid waste containers may be permitted
to be located at a designated location within a subdivision for the purpose of
providing service to multiple building sites; provided that construction
activity does not result in the accumulation of debris at any one building
site.
   (C)   Removal of debris; request city service. As the container is filled,
the person, firm or corporation having secured the building permit shall cause
said container to be emptied and its contents removed to an approved sanitary
landfill. Upon request, the City shall provide waste disposal services.
   (D)   Authority to waive requirements. The Code Official may waive the
requirements of subsection (A) above when such construction activity shall not
result in the storage of any debris outside the confines of the building or
structure.
   (E)   Containment of refuse. No person, firm or corporation shall permit any
refuse, rubbish or any other waste materials to blow or be carried from the
premises for which the building permit has been issued.
(1994 Code, § 34-164.5) (Prior Code, § 8-4-10)
§ 8-4-11 USE OF ANOTHER’S TRASH CONTAINER.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to use another person’s trash container,
whether the container is furnished by the City or by the individual, without
permission of such other person.
(1994 Code, § 34-165) (Prior Code, § 8-4-11)
§ 8-4-12 REQUEST FOR EXEMPTION FROM USE OF SERVICE.
   Any person living in a residence upon which city water or sewer service is
not available, as defined in §§
8-2-2 and
8-3A-5, may request an exemption from using the City’s solid waste collection
service for such residence. Such exemption request shall be made in writing to
the Utility Billing Department. All persons who qualify under this section
shall be exempt from receiving and paying for the City’s solid waste collection
service for such residence.
(1994 Code, § 34-166) (Prior Code, § 8-4-12)
§ 8-4-13 SANITARY LANDFILL; PERMIT; FEES; RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   Permit required. No person shall dump or deposit any rubbish, material
or property of any kind at the sanitary landfill of the City without first
obtaining a permit.
   (B)   Refuse originating within city. A permit shall be issued for the
depositing of refuse material or property originating within the City, at the
sanitary landfill upon payment of the fees provided in §
2-6C-2 (A).
   (C)   Refuse originating outside city. A permit shall be issued for the
depositing of refuse material or property originating outside the City, at the
sanitary landfill, upon payment of the fees provided in §
2-6C-2 (B).
   (D)   Unsecured loads. An additional fee will be paid by any user entering
the sanitary landfill of the City with a vehicle containing an unsecured load,
as provided in §
2-6C-2 (C). A load is unsecured when material hauled is susceptible to blowing,
dropping, leaking or otherwise escaping from said vehicles. Particular loads
that will be considered unsecured, unless adequately covered or secured, are:
      (1)   Construction and demolition materials or byproducts;
      (2)   Yard wastes including tree limbs, brush, grass and leaves;
      (3)   Roofing materials;
      (4)   Cardboard, paper and other lightweight materials; and/or
      (5)   Unsecured trash bags subject to blowing off of a vehicle.
   (E)   Yard and tree trimmings originating within city.
      (1)   A waiver on the landfill permit fee for the depositing of loads
containing yard and tree trimmings originating within the City shall be given
to any person furnishing proof of residency within the City, as evidenced by a
current driver’s license, a city issued landfill card or a water bill with a
city address. This waiver shall not be available when the yard and tree
trimmings were collected by a commercial business.
      (2)   Loads containing yard and tree trimmings mixed with trash or other
materials that cannot be processed in the city compost site shall not be
allowed a waiver on the landfill permit fee and shall be charged as provided in
§
2-6C-2(A).
   (F)   Yard and tree trimmings originating outside city.
      (1)   The landfill permit fee for the depositing of loads containing yard
and tree trimmings originating outside the City shall be as provided in §
2-6C-2(B).
      (2)   Loads containing yard and tree trimmings mixed with trash or other
materials that cannot be processed in the city compost site or loads which
contain refuse material shall be charged as provided in §
2-6C-2(B).
   (G)   Petroleum contaminated soil.
      (1)   A permit will not be issued for any petroleum contaminated soil
that originates outside the state.
      (2)   For all petroleum contaminated soil, the generator is responsible
for providing laboratory analysis for benzene, BTEX (benzene, toluene,
ethylbenzene and xylene), TPH (total petroleum hydrocarbons - gas range, diesel
range or both) and flashpoint. For any site that is suspect of containing
leaded gasoline, the generator is also required to test the soil for lead
content. In addition, any contaminated soil with a benzene concentration above
ten mg/kg, or a lead concentration above five mg/kg, the generator shall
perform a TCLP (toxicity characteristic leaching procedure) analysis. All
testing shall be performed by a laboratory approved by the Oklahoma Department
of Environmental Quality (ODEQ).
      (3)   All generators of petroleum contaminated soil will be required to
complete the nonhazardous industrial waste disposal request form provided by
the ODEQ, which shall be submitted to the City for approval 30 days prior to
anticipated delivery. Approval or denial shall be provided to the generator
within 15 days of the receipt date of the request.
      (4)   The generator must present a copy of the approval letter to
landfill personnel upon delivery of the first load of material and every load
thereafter must include a written statement indicating the originating site and
the load number it represents. Any load that is delivered to the landfill that
is unable to provide the required documentation will be rejected.
      (5)   The City will deny any request to dispose of petroleum contaminated
soil with a TPH concentration in excess of 18,000 ppm for the diesel range, and
3,610 ppm for the gas range. The City reserves the right to perform random
testing for any contaminated soil disposed of at the landfill facility. For any
composite sample that is found to be in excess of ten percent (10%) of the
upper TPH limit of the specified range, the generator is responsible for
removing the material within 30 days. For any material that is not removed
within 30 days, the generator will be assessed a fee as provided for in §
2-6C-2(E).
      (6)   Any petroleum contaminated soil shall be delivered to the landfill
between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday.
(Prior Code, § 8-4-13) (Ord. 2012-13, passed 6-5-2012)
§ 8-4-14 PENALTY.
   A violation of any provision in this chapter shall be a Class A offense.
Each and every day on which a violation shall occur or continues to occur shall
be deemed a separate and distinct offense. Prosecution of such an offense is
not the exclusive remedy or mode of prosecution.
(1994 Code, § 34-177) (Prior Code, § 8-4-14)
CHAPTER 5: STORMWATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM

§ 8-5-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY. The City of Enid.
   COMMON BILLED. A billing for water and/or sanitary sewer service for a tract
that is billed to the tract as one bill and not directly to the individual
units of that tract.
   EQUIVALENT SERVICE UNIT (ESU). Shall be established at one unit per 5,000
square feet of impervious surface or a portion thereof.
   INDIVIDUAL BILLED. Where billing for water and/or sanitary sewer services
for a tract is by separate billing to the individual units of that tract.
   STORMWATER UTILITY SERVICE CHARGE. The fee levied within the boundaries of
the City for the use of the City’s stormwater drainage facilities.
   USER. The owner, renter or lessee of a tract of land that drains stormwater
to the stormwater drainage system.
(1994 Code, § 11-61) (Prior Code, § 8-5-1)
§ 8-5-2 STORMWATER UTILITY SERVICE CHARGE AND EXEMPTIONS.
   (A)   Charges established. There is hereby established a stormwater utility
service charge for the City’s stormwater drainage system at rates hereinafter
established; provided, however, that the service charge shall not be imposed on
the following types of property:
      (1)   City streets, rights-of-way, parks and city owned property;
      (2)   State highway rights-of-way;
      (3)   Railroad rights-of-way; and
      (4)   Undeveloped land.
   (B)   Monthly rate. The monthly stormwater utility service charge rate shall
be charged and collected as provided for in §
2-6E-9.
   (C)   Application for reduced impervious surface rate. Any individually
billed single-family residential user may apply for a reduced impervious
surface rate for the user’s individually billed single-family unit where the
total impervious surface of the tract associated to the unit is less than 1,250
square feet in area. Application shall be made to the Customer Service
Department on forms provided. Review of applications shall be made by the
Engineering Department for completeness and correctness. Upon approval of
application for a unit, the stormwater utility service charge rate for that
unit shall be changed to the reduced impervious surface rate at the next
billing cycle. At such time as the impervious surface area of a unit exceeds
1,250 square feet, the standard rate shall apply and the reduced impervious
surface rate shall not apply.
(1994 Code, § 11-65) (Prior Code, § 8-5-2)
§ 8-5-3 COLLECTION OF SERVICE CHARGE.
   (A)   Monthly charges; billing; water termination for nonpayment.
      (1)   The stormwater utility service charges herein established for the
use of the City’s stormwater drainage system shall be billed to each user
monthly, along with a bill for water or other utility services and such
penalties as are now or may hereafter be established for other utility service
bills. All collecting agencies authorized by the City to accept payment of city
utility bills are hereby directed to advise customers of the provisions of this
section.
      (2)   In the event that any person, firm or corporation shall tender as
payment of water service, sewer service, collection of solid waste service and/
or stormwater utility service charge for the use of the City’s systems an
amount insufficient to pay in full all of the charges so billed, the payment
shall be credited to the account or accounts in accordance with accounting
procedures used by the Customer Service Department for utility bill payments.
      (3)   The City shall have the right and privilege of discontinuing any
and all utility service to any premises for insufficient payment.
      (4)   In the event that any utility account shall become delinquent,
water services may be terminated by the City until all delinquent charges for
the use of the City’s stormwater drainage system, collection of solid waste
service, sanitary sewer service and water service shall have been paid in full.
      (5)   The provisions for collection provided herein shall be in addition
to any rights or remedies which the City may have under the laws of the state.
   (B)   Billing for stormwater drainage only. In the case of users of real
estate who are not billed for water, sanitary sewer or collection of solid
waste, the owner of the real estate or agent of the owner shall be billed
monthly for the service charges herein established.
   (C)   Saving clause. The invalidity of any provision, clause or portion of
this section or the invalidity of the application thereof to any person or
circumstance shall not affect the validity of the remainder of this section or
the validity of its application to other persons or circumstances.
(1994 Code, § 11-66) (Prior Code, § 8-5-3)
Cross-reference:
   Notice to user before termination of service, see §
8-1-7
§ 8-5-4 CALCULATION OF EQUIVALENT SERVICE UNIT (ESU).
   (A)   Basis for billing. The equivalent service unit (ESU) shall be
calculated by determination of the amount of impervious surface that exists or
will exist after development of any tract as set out in the definition of
“equivalent service unit (ESU)” in §
8-5-1 . The ESU for certain tracts as calculated by, and on file in, the
Engineering Department of the City shall be the official determination and
shall be used as the basis for billing of the stormwater utility service
charge.
   (B)   Application for determination.
      (1)   Upon the development of a tract or tracts of land, the owner or
user of the same shall make application for a determination of ESU for the
tract.
      (2)   Application shall include the measured square foot area of the site
being developed, amount of impervious surface to be in place at the time of
full development, location, legal description, name of owner or user of the
tract and address.
      (3)   Application shall be made as part of the building or other city
permit application. A building permit shall be required when no other city
permit is applied for.
      (4)   Upon determination of the ESU for the tract, it shall be added to
the official list, and billing for the stormwater utility service charge shall
begin as set out in this chapter.
   (C)   Changes in list. Changes may be made in the official list of ESU, from
time to time, to add tracts not included, add new developments or make
corrections or adjustments.
   (D)   Appeal of determination. Determinations in the official ESU may only
be appealed by the owner or user of the affected tract. Appeals shall be made
in writing to the Director and shall include evidence of an error or
miscalculation in the determination. The Director shall be given two weeks to
review the application and, finding sufficient evidence, may direct the
official list of ESU to be changed. A finding of insufficient evidence or no
response in the two-week period shall be a denial of the appeal.
(1994 Code, § 11-67) (Prior Code, § 8-5-4)
§ 8-5-5 STORMWATER DEVELOPMENT FEE.
   See §§
2-6E-10 and
13-3-10 for charges and regulations.
(1994 Code, § 11-70) (2003 Code) (Prior Code, § 8-5-5)
CHAPTER 6: NATURAL GAS TRANSPORTATION
Section

§ 8-6-1 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY. The City of Enid, Oklahoma, a municipal corporation.
   CONSUMER. Any individual person, corporation, company, partnership, firm,
unincorporated association, trust or public corporation who uses or consumes
natural gas in the City but does not include self-suppliers of natural gas.
   FRANCHISEE. Oklahoma Natural Gas Company or any other entity holding a valid
franchise from the City for the transportation, distribution or sale of gas.
   LICENSE. The rights and privileges granted by the City Manager on behalf of
the City to a consumer to use the public ways for the transportation of natural
gas as provided by this chapter.
   LICENSEE. A consumer granted a license under this chapter.
   PIPELINE SYSTEM. A system of works, pipes, pipelines, apparatus, machinery,
structures, appliances and appurtenances located within the public ways
reasonably necessary for the transportation, distribution or sale of natural
gas.
   PUBLIC WAYS. Any street, alley, avenues, boulevard, lane, park, parkway,
sidewalk, driveway, utility easement, right-of-way and any other public ways,
places, areas or grounds within the corporate limits of the City as now
constituted or may be added hereafter.
   SETTLEMENT PRICE. The inside FERG first of the month price for natural gas
as published for the month of delivery in the “Platts Inside FERG Gas Market
Report” publication, under the heading “Prices Of Spot Gas Delivered To
Pipelines”, Oneok Gas Transportation, LLC - Oklahoma, or a successor
publication or index.
   TRANSPORT GAS. All natural gas transported and/or distributed by the
franchisee, but not sold by the franchisee, through the pipeline system to any
consumer located within the corporate limits of the City.
   VOLUMETRIC RATE. The sum measured in cents per dekatherm “Dth” in accordance
with the provisions of §
8-6-3 . The VOLUMETRIC RATE calculation shall be based on the settlement price
for the month of delivery and multiplied by three percent (3%) to obtain the
volumetric rate for that month.
(Prior Code, § 8-6-1) (Ord. 2005-22.5, passed 9-6-2005)
§ 8-6-2 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No consumer shall receive or deliver gas within the City pursuant to any
pipeline system installed in the public ways, unless the consumer shall hold a
valid license from the City or the company selling the gas has a franchise with
the City. Such license shall be issued for the purpose of granting the licensee
authority to use the public ways. The City Manager is hereby authorized to
issue licenses pursuant to the terms of this chapter and may adopt any
administrative policy or procedures deemed necessary to implement this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 8-6-2) (Ord. 2005-22.5, passed 9-6-2005)
§ 8-6-3 FEE.
   (A)   In consideration of the issuance of a license by the City, a licensee
shall pay to franchisee, who shall collect and remit such fee on behalf of the
City, a fee for use of the public ways equal to the then current volumetric
rate multiplied by the number of Dth of transport gas distributed to the
licensee for consumption within the City.
   (B)   All fees collected by the franchisee shall be monthly remitted to the
City on or before the twenty-fifth day of each successive month during the term
of the license.
(Prior Code, § 8-6-3) (Ord. 2005-22.5, passed 9-6-2005)
§ 8-6-4 LICENSING REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Any license issued shall contain the following material terms:
      (1)   The licensee shall pay the fee set forth in §
8-6-3 to franchisee;
      (2)   The licensee shall grant to the City the right to audit at
reasonable times the books and records of the licensee to verify the correct
payment of the fee set forth in §
8-6-3; and
      (3)   The licensee shall assume conjointly with the franchisee or other
party allowed use of the public ways for pipeline installation the
indemnification terms of the franchise or other agreement insofar as the terms
apply to the licenses.
(Prior Code, § 8-6-4) (Ord. 2005-22.5, passed 9-6-2005)
§ 8-6-5 REVOCATION AND PENALTIES.
   (A)   A license shall be revocable by the City Council at any time upon a
30-day prior written notice to licensee, with a copy to the franchisee, for
failure to pay fees assessed under §
8-6-3 or upon a finding that the licensee or the third party supplier of
natural gas has violated a state or federal law having a reasonable
relationship to its fitness to conduct business.
   (B)   Any violation of this chapter shall be an offense. Any consumer
adjudged guilty of violating any section contained in this chapter shall be
punished by a fine of $100 plus costs, for each offense; and each day of a
continuing violation shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 8-6-5) (Ord. 2005-22.5, passed 9-6-2005)
§ 8-6-6 DUTIES OF FRANCHISEE.
   In addition to the duty to collect and distribute the fees as provided in §
8-6-3, franchisee shall provide a yearly written report to the City accounting
for all volumes of gas transported or distributed through its distribution
system within the corporate limits of the City on behalf of all licensees.
(Prior Code, § 8-6-6) (Ord. 2005-22.5, passed 9-6-2005)
CHAPTER 7: NATURAL GAS FRANCHISE
Section
   
8-7-1   Definitions
   
8-7-2   Grant of franchise
   
8-7-3   Franchise assignment, sale or lease
   
8-7-4   Use and repair of the public ways
