§ 9-12-1 PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   The purpose and intent of this chapter is to establish and provide minimum
acceptable standards, requirements, and regulations for the planned use,
development and maintenance of mobile homes and mobile home parks within the
corporate limits of the City, for the protection of the health, safety and
general welfare. The standards, requirements and regulations as herein provided
are to encourage mobile home park use, development and maintenance in locations
and in a manner for safe and sanitary living conditions and convenience for
purposes of employment, shopping, education and the availability of other
necessary community facilities.
(1994 Code, § 19-1) (Prior Code, § 9-12-1)
§ 9-12-2 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
Definitions for MANUFACTURED HOME, MOBILE HOME, MODULAR HOME (IRC CODE),
RESIDENTIAL MANUFACTURED HOME, SINGLE-WIDE RESIDENTIAL MANUFACTURED HOME and
SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL MANUFACTURED HOME and TWO-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL
MANUFACTURED HOME are found in §
11-1-7  of this code.
   CAMPING TRAILER. A portable or mobile living unit used for temporary
occupancy away from the principal place of residence.
   DEPENDENT MOBILE HOME. A mobile home which does not have a toilet and a bath
or shower.
   DEVELOPER. Any person engaged in the development or planning of a mobile
home park or subdivision.
   DRIVEWAY. A minor private way used by vehicles and/or pedestrians on a
mobile home site or used for common access to facilities or groups of lots.
   EXPANSION. The increasing of either the total land area of a mobile home
park, or the total number of mobile homes or mobile home spaces.
   FREESTANDING MOBILE HOME OR TRAVEL TRAILER. Any mobile home or travel
trailer not located in a mobile home park or travel trailer park, respectively,
licensed by the City, or in an approved mobile home neighborhood.
   HEALTH AUTHORITY. The Oklahoma Department of Health as represented by the
county health unit or its authorized representative of the City.
   INDEPENDENT MOBILE HOME. A mobile home that has a toilet and bath or shower.
   LICENSEE. Any person licensed to operate and maintain a mobile home park,
under the provisions of this chapter.
   MOBILE HOME LICENSE. A permit issued by the Code Official to a developer for
the construction and operation of a mobile home park.
   MOBILE HOME LOT. A plat of ground designated for the accommodation of one
mobile home and the exclusive use of its occupants.
   MOBILE HOME NEIGHBORHOOD OR SUBDIVISION. An area designated and zoned by the
City, not in a mobile home park, where mobile homes are permitted and
encouraged on separately and privately owned lots.
   MOBILE HOME PARK. A contiguous parcel of land which has been developed for
the placement of two or more mobile homes to be occupied for dwelling purposes
and is owned by one person.
   MOBILE HOME PARK DEVELOPMENT PLAN. A plan bearing the written approval by
signature and seal of a registered architect, engineer or land surveyor
licensed in the state, showing all existing conditions of a proposed mobile
home park site, and the preliminary plans on a topographic map of the proposed
development, including all buildings, improvements and facilities existing or
to be constructed therein.
   MOTOR HOME. A self-propelled travel vehicle designed as one unit to be used
principally as a dwelling for vacation use and can be operated independently of
utility connections, excluding pickup campers.
   NONRESIDENTIAL MOBILE TRAILER. Any vehicle having the basic characteristics
of either a mobile home or travel trailer, but which is used for purposes other
than residential and is not being offered for sale.
   OCCUPANCY PERMIT. A written permit issued by the Code Official permitting
the placement of a mobile home upon a mobile home lot.
   PARK MANAGEMENT. The person who owns or has charge, care or control of a
mobile home park.
   SEWER CONNECTION. The connection consisting of all pipes, fittings and
appurtenances from the drain outlet of the mobile home to the inlet of the
corresponding sewer riser pipe of the sewerage serving the mobile home park.
   STRUCTURAL ADDITION. Any roofed, canopied or enclosed porch, room or
structure used in connection with a mobile home; provided that the construction
of a concrete slab porch without a roof or walls shall not be a structural
addition.
   TRAVEL TRAILER. A portable unit designed principally as a temporary vacation
dwelling to be towed on its own chassis by a passenger automobile, and can be
operated independently of utility connections. The term shall not include
camping trailers.
   TRAVEL TRAILER PARK. Any plot of ground upon which two or more travel
trailers, occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes, are located regardless of
whether or not a charge is made for such accommodations and whether or not it
is a part of a mobile home park.
   WATER CONNECTION. The connection consisting of all pipes, fittings and
appurtenances from the water riser pipe to the water inlet pipe of the
distribution system within the mobile home.
(1994 Code, § 19-2) (Prior Code, § 9-12-2) (Ord. 2024-11, passed 8-6-2024)
§ 9-12-3 MOBILE HOME PARK LICENSING REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Application for license; general requirements.
      (1)   Contents of application. Every person, firm or corporation desiring
to create, establish, develop or construct a mobile home park, or expand a
mobile home park, shall make written application, upon forms to be provided, to
the Code Official for a mobile home park license. Such written application
shall include the following:
         (a)   Applicant’s name and mailing address; and
         (b)   Five copies of a mobile home park development plan, to include
the following, on a scaled drawing of an appropriate dimension prepared by a
registered engineer, architect or land surveyor so indicated by signature and
seal:
            1.   A north arrow, date, scale and appropriate legend;
            2.   Two foot contour intervals;
            3.   Location and size of all easements, utilities and rights-of-
way existing and proposed;
            4.   All public and private street names;
            5.   Location and size of all proposed mobile home spaces, utility
and drainage easements, public streets and rights-of-way, private drives with
surface types, walkways, parking spaces with surface types, drainage
improvements, recreational spaces, screening, offices, laundry buildings and
any other contemplated permanent structures or improvements;
            6.   Location and size of all existing or proposed permanent
improvements, including pads, off street parking with surface types and
utilities; and
            7.   All proposed front, side and rear yard setback distances.
      (2)   Site plan submittal; hearing. The mobile home park site plan shall
be submitted to the Planning Commission for review, study and recommendation.
The same shall then be submitted to the City Council for approval, denial or
conditional approval only after said Board conducts a public hearing concerning
such development plan. Once approved, the land covered by such mobile home park
plan shall be developed in accordance therewith as approved, and any change,
modification, revision or deviation therefrom may be grounds for the revocation
of the mobile home park license issued, and deemed a violation of this chapter.
      (3)   City may require certain park modifications. The Planning
Commission or the City Council may require certain alterations, modifications
or amendments of the mobile home park development plan when deemed necessary
for the inclusion of easements, rights-of-way, utilities or any other amendment
necessary for the general welfare of the public.
      (4)   Improvement bonds. Improvement bonds may also be required to be
furnished on the subject property for public streets, water lines, sewer lines,
drainage structures and all other public improvements.
   (B)   Inspection for compliance; license issuance; fee.
      (1)   Upon the completion of a mobile home park, or the expansion of a
mobile home park, the Code Official shall be immediately notified of the same
by the permittee. After such notification, the Code Official, without
unnecessary delay, shall cause there to be an inspection of the mobile home
park, and if the said mobile home park has been developed and constructed in
compliance with all the pertinent provisions of this chapter and in accordance
with the approved mobile home park development plan, the Code Official shall
issue to the permittee a license to operate a mobile home park.
      (2)   No person shall operate any mobile home park within the City unless
he holds a valid license issued annually by the Director of Finance in the name
of such person for the specific mobile home park.
      (3)   In addition to the requirements as set forth herein to obtain a
license for the operation of a mobile home park, a fee as provided in §
2-6B-12(B) shall be paid to the City.
      (4)   All mobile home park licenses shall expire June 30 and all fees for
the ensuing year are due and payable prior thereto. Original fees for a license
may be prorated to June 30 of the following year, when appropriate.
   (C)   Transfer of license; notification.
      (1)   Every person holding a license shall give notice in writing to the
Code Official within ten days before having sold, transferred, given away or
otherwise disposed of his interest in, or control of, any mobile home park.
Such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the
ownership or control of such mobile home park. Upon application in writing for
transfer of the license and deposit of a fee in the amount provided in §
2-6B-12(C), the license shall be transferred, if the mobile home park is in
compliance with all applicable provisions of this chapter.
      (2)   After an on site inspection is performed by the Code Official,
written notice shall be given to the person holding the license and the person,
firm or corporation receiving the license, of any repairs, improvements or
other requirements which must be corrected within a specified period of time
determined by the Code Official.
      (3)   Transfer of the license may be permitted after both parties have
received written notification. However, responsibility for repairs,
improvements or requirements specified by the Code Official shall then be to
the person receiving the license.
   (D)   Suspension of license; notice; hearing.
      (1)   Whenever, upon inspection of any mobile home park, the Code
Official or any other authorized city officers or employees or the health
authority finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of
any provision of this chapter, such inspecting officer shall give notice in
writing to the person to whom the license was issued that such conditions or
practices shall be corrected within a reasonable period of time specified in
the notice. At the end of such period, the party issuing the notice shall
reinspect such mobile home park and, if such conditions or practices have not
been corrected, he shall file a complaint against the person to whom the
license was issued for the violation.
      (2)   If such person is found guilty by a municipal court, the license
shall be suspended after a hearing before the Code Official giving due process
and an opportunity to be heard.
(1994 Code, §§ 19-53, 19-54, 19-55 and 19-56) (Prior Code, § 9-12-3)
§ 9-12-4 OCCUPANCY PERMIT.
   (A)   Permit required. No mobile home lot shall be occupied by a mobile home
without the issuance of an occupancy permit by the Code Official.
   (B)   Application required; contents. Any person desiring to move a mobile
home onto any mobile home lot shall first make written application to the Code
Official, such application shall include the following:
      (1)   Applicant’s name;
      (2)   Mobile home park title and mobile home lot description; and
      (3)   A plot plan of the mobile home lot indicating the proposed location
of the mobile home.
   (C)   Inspection of plot plan. Upon inspection of the mobile home plot plan,
the Code Official shall grant or deny the applicant permission to move the
mobile home onto the mobile home lot.
   (D)   Inspection of mobile home on lot. The applicant shall then move the
mobile home onto the mobile home lot and immediately notify the Code Official
that the mobile home is in place. However, the tractor used to transport the
mobile home shall not be disconnected until an on site inspection is performed
by the Code Official, or his representative.
   (E)   Setback requirements. Upon notification, the Code Official, or his
representative, shall immediately inspect the mobile home lot to ensure all
setback requirements are in compliance with §§
9-12-16 and
9-12-17 .
   (F)   Permission for occupancy. If the mobile home is determined to be in
compliance with applicable setback distances, permission shall then be given to
prepare the mobile home for occupancy.
   (G)   Inspection of mobile home for compliance. Upon notification, the Code
Official shall perform a final inspection to determine if the mobile home is in
compliance with the provision of this chapter. If the mobile home is found to
be in compliance, the Code Official shall then issue an occupancy permit.
   (H)   Permit fee. The fee for an occupancy permit required under this
section shall be as provided in §
2-6B-12(D), and shall be payable to the Director of Finance.
(1994 Code, § 19-57) (Prior Code, § 9-12-4)
§ 9-12-5 PREEXISTING OR NONCONFORMING USES.
   (A)   Nonconforming parks allowed; expansion excepted. Mobile home parks
developed on or before February 12, 1984, shall not be governed by the
regulations and standards established in this chapter unless specifically
otherwise stated herein; provided, however, that no existing mobile home park
shall be permitted to expand beyond its existing boundaries or have placed a
greater number of mobile homes or travel trailers within its existing
boundaries unless the new area developed and the additional units conform to
all of the regulations and standards of this chapter.
   (B)   Nonconforming mobile homes allowed. All nonconforming individual
mobile homes legally in use as dwellings on June 1, 1983, may continue in their
existing condition by annually securing a license under the terms of this
chapter.
   (C)   Alteration in mobile home. Any alteration in the mobile home or its
environment or change in ownership may invalidate its license and subject the
owner to liability to penalties provided under this chapter.
   (D)   Record of parks, freestanding mobile homes. The City Clerk shall keep
complete and accurate permanent records which provide applicable information
for all mobile home parks and freestanding mobile homes entitled to continue
occupancy under the terms of this section.
(1994 Code, § 19-3) (Prior Code, § 9-12-5)
§ 9-12-6 LOCATION RESTRICTIONS.
   All mobile home parks, travel trailer parks and mobile home neighborhoods
shall be situated only in those districts where authorized by the zoning
ordinances of the City, which are as follows:
   (A)   Mobile home parks, R-6;
   (B)   Travel trailer parks, C-3, R-6;
   (C)   Mobile home neighborhoods or subdivisions, R-3; and
   (D)   Freestanding mobile homes, R-3, A Agriculture.
(1994 Code, § 19-4) (Prior Code, § 9-12-6)
§ 9-12-7 MOBILE HOME NEIGHBORHOODS; FREESTANDING MOBILE HOMES.
   (A)   Location by owner. A lot in a mobile home neighborhood residential
area, as determined by zoning ordinances, under separate ownership and having
no structure thereon may be used by the owner of said lot for the location of
one mobile home for his own place of residence.
   (B)   Continuance of nonconforming use; permit. A single mobile home lot not
in an approved mobile home park or neighborhood which legally existed on or
before February 12, 1984, may continue to operate as such; provided, however,
that within 60 days from that day, the owner of any said mobile home lot shall
have obtained a permit from the Director of Finance for said mobile home lot.
Failure to make initial application for such permit within the time required
shall be presumptive evidence that such mobile home lot did not exist on or
before February 12, 1984.
   (C)   Connection to utilities required. The owner of any single mobile home
lot occupied by a mobile home shall connect to all available utilities and
shall pay to the City the same monthly fees for water, sewer and garbage pickup
service, and shall be subject to the same penalties for nonpayment of such fees
as are prescribed by ordinance of the City for single-family dwelling units,
including discontinuance of such service.
   (D)   Inspections. Any single mobile home or mobile home lot located within
the City not in a “mobile home park” as defined in §
9-12-2 shall comply with all regulations herein contained concerning the
inspection by the health authority, city and Fire Marshal.
   (E)   Application of provisions. The provisions of this section shall apply;
provided that they do not violate any plat restrictions or private covenants
applicable to the lot on which a permit for a mobile home or a mobile home lot
is requested.
(1994 Code, § 19-5) (Prior Code, § 9-12-7)
§ 9-12-8 RESIDENTIAL USE OF TRAVEL TRAILERS, CAMPERS.
   (A)   Use as dwellings prohibited. The use, occupancy or location of travel
trailers, camp trailers or pickup campers as dwellings is prohibited.
   (B)   Location restrictions. The use, occupancy or location of travel
trailers, dependent camp trailers within mobile home parks or mobile home
neighborhoods is prohibited.
   (C)   Parking on public street. No mobile home, camp trailer or travel
trailer shall be parked on any public street, thoroughfare or right-of-way.
(1994 Code, § 19-6) (Prior Code, § 9-12-8)
§ 9-12-9 COMMERCIAL USE OF MOBILE HOMES.
   (A)   Temporary permit for builders, demonstrations, exhibitions.
      (1)   Builders, subdividers, exhibitors and others who desire to use
mobile homes or travel trailers temporarily at certain locations for field
offices, demonstrations and exhibitions of certain equipment therein or for
charitable purposes may do so upon the issuance of a temporary mobile home or
travel trailer permit issued by the Director of Finance upon order of the Code
Official.
      (2)   The sale of any items from any home or travel trailer used in
conjunction with any demonstration or exhibition, except for charitable
purposes, shall be prohibited.
      (3)   The fee for the permit shall be as provided in §
2-6B-12(A) and shall be payable to the Director of Finance. The permit shall be
issued for a period not to exceed 30 days and shall be subject to renewal by
approval of the Code Official and the payment of the appropriate fees.
      (4)   The Code Official shall order the issuance or denial of the permit
within five working days of the filing of the application. Charitable and non-
profit organizations are exempt from said fee.
   (B)   Water and sewer connections. Where placement of a mobile home or
travel trailer is contemplated for employee occupancy for a period of time
greater than 30 days, water and sanitary sewer connections shall be installed
unless such connections are not required by §
8-3A-5 .
   (C)   Occupancy and use restrictions.
      (1)   Caretakers, custodians, night watchmen and other bona fide
employees or persons using mobile homes or travel trailers for commercial or
industrial purposes as herein set forth may, when required by the nature of
their employment, occupy such mobile homes as residences for themselves and
their families; provided that no more than one mobile home may be used for such
purposes by any commercial or industrial enterprise on property of 30 acres or
less.
      (2)   Additional mobile homes as required for the purposes herein set
forth may be thereafter situated on land held by single or common ownership;
provided that no more than one mobile home may be so situated for each
additional 30 acres of property. Nothing herein shall be construed to permit
the placement of a mobile home on any tract of land that comprises an existing
structure presently being used as a residence.
      (3)   Nothing herein shall be construed to permit the establishment of
any public enterprise other than those herein provided.
   (D)   Location in mobile home parks prohibited. No repair facility or home
business of any kind shall be permitted, authorized, maintained or allowed
within a mobile home park.
   (E)   Sale of mobile homes. The commercial sale of mobile homes within a
mobile home park or in conjunction with the maintenance and operation of a
mobile home park shall be conducted only on land that has been appropriately
zoned in which such sales are permitted.
(1994 Code, § 19-7) (Prior Code, § 9-12-9)
§ 9-12-10 INSECT, RODENT AND WEED CONTROL.
   All mobile home parks, mobile home neighborhoods and single mobile homes
shall comply with all ordinances containing provisions dealing with weeds,
debris, rodents, nuisances or any other obnoxious element.
(1994 Code, § 19-20) (Prior Code, § 9-12-10)
§ 9-12-11 INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   Inspection by city officials. The health authority, the Code Official
and other authorized city officers and employees shall make inspections to
determine the condition of mobile home parks in order that they may perform
their duty of safeguarding the health and safety of the occupants therein and
of the general public.
   (B)   Right of entry. Subject to constitutional limitations, the inspection
officials shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon any private or
public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions
relating to the enforcement of this chapter.
   (C)   Allowing inspectors free access. The owners or occupants of mobile
home parks and mobile homes contained therein or the person in charge thereof
shall give the inspection officials free access to such premises at reasonable
times for the purpose of inspection.
   (D)   Access by park owner for repairs. Every occupant of a mobile home park
shall give the owner thereof or his agent or employee access to any part of
such mobile home park or to premises at reasonable times for the purpose of
making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with
this chapter.
   (E)   Annual inspection of parks. All mobile home parks shall be inspected
annually before the reissuance of a license. Alterations and repairs may be
required before the mobile home license is issued in order to enforce the
provisions of this chapter.
(1994 Code, § 19-21) (Prior Code, § 9-12-11)
§ 9-12-12 REGISTRATION OF OCCUPANTS.
   (A)   Register required. Every mobile home park or operator shall maintain a
register containing a record of all mobile homes and occupants using the mobile
home park.
   (B)   Availability; preservation. The register shall be available to any
authorized person inspecting the park, and shall be preserved for a period of
three years.
   (C)   Contents of register. The register shall contain:
      (1)   The names and addresses of all mobile home occupants in the park;
      (2)   The make, model and license number of the mobile home;
      (3)   The state, territory or county issuing the mobile home permit; and
      (4)   The dates of arrival and departure of each mobile home.
(1994 Code, § 19-22) (Prior Code, § 9-12-12)
§ 9-12-13 COMMUNICABLE DISEASE REPORTS.
   Every owner, operator, attendant or other person operating a mobile home
park shall notify the health authority immediately of any suspected
communicable or contagious disease within the mobile home park.
(1994 Code, § 19-23) (Prior Code, § 9-12-13)
§ 9-12-14 SANITATION GENERALLY.
   The licensee, or a duly authorized attendant or caretaker, shall be in
charge at all times to keep the mobile home park, its facilities and equipment,
in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition. The attendant or caretaker shall be
answerable, with the licensee, for the violation of any provision of this
chapter. (1994 Code, § 19-24) (Prior Code, § 9-12-14)
§ 9-12-15 DIMENSIONAL AND SITE DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Size; street frontage. No mobile home park shall be developed,
constructed or maintained on a lot or tract of land of less than two and one-
half acres fronting on a major or minor arterial street. No drive within the
park shall have direct access to the arterial street.
   (B)   Circulation system for vehicular movement.
      (1)   A convenient circulation system for vehicular movement shall be
provided within a mobile home park by means of minor streets and properly
located collector streets.
      (2)   Collector streets shall be paved for a minimum width of 27 feet.
Other drives shall be paved for a minimum width of 20 feet.
      (3)   If parallel guest parking is desired, an additional seven feet
shall be provided on one side of a street. Parallel parking shall not be
permitted on both sides of any street.
      (4)   Dead end streets shall have a cul-de-sac with a diameter of no less
than 50 feet.
   (C)   Private streets; construction standards. All private streets within a
mobile home park shall be constructed of materials in accordance with the
following standards for sealed surface paving covering either earth, gravel or
other natural or artificial base or foundation, and approved by the City
Engineer:
      (1)   A minimum of three to four inches of rock aggregate not to exceed
one and one-half inches of crusher-run limestone spread, rolled and packed into
a properly drained area; then, to be primed with a minimum coat of MCI, RC 70,
or 250) asphalt equal to an amount of 0.25 to 0.30 gallons per square yard; and
then, to be sprayed with an equal amount of MC800 or AC4; then, to be covered
with a minimum coat or layer or three-eighths inch of limestone chips, broomed
or rolled into the surface;
      (2)   Three inches of hot asphaltic concrete on a four inch base of
compacted soil, gravel or a base thickness equivalent thereto; or
      (3)   Five inches of portland cement concrete with a minimum of 3,000 psi
on a two-inch sand cushion base.
   (D)   Maintenance of streets. All private streets within a mobile home park
shall be maintained in good condition.
   (E)   Subdivision street paving standards. All public streets within a
mobile home park shall be constructed in accordance with the subdivision street
paving standards of the City, and approved by the City Engineer.
   (F)   Drainage of surface water. Adequate facilities for drainage of surface
water shall be provided for within a mobile home park, to include proper
grading and, where necessary, the installation of gutters, culverts, catch
basins, drain inlets, storm and water sewers or other satisfactory drainage
systems.
   (G)   Drainage plans required; approval. All drainage plans shall be
prepared by a professional engineer and submitted to the City Engineer for
approval prior to the issuance of any mobile home park permit.
   (H)   Buffer zones and screening.
      (1)   A buffer zone of not less than 20 feet in width from the property
line of a mobile home park to the nearest home therein shall be required to
provide a continuous buffer along all side and rear yards of the mobile home
park.
      (2)   A buffer zone of not less than 25 feet in depth shall be provided
to extend along the entire frontage of the mobile home park where the said park
abuts a public street or thoroughfare.
      (3)   Screening of seventy-five percent (75%) opaque and six feet in
height by any combination of adequate fencing, landscaping or planting to
provide visual separation and privacy shall be provided where a mobile home
park abuts an incompatible use or zoning district and where existing foliage
within the buffer zone provided is not sufficient for screening purposes.
   (I)   Lighting. All interior streets and pedestrian walkways within a mobile
home park shall be lighted with lamp posts placed at intervals of not less than
300 feet.
(1994 Code, § 19-35) (Prior Code, § 9-12-15)
§ 9-12-16 INDIVIDUAL LOT REQUIREMENTS.
   Each mobile home park space or lot for a mobile home shall satisfy all of
the requirements of §
11-6C-5(B).
(1994 Code, § 19-36) (2003 Code) (Prior Code, § 9-12-16)
§ 9-12-17 INDIVIDUAL MOBILE HOME REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Location. No mobile home, addition, storage building or related
structure shall be located within five feet of any lot line; except, however,
no mobile home addition or storage building shall be located, constructed or
maintained within any dedicated easement, right-of-way, buffer area or drainage
area. See also §
11-6G-5(C).
   (B)   Tie down standards. All mobile homes shall be securely tied down in
accordance with the standards provided in the Building Code.
   (C)   Anchoring. All mobile homes shall be securely anchored in accordance
with the standards provided in the Building Code.
   (D)   Skirting. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or occupant of
any mobile home, within a period of no longer than ten days upon the issuance
of an occupancy permit, to cause such mobile home to be totally skirted of
metal or other noncombustible solid material in such a manner to prevent the
intrusion of animals under said home. Failure to provide said skirting within
the prescribed time period shall subject the owner to penalties provided under
this chapter.
(1994 Code, § 19-37) (Prior Code, § 9-12-17)
§ 9-12-18 WATER SUPPLY.
   (A)   Potable supply required.
      (1)   An accessible, adequate, safe and potable supply of water shall be
provided in each mobile home park, capable of furnishing a minimum of 150
gallons per day per mobile home lot.
      (2)   The development and use of an independent water supply to serve the
mobile home park shall be made only after express approval has been granted by
the health authority.
      (3)   Where a public supply of potable water is available pursuant to the
requirements of §
8-2-2 within the boundaries of the mobile home park, connection shall be made
thereto and its supply shall be used exclusively.
   (B)   Connection to system. The water system of the mobile home park shall
be connected by pipes to all buildings and all mobile home lots.
   (C)   Construction and maintenance. All water piping shall be constructed
and maintained in accordance with state and local plumbing codes. The water
piping system shall not be connected with nonpotable or questionable water
supplies and shall be protected against the hazards of backflow or back
siphonage.
   (D)   Individual water system.
      (1)   Where an individual water system is used to serve the mobile home
park, the source, distribution and storage system shall comply with the minimum
requirements of the Oklahoma Department of Health for public water supplies.
      (2)   Underground stop and waste valves shall not be installed on any
water service.
      (3)   The mobile home park water system shall be adequate to provide 30
pounds per square inch of pressure at all mobile home connections.
   (E)   Water line compliance with city specifications. Water lines shall be
in accordance with city specification.
(1994 Code, § 19-38) (Prior Code, § 9-12-18)
§ 9-12-19 SEWAGE DISPOSAL.
   (A)   Compliance with state and local regulations. All plumbing in a mobile
home park shall comply with state and local plumbing laws and regulations.
   (B)   Discharge into public sewer system. Waste from showers, bathtubs,
flush toilets, urinals, lavatories and slop sinks in service and other
buildings within the park shall be discharged into a public sewer system in
compliance with applicable ordinances.
   (C)   Mobile home lot, connection. Each mobile home lot shall be provided
with a sewer at least four inches in diameter which shall be connected to
receive the waste from the shower, bathtub, flush toilet, lavatory and kitchen
sink of a mobile home harbored in such lot and having any or all of such
facilities. The sewer in each lot shall be connected to discharge the mobile
home park waste into a public system in compliance with applicable ordinances.
   (D)   Fittings; watertight connection. The sewer connection shall be
provided with suitable fittings, so that a watertight connection can be made
between the mobile home drain and the sewer connection. Such individual mobile
home connections shall be so constructed that they can be closed when not
linked to a mobile home and shall be capped so as to prevent any escape of
odors.
   (E)   Sewer line construction. Sewer lines shall be constructed in
accordance with specifications of the Health Department and the City. All sewer
lines shall be adequately vented, and shall be laid with sufficient earth cover
to prevent breakage from traffic.
   (F)   Private disposal facilities; restrictions.
      (1)   Where the sewer lines of the mobile home park cannot be connected
to a public sewer, a method of sewage disposal approved by the Health
Department and the City shall be provided. The design of such sewage treatment
facilities shall be based on the maximum capacity of the mobile home park.
      (2)   Effluents from sewage treatment facilities shall not be discharged
into any water of the state except with prior approval of the appropriate state
authority and the Health Department.
      (3)   The disposal facilities shall be located where they will not create
a nuisance or health hazard to the mobile home park or to the owner or
occupants of any adjacent property.
      (4)   The approval of the Health Department and the City shall be
obtained on the type of treatment proposed and on the design of the disposal
plant prior to construction.
   (G)   Plumbing alterations and repairs. All plumbing alterations and repairs
shall be made in accordance with applicable ordinances and regulations.
(1994 Code, § 19-39) (Prior Code, § 9-12-19)
§ 9-12-20 NATURAL GAS.
   (A)   Compliance with state and local regulations. A natural gas system, if
utilized, shall be designed, installed and maintained in accordance with all
pertinent provisions of the applicable ordinances of the City and laws of the
state.
   (B)   Installation by licensed contractor. All gas piping shall be
installed, repaired and maintained by a licensed contractor only.
   (C)   Inspection and testing. The gas supply shall be connected in the
proper manner, ensuring that piping is properly purged and free from leaks. A
gas pressure inspection shall be required by the Code Official to ensure the
system is free from any leaks incurred during mobile home transport.
   (D)   Proper disconnection upon moving mobile home. Before a mobile home is
moved, adequate arrangements shall be made to assure that all gas connections
are properly disconnected.
   (E)   Liquid petroleum gas prohibited; exception.
      (1)   The use, installation or storage of liquid petroleum gas within any
mobile home park constructed after February 12, 1984, shall be prohibited.
      (2)   The use of liquid petroleum gas shall be permitted for freestanding
mobile homes or within mobile home neighborhoods if installed and stored in
strict accordance with all applicable provisions of the International Fire
Code, the ordinances of the City and inspected by the Code Official or Fire
Marshal of the City.
(1994 Code, § 19-40) (2003 Code) (Prior Code, § 9-12-20)
§ 9-12-21 ELECTRICITY.
   (A)   Design; lines underground. The electricity system shall be designed to
provide adequate capacity to supply the connected load without exceeding the
current carrying capacity of the connectors. All electrical lines shall be
placed underground, except for higher voltage lines, as determined by the
public utility.
   (B)   Facilities provided. The permittee shall provide electricity supply
facilities for and to each mobile home with readily accessible means of
disconnecting the same, and shall provide a grounding type supply receptacle
with appropriate fuses or circuit breakers for each mobile home.
   (C)   Proper disconnection before moving mobile home. Before a mobile home
is moved, adequate arrangements shall be made to assure that both electrical
supply and ground connections are properly disconnected.
   (D)   Compliance with regulations. All electrical work, alterations and
repairs shall be made in accordance with applicable ordinances and regulations.
(1994 Code, § 19-41) (Prior Code, § 9-12-21)
§ 9-12-22 FIRE PROTECTION.
   (A)   Rules and regulations. The mobile home park area shall be subject to
the rules and regulations governing fire prevention and safety.
   (B)   Parking of tow car or mobile home on streets. No tow car or mobile
home shall be parked, placed or allowed to remain at any time on a public or
private street, or pedestrian walkway within a mobile home park.
   (C)   Fire hydrants, water mains.
      (1)   Fire hydrants and water mains of adequate size and number shall be
provided for within a mobile home park.
      (2)   Fire hydrants shall be located no greater than 400 feet apart as
measured by street travel, requiring the inspection and approval of the Fire
Chief.
(1994 Code, § 19-42) (Prior Code, § 9-12-22)
§ 9-12-23 REFUSE DISPOSAL.
   (A)   Removal by city. All refuse, debris, trash and garbage in a mobile
home park shall be removed by the City in accordance with all ordinances.
   (B)   Collection and disposal. Methods and facilities for the collection,
storage, handling and disposal of garbage and refuse shall be provided for as
determined and in accordance with
Title 8, Chapter 4  relating thereto.
   (C)   Refuse containers.
      (1)   All refuse containers shall be located upon a concrete pad in
designated areas for collection.
      (2)   In addition, all collection areas shall be screened on three sides
with fencing, vegetation or any combination thereof for a height of not less
than five feet.
(1994 Code, § 19-43) (Prior Code, § 9-12-23)
§ 9-12-24 SERVICE, ADMINISTRATIVE AND OTHER BUILDINGS.
   (A)   Mobile home as office; other buildings. One mobile home within a
mobile home park may be used as an administrative office. Other administrative
offices, and service buildings for housing sanitation, laundry or other
facilities shall be of permanent structure, complying with all pertinent
provisions of this code relating to construction and maintenance, for the use
of all the park.
   (B)   Service buildings. All service buildings shall be adequately lighted
at all times, well ventilated with screened openings and constructed of such
moistureproof material, including painted woodwork to permit repeated cleaning
and washing and shall have an adequate supply of both hot and cold water.
   (C)   Maintenance. All service buildings and the grounds of a mobile home
park shall be maintained in a clean and sightly condition, free from any
condition that will menace the health of any mobile home park resident therein
or constitute a nuisance.
(1994 Code, § 19-44) (Prior Code, § 9-12-24)
§ 9-12-25 STRUCTURAL ADDITIONS, ALTERATIONS OR MODIFICATIONS.
   (A)   Building permit required; exception. Any structural addition,
alteration or modification to a mobile home, other than those which are built
into a mobile home unit and designed to fold out or extend from it, shall be
done only when first having obtained a building permit from the Code Official
prior to construction, and then in accordance with all pertinent provisions of
this code relating to building; provided, a building permit for the addition of
a metal or noncombustible canopy, not to exceed ten feet in width, is not
required.
   (B)   Permanent addition prohibited. No permanent additions shall be built
onto or become a part of any mobile home located in a mobile home park.
   (C)   Storage structures. No structure other than a mobile home shall be
permitted on a mobile home park space or lot, except that one structure
constructed of metal or other noncombustible material shall be permitted for
storage. Storage structures shall be limited in size to 100 square feet and
seven feet in height.
(1994 Code, § 19-45) (Prior Code, § 9-12-25)
