CHAPTER 1: METROPOLITAN AREA PLANNING COMMISSION
Section
   
10-1-1   Commission organization; agreement with county
   
10-1-2   Appointment; terms
   
10-1-3   Designation as City Planning Commission
§ 10-1-1 COMMISSION ORGANIZATION; AGREEMENT WITH COUNTY.
   The City has availed itself of the provisions of 19 O.S. §§ 866.1 through
866.34 and entered into an agreement with the Board of County Commissioners of
Garfield County for the organization of a Metropolitan Area Planning
Commission.
§ 10-1-2 APPOINTMENT; TERMS.
   (A)   Appointment of members. The Mayor, by and with the consent of the
Board of Commissioners, is hereby authorized and directed to appoint four
members of this Commission as provided by law. The Mayor may also appoint one
of the Board of Commissioners to serve as an ex officio member of this
Commission. The Mayor and Board of Commissioners are authorized to appoint one
additional member of the Commission. Appointees shall be residents of the City
for a period of three years or more immediately preceding their appointment and
shall hold no other municipal office except those expressly provided for by
state law.
   (B)   Term of office. The members of this Commission shall hold office for a
term of four years or until their successors are appointed and qualified. The
appointments shall be made in such a manner that the term of every member shall
expire in March of each year.
§ 10-1-3 DESIGNATION AS CITY PLANNING COMMISSION.
   The Metropolitan Area Planning Commission is hereby designated as the
Planning Commission for the City.
CHAPTER 2: BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT
Section
   
10-2-1   Board created
   
10-2-2   Membership; appointment
   
10-2-3   Meetings and rules
§ 10-2-1 BOARD CREATED.
   Whereas, the City is exercising zoning powers as conferred by 11 O.S. §§ 43-
101 through 43-109, the City hereby provides for the appointment of a Board of
Adjustment.
§ 10-2-2 MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT.
   (A)   Appointment. This Board shall consist of five residents of the City,
each appointed by the City Council, for a term of three years.
   (B)   Chairman. The Board of Adjustment shall elect a Chairman and Vice
Chairman from its membership. The Chairman and Vice Chairman shall serve as
such for the term of their appointment.
   (C)   Compensation. All members of the Board shall serve without
compensation.
   (D)   Removal; hearing. A Board member may be removed by the City Council
for cause upon the filing of written charges and after a public hearing before
the City Council.
   (E)   Vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of any
member in the manner set forth for appointments to a full term.
   (F)   Term limit. No person shall serve more than two terms in succession.
However, partial terms shall not be considered in determining the term limit.
§ 10-2-3 MEETINGS AND RULES.
   (A)   Rules.
      (1)   Meetings of this Board shall be held at the call of the Chairman
and at such other times as the Board of Adjustment may determine.
      (2)   The Chairman, or in his absence the Vice Chairman, may administer
oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses.
      (3)   The Board shall be subject to the Open Meeting Laws of the state,
see 25 O.S. §§ 301 et seq., and all voting of the Board shall be open to the
public.
      (4)   A city staff member shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing
the vote of each Board member upon each question, or, if absent or failing to
vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep record of all official actions.
   (B)   Scheduled meetings. Meetings of the Board of Adjustment shall be held
at 4:00 p.m. on the second Tuesday of each month. Additional meetings may be
held upon determination of the Board.
   (C)   Voting. The concurring vote of at least three members of the Board
shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination
being appealed from, to decide in favor of the applicant, or to decide any
matter which may properly come before it pursuant to Title 11.
CHAPTER 3: HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION
Section
   
10-3-1   Creation of Historic Preservation Commission
   
10-3-2   Members
   
10-3-3   Terms; compensation
   
10-3-4   Meeting and rules
   
10-3-5   Duties
§ 10-3-1 CREATION OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION.
   There is hereby created the Historic Preservation Commission of the City.
The Metropolitan Area Planning Commission will be select one of its members to
serve on this Commission. The other members shall be appointed by the Mayor
with the approval of the Board of Commissioners. In making appointments the
Mayor shall maintain a balance of interests and skills by assessing the
individual’s qualifications, including, but not limited to, their knowledge or
interest in any one or more of the following: architecture, history, landscape
architecture, structural engineering, lending and finance and commerce. All
members shall have knowledge of, and interest in, historic preservation and
will have demonstrated their civic interest and knowledge of the history of the
community.
§ 10-3-2 MEMBERS.
   This Commission shall be composed of the following persons, all of whom
shall be residents of the City.
   (A)   One member shall be a registered architect, or if no registered
architect is willing to serve, an individual with a demonstrated interest in
historic preservation or experience in restoration.
   (B)   One member shall be a historian.
   (C)   One member shall be an attorney.
   (D)   One member shall be a licensed real estate broker or a banker.
   (E)   One member of the Metropolitan Area Planning Commission who shall be
elected by the Metropolitan Area Planning Commission.
   (F)   One member from each designated Historic Preservation District within
the City.
§ 10-3-3 TERMS; COMPENSATION.
   (A)   The terms for each member shall be two years or until his successor
takes office.
   (B)   Members may be appointed to fill the remainder of a vacant term. There
is no limitation on serving consecutive terms.
   (C)   All members of the Commission shall serve without compensation.
§ 10-3-4 MEETING AND RULES.
   (A)   The Commission shall be empowered to adopt rules for the conduct of
its business. The Commission shall elect a Chairman who shall serve for one
year and who shall be eligible for reelection. The Commission shall elect a
Vice Chairman who shall serve for one year and who shall be eligible for
reelection.
   (B)   All meetings of the Commission shall be held as determined by the
Commission at a frequency and at time determined and delivered to the City
Clerk before December 15 of each year and shall be open to the public. Meetings
may be canceled if there is no business to be conducted. Special meetings may
be called as needed.
   (C)   Any person, or his duly appointed representative, shall be entitled to
appear and be heard on any matter before the Commission.
   (D)   The Commission shall keep a record of its proceedings, a copy of which
shall be filed for public view in the Office of the City Clerk.
   (E)   No business of the Commission may be conducted unless a quorum of not
less than five members is present. A simple majority of those present is
sufficient to approve or disprove any act or action of this Commission.
   (F)   The Planning Administrator, or the designated representative of such
Administrator, shall act as secretary of the Commission and shall attend and
keep the minutes of all meetings. This person shall act in an advisory capacity
only and may participate in the Commission’s discussions but shall have no
vote. The Planning Administrator and the staff of the Community Development
Department shall assist the Commission in discharging its duties.
§ 10-3-5 DUTIES.
   Unless otherwise specified in §§
11-10B-1 through
11-10B-19, the duties of the Historic Preservation Commission shall include,
but may not be limited to, the duty to:
   (A)   Prepare, or cause to be prepared, a comprehensive inventory of
historic, architectural and archaeological resources within the City;
   (B)   Prepare, or cause to be prepared, a general historic preservation plan
to be incorporated within the Comprehensive Plan of the City;
   (C)   Prepare findings of fact relating to the recommendation for
designation of historic, architectural and archaeological resources;
   (D)   Prepare findings of fact pursuant to action taken by the Commission
relating to certificates of appropriateness;
   (E)   Make recommendations to the City Council concerning the acquisition of
development rights, facade easements and the development of historic
preservation plans;
   (F)   Make recommendations to the City Council concerning grants from
federal and state agencies, private groups and individuals and the utilization
of budgetary appropriations to promote the preservation of historic,
architectural or archaeological resources; and, when so directed by the City
Council, may oversee historic projects or programs;
   (G)   Increase public awareness of the value of historic, architectural or
archaeological resources by developing and participating in public information
programs and by recommending the update of the preservation program and by the
giving of advice to owners or residents of such resources as to the problems
and techniques of preservation work; and further, by placing monuments and
markers at historic sites as chosen by the Commission;
   (H)   Comment and make recommendations concerning actions undertaken by
other city agencies or actions of other governmental units with respect to the
effect of such actions upon historic, architectural and archaeological
resources;
   (I)   Conduct a periodic review of the status of designated landmarks and
historic districts and provide periodic reports on the findings of said review,
along with any resolutions for action, as considered appropriate, to the City
Council; and
   (J)   Review requests for demolition of properties listed in the National
Register of Historic Places and make comments and recommendations to the
property owners with respect to the degree to which the proposed removal of the
historic structure would serve to change the overall historic culture of the
community.
CHAPTER 4: GRADING, LAND SURFACE CHANGES AND NUMBERING BUILDINGS
Section
   
10-4-1   Grading or land surface changes
   
10-4-2   Numbering required
   
10-4-3   System of numbering
   
10-4-4   Dividing line for numbering purposes
   
10-4-5   Division of streets for numbering purposes
   
10-4-6   One number per lot; irregular sized lots
   
10-4-7   Duty of owners and agents to number buildings
§ 10-4-1 GRADING OR LAND SURFACE CHANGES.
   (A)   Permit required; fee.
      (1)   No person shall change the grade of any land (filling, excavating
or raising) by one foot or more or change the permeable nature of the surface
of the soil without first having obtained a permit from the City Engineer,
which may require a drainage report.
      (2)   The application for such permit shall show the amount of the fill
to be made, the substance to be used for the fill and the general topography of
the land of the applicant and the land surroundings.
      (3)   A fee in the amount provided in §
2-6F-12 shall be submitted with the application to cover the cost of plan
review.
      (4) After filing an application, the City Engineer shall inspect the
premises to be graded or changed and shall issue the permit if it is determined
by said inspection the grading or changing would not obstruct or change the
capacity of any drainage channel or waterway or cause floodwaters to invade
other areas and that it is not in violation of this section.
   (B)   Fill materials. No debris, noxious or organic material shall be used
for a fill or to raise or level ground, at any place in any amount.
§ 10-4-2 NUMBERING REQUIRED.
   All buildings and residences in the City shall be numbered and lettered as
provided in this chapter.
§ 10-4-3 SYSTEM OF NUMBERING.
   The system of numbering shall be as follows.
   (A)   Blocks. Each block shall contain not more than 100 numbers, beginning
at a point on Broadway and Grand Avenue, east from Grand Avenue on Broadway
Street the numbering shall be as follows.
      (1)   The first building on the south side of Broadway Street and east on
Grand Avenue shall be number 101.
      (2)   The first building on the north side of Broadway and east of Grand
Avenue shall be number 102, and so on throughout the entire block.
      (3)   The first building on the south side of Broadway Street east of
Second Street shall be number 201, and so on throughout the entire length of
said street to its eastern terminus.
      (4)   The same system of numbering shall apply on Broadway west of Grand
Avenue beginning with number 101 on the south side of the first block and
number 201 on the south side of the second block and so to the western terminus
of said street.
   (B)   Streets running north and south. The numbering of the streets running
north and south shall be as follows.
      (1)   Using Broadway as the dividing line, the even numbers shall be on
the west side of the streets running north and south and the odd numbers on the
east side of the streets running north and south.
      (2)   The same system of numbering shall apply on all streets running
north and south beginning south of Broadway at number 101 and so on up to the
southern terminus of said street.
§ 10-4-4 DIVIDING LINE FOR NUMBERING PURPOSES.
   Broadway running east and west in the City shall be the dividing line north
and south and Grand Avenue running north and south shall be the dividing line
east and west.
§ 10-4-5 DIVISION OF STREETS FOR NUMBERING PURPOSES.
   All streets north of Broadway running north and south shall be known as
North Grand Avenue or North Independence Avenue and the like, and all streets
south of Broadway, South Grand Avenue or South Independence Avenue, as the case
may be. All streets running east and west shall be designated as follows: Those
west of Grand Avenue shall be known as West Monroe or West Broadway as the case
may be, and those east of Grand Avenue shall be known as East Monroe or East
Broadway as the case may be.
§ 10-4-6 ONE NUMBER PER LOT; IRREGULAR SIZED LOTS.
   In the business and residence districts, each 25-foot lot shall be entitled
to a number. If there is more than one place of business on any 25-foot lot,
each place of business shall be entitled to a letter. All building numbering,
lettering or addressing shall be designated by the Code Official.
§ 10-4-7 DUTY OF OWNERS AND AGENTS TO NUMBER BUILDINGS.
   Owners or agents of buildings erected shall, within ten days after the
erection of such buildings, cause to be placed thereon the numbers or letters
of such buildings provided for in this chapter.
CHAPTER 5: CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT AND RECOVERY
Section
   
10-5-1   Purpose
   
10-5-2   Definitions
   
10-5-3   Capital improvement requirements
   
10-5-4   Capital recovery for public improvements
   
10-5-5   Capital recovery special conditions for sanitary sewer improvements
   
10-5-6   Special conditions for stormwater improvements
   
10-5-7   Special conditions for water improvements
   
10-5-8   Special conditions for transportation improvements
   
10-5-9   City as developer
§ 10-5-1 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to encourage uniform and comprehensive
improvement of the City’s public infrastructure systems; to provide for the
equitable distribution of costs of these improvements; and to protect the
general health, safety and welfare of the residents of the City.
§ 10-5-2 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ADT. The average daily traffic count for a street based upon the 24-hour
volume over a specified number of days.
   ALLOWABLE COST. The cost of a capital recovery public improvement including
the cost of the construction, inspection fees, easements and rights-of-way
acquisition (at or below appraised value), advertising and recording and
engineering fees capped at seven percent (7%) of the bid construction amount
for a qualified project.
   ALLOWABLE RECOVERY COST (ARC). The amount, in dollars, of money subject to
collection based on an increased capacity improvement project.
   APPRAISED VALUE. The value of real property as determined by an independent
appraiser who is certified by the state.
   AREA OF IMPACT (AI). The area that receives a benefit from the installation
of the improvement.
   BUA. The undeveloped area in a particular area of impact in acres.
   “C” FACTOR. The coefficient of stormwater runoff as established in the
City’s Chart of Land Uses versus the average slope of the drainage area.
   CFS. Cubic feet per second.
   CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT. An improvement of the public infrastructure with a
value of $50,000 or more.
   CONNECTION. The tapping into a public utility line, or physical work that
allows a capital improvement to be used.
   DEVELOPER. The person, company or firm that is making the capital
improvement to service a development site. The City and its trusts may be
considered the DEVELOPER when it is the entity making the improvement.
   DEVELOPMENT. The act of improving property by subdividing, site planning,
construction on lot or building permitting.
   DEVELOPMENT SITE. The subdivision area, site plan area, building site or
tract of land on which the development occurs.
   DRAINAGE AREA. The area of land that stormwater would drain to or through at
a specified point.
   DRAINAGE SUBBASIN. An area within a drainage area to which drainage would
contribute to a submain of a sewer.
   FLOW CAPACITY. The flow rate of water that a channel will transfer within
its banks or the design capacity of a utility line or a transportation system.
   FLOW (Q). Volume over time calculated in cubic feet per second for water.
   FULLY DEVELOPED. A condition where the acreage within the associated area of
impact (AI) is considered to have been altered from its natural state to a
state that is consistent with the use identified in the most recent version of
the City’s Comprehensive Plan.
   GPD. Gallons per day.
   IMPROVEMENT. The construction of public infrastructure that connects an area
where city water, sewer, transportation or stormwater drainage systems were
previously unavailable or a developer’s upgrade to the existing systems.
   IMPROVEMENT COST. The actual cost of construction of the required capital
improvement including any approved change orders based upon bidding in
compliance with the Oklahoma Public Competitive Bidding Act, see 61 O.S. §§ 101
et seq., including noncollusion standards, the cost of easements and rights-of-
way at or below the appraised values, the cost of advertising and recording,
the cost of inspection by the City and the cost of engineering as provided in
this chapter.
   INCREASED CAPACITY. Capacity of a capital improvement project beyond the
capacity required for the development site providing the improvement.
   INCREASED CAPACITY AGREEMENT. The contract between the City, and the
“developer”, concerning the construction, operation and maintenance of an
increased capacity capital improvement system and payment of increased capacity
fees.
   INCREASED CAPACITY FEE (ICF). The amount of money to be paid by the post-
improvement developer for use of his proportionate share of the increased
capacity of an improvement constructed under §
10-4-4 . The FEE is paid to the City, for the user’s benefit of increased
capacity of the improvement. Such FEE shall be based upon the cost of providing
the increased capacity.
   LATERAL SEWER. A gathering sewer main of eight inches in diameter or more
and which function is to convey sewage from user service lines to the submain
or main sewer.
   MAIN DRAINAGE CHANNELS. Those channels identified by FEMA, Stormwater Master
Plan or otherwise designated in this chapter.
   ONE HUNDRED-YEAR STORM EVENT. A rain event that has a one percent (1%)
chance of occurring in any year.
   PEAK HOURLY WASTEWATER FLOW RATE. The maximum flow rate sustained for one
hour during a 24-hour period.
   PEAK STORMWATER DISCHARGE. The maximum flow rate that a particular
development will discharge based upon a 100-year storm event, as determined by
the engineer’s drainage report approved by the City.
   POST-IMPROVEMENT DEVELOPMENT. After the capital recovery, increased capacity
improvement is in place, any development that occurs in an area of impact or
any development that receives direct benefit from an increased capacity
improvement.
   PROJECTED TOTAL BASIN IMPACT. The total increase in the peak flow or use of
infrastructure compared to the full development condition. For stormwater, it
is the peak discharge of a basin from its existing condition prior to the
stormwater improvement compared to the full development condition.
   SERVICE LINE. That portion of a water or sanitary sewer line extending from
the public utility line or water meter to serve the customer.
   SEWER CAPACITY. The quantity of sewage that can be conveyed through a given
sewer flowing at its design peak level.
   SEWER MAIN. A sewer whose function is to convey sewage gathered from a
number of lateral sewers or submain sewers to a trunk line or treatment plant.
   SEWER SUBMAIN. Any sewer whose function is to convey sewage from lateral
sewers to a sewer main.
   STORMWATER. Rain runoff, snowmelt runoff, surface runoff, street wash waters
related to street cleaning and maintenance, infiltration (other than
infiltration contaminated by seepage from sanitary sewers or other discharges)
and drainage.
   STORMWATER CHANNELS. All natural and manmade structures, which convey
surface flood runoff water within the jurisdictional boundaries of the City.
   WATER LINE. All water mains, valves and hydrants which are laid, placed or
constructed in a public street, alley or easement and form a part of the water
system of the City.
   WATER MAIN CAPACITY. The quantity of water that can be conveyed through a
water main, flowing at its designed peak level.
§ 10-5-3 CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   The purpose of this section is to identify capital improvements required to
be provided by developers.
   (A)   Water system.
      (1)   New development sites shall extend the public water system across
the length of the subdivision or developed site.
      (2)   Water system improvements shall comply with §
8-2-14 and the City’s Engineering Design Standards.
   (B)   Sanitary sewer system.
      (1)   New development sites shall extend the public sanitary sewer system
to the site and to a point ten feet within all lots within the new development.
      (2)   Sanitary sewers shall comply with the City’s Engineering Design
Standards and shall be constructed to the size requirement specified in the
City’s Sanitary Sewer Master Plan, but not less than the capacity required for
the development site.
   (C)   Stormwater system.
      (1)   New development shall provide improvement of the public stormwater
system to transport stormwater through the development site in accordance with
Title 12, “Subdivisions”.
      (2)   New development shall mitigate the impact from the development site
by improving the downstream drainage ways to comply with Title 12, or provide
an improvement to mitigate the impact by on site detention or other acceptable
means. The mitigation shall cover the impact from the development site to the
main drainage channel as defined in the City’s Stormwater Master Plan.
   (D)   Transportation system.
      (1)   New development shall provide public roads within the development
that are in compliance with Title 12.
      (2)   Subdivision development on arterial streets shall provide
acceleration and deceleration lanes, per Title 12.
      (3)   Development, under Title 11, Chapter 11, shall provide public
infrastructure improvements as required by the site plan process to provide for
adequate and safe vehicular access to adjacent streets.
   (E)   Sidewalks. New development and redevelopment shall provide sidewalks
in accordance with §§
10-7-1 and
12-8-7 .
   (F)   Fire protection system. New development and redevelopment shall
provide fire hydrants in accordance with the International Fire Code as adopted
by the City.
§ 10-5-4 CAPITAL RECOVERY FOR PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   Approval of increased capacity capital improvements.
      (1)   Application for increased capacity capital improvement. A developer
desiring to make an increased capacity capital improvement under this chapter
shall apply in writing to the City Engineering Department for consideration of
the improvement for capital recovery prior to completion of the project. The
application shall contain the following information:
         (a)   The name and address of the developer making the application;
         (b)   A detailed drawing of the proposal, indicating the area to be
served, proposed location of the new improvement, location of existing services
in close proximity and the proposed point of connection;
         (c)   Estimates of improvement cost, allowable recovery cost and
proposed excess capacity fee;
         (d)   Proposed area of impact, with a map and necessary legal
descriptions;
         (e)   Proposed routing of capital improvements with coordination of
drainage and other public utility services;
         (f)   Estimate of increased capacity to be provided by the project;
         (g)   A certified list of properties and owners within the area of
impact;
         (h)   Additional requirements as set out in the sections for water,
sanitary sewer, stormwater and transportation; and
         (i)   Any other information pertinent to the proposal.
      (2)   Review and approval procedure. After the application has been
reviewed and found to be acceptable and complete, the application will be
forwarded to the Metropolitan Area Planning Commission for approval and then to
the City Council for action.
      (3)   Increased capacity development agreement conditions. Upon approval
of the application by the City Commission, an increased capacity development
agreement should be entered into between the initial developer and the City,
which should address the following items.
         (a)   The developer will prepare and furnish plans, profiles, contract
documents and specifications for the qualified improvements, all in accordance
with the ordinances, regulations and specifications of the City.
         (b)   All construction will be of the size, type and depth in
accordance with city standards and of sufficient capacity to serve the
anticipated need for the area being served, as defined by the City’s Master
Plans, for the design life of the improvements.
         (c)   The developer shall acquire easements and rights-of-way
necessary to construct improvements. The easements shall be dedicated to the
City, approved by the City and recorded at the expense of the developer. The
easements will be located so as to be reasonably accessible to all parties that
may be anticipated to access the improvement.
         (d)   The developer shall file with the City an engineer’s estimate of
the cost of construction of said improvements, prepared by a licensed engineer,
registered in the state, as called for in this chapter.
         (e)   The developer shall deposit with the City the estimated amount
of all inspection and administration fees, if and when such fees are required.
         (f)   The developer shall furnish a “record drawing” on compatible
digital format, approved by the City prior to acceptance of improvements.
         (g)   After completion and acceptance of the developer’s improvement,
said improvements shall become a part of the city system, under its exclusive
control and operation.
         (h)   The developer shall, within 30 days after completion of the
construction, furnish to the City a certified, itemized statement of the cost
of the improvements, including the actual cost of construction, engineering,
inspections, easements, rights-of-way and recording fees.
         (i)   The developer shall provide a map and boundary description of
all property in the area of impact covered by the agreement.
         (j)   The developer shall provide a one-year warranty on all qualified
improvements.
   (B)   Qualified improvements.
      (1)   Improvement to system. The project must be an improvement to the
city public infrastructure system and provide excess capacity for use beyond
the amount required for the development site that is undertaking the qualified
improvement.
      (2)   Public benefit. The improvement must provide a public benefit and
provide a benefit or service to other property.
      (3)   Project requirements. The project must:
         (a)   Be consistent with the City’s Master Plans; or
         (b)   Encourage infill development.
      (4)   Standards, size, depth requirements. The project shall conform to
the standards, size and depth requirements of the City’s Master Plans on file
in the Engineering Department of the City and the city standards.
   (C)   Allowable recovery cost. This section sets out how the developer’s
costs for increased capacity in an improvement is calculated for the purpose of
establishing an amount of money from which recovery by postimprovement
developers can be derived, as well as the determination of the area of impact
for recovery.
      (1)   Allowable cost. The aggregate cost of the qualified portion of the
improvement cost, including the developer’s actual cost of construction,
inspection fees, easements and rights-of-way acquisition cost (at or below
appraised value), advertising and recording cost and engineering fees capped at
seven percent (7%) of the bid construction amount for a qualified project. The
allowable cost shall not exceed the actual funds expended by the developer for
the allowed project.
      (2)   Allowable recovery cost. The allowable recovery cost (ARC) shall be
the allowable cost less the original developer’s proportional cost.
Proportional cost shall be based on the original development’s share of the
total cost and the required capacity of the original development.
      (3)   Area of impact. An area of impact shall be determined for each
qualified project based on the properties that benefit or could reasonably
benefit from the improvement.
      (4)   Determinations final and binding. The determination of the AI, the
allowable recovery cost and the development site’s cost obligations as approved
by the City, shall be final and binding upon all parties.
   (D)   Notice of capital improvement.
      (1)   Notice of the estimated allowable recovery costs for the project
shall be mailed to the current property owners within the area of impact by the
developer with proof of mailing provided to the City. The notice shall include
a description of the project, the boundary of the area of impact, the estimated
allowable recovery cost and the method of determining the post-developer’s
increased capacity fees.
      (2)   Notice of the determined allowable recovery costs after completion
of the work shall be mailed to the current property owners within the area of
impact by the developer with proof of mailing provided to the City 30 days
before final acceptance of the capital recovery allowable cost by the City. The
notice shall include the information set out in the previous notice with
updated constructed amounts.
      (3)   Notice of the final determined allowable cost shall be placed on
the title records at the County Courthouse for the properties within the area
of impact putting the owners on notice that the properties are subject to the
increased capacity fee.
   (E)   Increased capacity capital improvement; payback contract with
developer.
      (1)   Upon approval of an increased capacity capital improvement, the
City may enter into a contract with the developer concerning the construction,
operation or maintenance of the capital improvement and a payment of increased
capacity fees in an amount not to exceed the allowable recovery cost to the
developer of the increased capacity capital improvement and any interest set
out in capital recovery section.
      (2)   After the completion and acceptance by the City of the developer’s
capital improvement constructed pursuant to this chapter, and upon connection
of the improvement to the City’s infrastructure, said improvement shall
thereupon be and become a part of the City’s capital improvement system, under
the City’s exclusive ownership, control and operation, including the right to
make all such connections and cross-connections, and use of the improvement as
it may deem necessary for the proper management and utilization of the
improvement as an integrated part of the City’s infrastructure.
      (3)   The sole and only obligation of the City to the developer
hereunder, after the capital improvement has been constructed, accepted and
becomes a part of the City’s infrastructure, shall be to require the
appropriate distribution of the capital recovery sums actually paid by others.
In the event the fees are not collected, the City shall not be liable for
payment.
      (4)   The City shall, during the term of any increased capacity contract,
require any post-improvement developer, within the area of impact, which
desires to connect to or extend any increased capacity improvement or otherwise
use the system, to pay to the City, for the benefit of the developer of the
increased capacity improvement, that portion of the allowable costs, as
calculated herein, for payment to developers which hold increased capacity
capital improvement contracts on that portion of the City’s infrastructure
which serves the property to be connected to or use the improvement.
      (5)   Neither the contract nor any right contained therein may be sold,
assigned, transferred or encumbered by the developer without the advance
written consent of the City.
      (6)   Nothing contained in the language of the contract shall prohibit
the City from making any connections, cross-connections or use of the capital
improvement constructed by the developer at any location, and no payment or fee
shall be required.
   (F)   Increased capacity fee calculation. The post-improvement development
site’s share of an increased capacity capital improvement cost shall be
calculated as follows.
      (1)   Basis for calculation. The allowable recovery cost shall be the
cost of the project minus the developer’s cost of share, where:
         (a)   Developer’s share of the project shall be based on the
developer’s share of the increased capacity compared to the total increased
capacity established in the agreement; and
         (b)   Developer’s cost share shall be the developer’s share of the
project multiplied by the allowable cost of the project.
      (2)   Post-improvement development sites. The post-improvement
development site’s increased capacity fee for a qualifying capital improvement
shall be calculated as follows.
         (a)   Post-improvement development share shall be based upon the post-
improvement development’s share of the increased capacity compared to the total
increased capacity established in the agreement.
         (b)   Post-improvement development cost share shall be the post-
improvement development share multiplied by the allowable cost, inflated by
four percent (4%) for each whole year from the date of acceptance of the
capital improvement as a capital recovery project.
   (G)   Post-improvement development sites.
      (1)   Increased capacity fees. When post-improvement development occurs
within the area of impact and makes use of, or receives a benefit of, a portion
of the increased capacity capital improvement covered under this chapter, the
developer of the post-improvement development shall pay the increased capacity
fees set out in this chapter. Fees shall be due and payable to the City before
issuance of the plat, or in cases where there are no plats issued, before
issuance of any permit for the post-improvement development site or certificate
of occupancy. When a post-improvement development occurs outside of the area of
impact (AI) but makes use of and receives fifty percent (50%) or more of the
development’s benefit from an increased capacity improvement covered under this
chapter, the developer of the post-development shall pay increased capacity
fees as if the post-development was within the area of impact.
      (2)   Site requirements. Post-development sites that fall within an
increased capacity capital improvement district or districts, or where fifty
percent (50%) or more of the site will use an improvement, or improvements,
covered by an increased capacity agreement, shall provide the following:
         (a)   The share of the increased capacity being accessed or used; and
         (b)   Payment of increased capacity fee or fees with plat submission,
or with other permits when a plat is not involved.
   (H)   Capital recovery payments.
      (1)   Increased capacity fees. The City shall account for the increased
capacity fees for each capital recovery improvement separately. Five percent
(5%) of all fees collected shall be retained by the City for administration.
The City shall provide notice to the developers of record of active capital
improvement districts, of the fees collected in amounts of $1,000 or more.
Developers of record may then file a claim for payment of fees, less the City’s
five percent (5%) administrative fee.
      (2)   Unclaimed fees. Fees not claimed by the developer within one year
of the second notice of fees on file shall become the property of the City, but
failure to collect fees in one year does not terminate the developer’s right to
collect in subsequent years.
      (3)   Non-liability or obligation of the City. The City shall not be
liable for payment of any increased capacity fees not collected. The sole
obligation of the City to any developer shall be to require the payment of
increased capacity fees as required by this chapter.
   (I)   Term of capital recovery district. Recovery of capital recovery fees
is available for a term of 20 years from the date of acceptance of the
improvements by the City. Provided, however, recovery will be terminated prior
to the term of 20 years if and when the entire allowable recovery cost has been
collected.
   (J)   City use. The City shall have the right to make such connections, use,
changes, improvements or abandonment of any public improvement, as it may deem
necessary, without payment of fees.
   (K)   Special exception. Prior to payment of capital recovery fees, any
person that can show that they have an interest in property in an area of
impact, AI of a capital improvement project, and that such property is
substantially unique, and that the capital improvement fee is a substantial
hardship due to the unique qualities, may file a request for a special
exception with the City Commission. The City Council, upon hearing a request,
must determine that there is a substantially unique condition that makes the
proposed capital improvement fee a substantial hardship on the property before
taking any action. The actions that may be taken include reduction of the
capital improvement fee, waiving of the fee, deferring the fee or taking no
action.
   (L)   Restrictions and reservations. The following restrictions and
reservations apply to projects proposed under this chapter: Nothing herein
shall be construed to obligate the City to give or continue to give service to
any person, firm or corporation, or to any particular tract of land, other than
pursuant to its other ordinances and regulations.
§ 10-5-5 CAPITAL RECOVERY SPECIAL CONDITIONS FOR SANITARY SEWER IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   Approval of increased capacity capital improvements. A developer
desiring to make an increased capacity public improvement shall include the
following information in the application:
      (1)   A detailed drawing of the proposal, indicating the drainage area to
be served, proposed location of the new improvement, location of existing
services in close proximity and the proposed point of connection; and
      (2)   Proposed routing of sewer with coordination of drainage and other
public services.
   (B)   Increased capacity fee calculation for sanitary sewers. The post-
improvement development site’s share of an increased capacity sanitary sewer
improvement cost shall be calculated as follows.
      (1)   Basis for calculation. The allowable recovery cost shall be
proportioned out based on the post-development site’s projected peak hourly
wastewater flow compared to the established design peak hourly wastewater flow,
less the peak hourly wastewater flow established for the original development
site. This calculation shall be made for each improvement district the post-
development site is within.
      (2)   Hourly wastewater flow designations. The post-development projected
peak hourly wastewater flow shall be:
         (a)   Nine hundred fifty GPD for each single residence;
         (b)   Four hundred GPD for each motel unit, hotel or other transient
living unit;
         (c)   Six hundred fifty GPD for each trailer space, mobile home or
apartment living unit;
         (d)   One hundred GPD for each student of any nonboarding type school;
         (e)   Twenty eight GPD for each person that may be accommodated in a
main assembly hall, with restroom facilities only; and
         (f)   Six hundred sixty GPD for each bed of a hospital.
      (3)   Other developments. The post-development projected peak hourly
wastewater flow for any development not covered above shall be equal to four
times the development site’s projected average water use contributing to the
sanitary sewer system, but in no case shall the flow be less than 400 GPD.
   (C)   Post-improvement development sites for sanitary sewers. Post-
improvement development sites that fall within an increased capacity
improvement district or districts or will use an improvement covered by an
increased capacity agreement shall provide the following information to
determine the post-improvement fee: Number and type of living units, lots,
sleeping units or participants projected for the site. The projected peak day
wastewater flow for the site when required, and the method that the flow was
calculated on.
   (D)   Exemption. Section 8-3A-5 (which requires connection to the City’s
sewer system) will not apply to properties within a sanitary sewer capital
recovery project until the recovery of capital recovery fees is terminated.
§ 10-5-6 SPECIAL CONDITIONS FOR STORMWATER IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   Approval of increased capacity capital improvements. A developer
desiring to make an increased capacity public improvement for stormwater shall
include the following additional information in their application: A detailed
drawing of the proposal indicating the drainage area to be served (AI) and the
proposed location of improvement; a drainage report identifying the existing
capacity of the facility; and the proposed improved capacity of the facility.
   (B)   Stormwater development fee. To defray the costs of stormwater
improvements, a stormwater development fee shall be assessed pursuant to the
fee schedule set forth in §
2-6E-10.
§ 10-5-7 SPECIAL CONDITIONS FOR WATER IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   Area of impact. Where the water line improvement follows road rights-
of-way, the area of impact shall generally include the area to a line one-half
of the distance to the next existing or planned water line, of equal size or
larger, on both sides of the improvement, but not more than one-half mile from
the improvement.
   (B)   Increased capacity fee calculation for water improvements. The post-
improvement development site’s share of an increased capacity water improvement
cost shall be calculated using two methods:
      (1)   Half is based upon the area of development, which shall be
determined to be the area of the lot or tract of land associated with any
building and associated with all impervious surface on the site; and
      (2)   Half is based upon the water capacity of the development by using
the following table.
         (a)   Meter size shall be the larger of the tap size placed on a water
main or the meter size.
         (b)   Water capacity is used to determine the proportional share of
the ARC for this subsection (B)(2).
 
Meter Size Water Capacity Factor (Acres)
5/8”     0.39
1”       1
2”       4
4”       16
6”       36
8”       64
 
   (C)   Basis for calculation. The ARC shall be proportioned out based on the
post-development site’s area and water tap size. Post-developments shall pay
their proportional share of one-half of the allowable recovery cost based upon
the post-development site’s developed area compared to the basin area, and the
other half of their payment is their proportional share of one-half of the ARC
based on their tap size, in the area, compared to the projected total metered
area established in the basin. In the case where a post-development site
outside the basin boundary ties to or makes use of a capital recovery
improvement, the required increased capacity fee shall be capped at not more
than one-half of the ARC, after the inflation multiplier is applied.
   (D)   Post-improvement development requirement. At the time of site plan,
platting, permitting or application to connect and in advance of connecting to
the water system, developments within a current area of impact shall provide
its area of development and the water tap size, or sizes.
§ 10-5-8 SPECIAL CONDITIONS FOR TRANSPORTATION IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   Approval of increased capacity capital improvements. A developer
desiring to make an increased capacity public transportation improvement shall
include the following additional information:
      (1)   A traffic study by a professional licensed engineer establishing
ADT, peak hour traffic for both a.m. and p.m., and an equivalent single axle
load (ESAL) for the highest use lane and level of service for existing
conditions, the increased condition with full development of the proposed site
and for the increased condition considering growth for a period of 20 years
from completion of the improvement; and
      (2)   When a traffic control signal is included in the improvement, the
traffic study should include the above information for the signaled
intersection and each lane of the intersection. Growth should include the
projected growth of the development with one-half mile of the intersection in
all directions or half way to the next traffic light.
   (B)   Increased capacity fee calculation for transportation improvement. The
post-improvement development site’s share of an increased capacity
transportation improvement cost shall be calculated as follows.
      (1)   Roads. Post-improvement developments within the area of impact for
a road or multiple roads shall provide as part of the site plan or plat a
traffic study the ESAL generated by the development for the life of the
improvement and the distribution of such loads to the road system. The post-
improvement development’s increased capacity fee shall be calculated by
multiplying its ESAL share of the total ESAL for the road by the ARC, after the
inflation multiplier is applied.
      (2)   Traffic control signal. Post-improvement developments within the AI
for a traffic signal shall provide a traffic study showing the distribution of
development generated traffic through the intersection for the life of the
improvement. The post-improvement development increased capacity fee shall be
calculated by multiplying the post-improvement developer’s share of traffic
impact on the signal system of the total traffic impact on the signal system by
the ARC, after the inflation multiplier is applied.
      (3)   Traffic study not required, fee calculation. For post-improvement
developments that are not required to provide a traffic study, the increased
capacity fee shall be calculated based on the area of the development compared
to the AI.
§ 10-5-9 CITY AS DEVELOPER.
   The City, or any of its trusts, may act as the developer for the purpose of
capital recovery. When the City acts as the developer, the following provisions
apply.
   (A)   Predevelopment site. No development site is required.
   (B)   Allowable recovery cost. The allowable cost may be used as the ARC.
   (C)   Notice of area of impact. The City may file a notice by resolution in
place of a “payback contract” to establish the area of impact, estimated ARC
and any other items necessary and usually covered by the contract.
CHAPTER 6: GROUP HOMES FOR THE DEVELOPMENTALLY DISABLED
Section
   
10-6-1   Purpose and intent
   
10-6-2   Definitions
   
10-6-3   General locational requirements
   
10-6-4   Design requirements
   
10-6-5   Exclusion by private agreement void
§ 10-6-1 PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   (A)   The “group home” concept offers the opportunity for the
developmentally disabled to live a normal life by residing in environments
providing maximum potential for social contact and interaction and by providing
appropriate treatment, services and habilitation in a setting that is least
restrictive of personal liberty. These residential facilities have similar off
site impacts and service demands as do conventional residences for nondisabled
persons and shall be permitted in any residential zoning district subject to
density limitations of other residential uses permitted in each district.
   (B)   The purposes of this chapter are:
      (1)   To promote the rights of the developmentally disabled to enjoy
adequate habilitative services in the least restrictive community based
setting;
      (2)   To provide the disabled with the patterns and conditions of
everyday living which are as close as possible to the regular circumstances and
way of life of society; and
      (3)   To provide a clear and uniform zoning and land use policy for the
establishment of residential facilities for the developmentally disabled.
§ 10-6-2 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITY. A severe, chronic disability that:
      (1)   Is attributable to a mental or physical impairment or combination
of mental and physical impairments;
      (2)    Is manifested before the person attains age 22;
      (3)   Is likely to continue indefinitely;
      (4)   Results in substantial functional limitations in three or more of
the following areas of major life activity:
         (a)   Self-care;
         (b)   Learning;
         (c)   Mobility;
         (d)   Self-direction;
         (e)   Capacity for independent living; and
         (f)   Economic self-sufficiency.
      (5)   Reflects the person’s need for a combination and sequence of
special, interdisciplinary or generic care, treatment or other services that
are lifelong or of extended duration and are individually planned and
coordinated.
   GROUP HOME. A facility, licensed by the state, providing housing and
habilitative services to persons with developmental disabilities. For purposes
of zoning, a GROUP HOME providing housing and habilitative services to five or
fewer persons not including staff, shall be considered a single family.
   HABILITATION. Procedures and interventions designed to assist a
developmentally disabled individual achieve greater physical, mental and social
development by enhancing the well-being of the person and teaching skills which
increase the possibility that a resident of a group home will make
progressively independent and responsible decisions about social behavior,
quality of life, job satisfaction and personal relationships.
§ 10-6-3 GENERAL LOCATIONAL REQUIREMENTS.
   Group homes may be established or developed in accordance with the following
standards.
   (A)   Residential zoning districts. Group homes shall be permitted by right
in all residential zoning districts and any zoning district which permits other
residential uses of equivalent density.
   (B)   Home of greater density; review. A group home of greater density than
the residential district permits by rights may be permitted by review in
accordance with §
11-14-1 .
§ 10-6-4 DESIGN REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Conformance with existing residences. Group homes shall conform, to
the extent possible, to the type and outward appearance of the residences in
the area in which they are located. When utilization of any existing residence
is planned, exterior alterations should be limited to rehabilitation work and
if additions are necessary, they should match, as closely as possible, the
materials and style of the existing structure. This provision shall in no way
restrict the installation of any ramp or other special structural features
required to serve physically handicapped residents.
   (B)   Compliance with zoning regulations. The initial establishment or
development of a group home that will house more than ten residents, excluding
staff, shall be subject to site plan review.
   (C)   Parking regulations. Off street parking shall be provided in an amount
equal to one parking space for each staff member calculated on the basis of the
maximum number of staff on duty at any one time and one parking space for each
four residents. If, due to occupant automobile ownership, facility visitation
policy or other factors, it is believed fewer parking spaces are necessary,
applicants may petition the Zoning Board of Adjustment for a special exception
in accordance with §
11-3-6.
§ 10-6-5 EXCLUSION BY PRIVATE AGREEMENT VOID.
   Any restriction, reservation or covenant in any subdivision, deed or
instrument of or pertaining to the transfer, sale, lease or use of property
that permits residential use of property, but prohibits the use of such
property as a group home for developmentally disabled persons, shall, to the
extent of such prohibition, be void as against the purpose and intent of this
chapter and shall, to the extent of such prohibition, be given no legal or
equitable force or effect.
CHAPTER 7: SIDEWALKS
Section
   
10-7-1   Sidewalks required
   
10-7-2   Sidewalk specifications
§ 10-7-1 SIDEWALKS REQUIRED.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this chapter, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      ADDITION. Construction of a structure that is attached to or connected
with an existing building.
      COMMUNITY CENTERS AND NEIGHBORHOOD CENTERS. As defined in the Envision
Enid Comprehensive Plan, § 6-1. The size of a COMMUNITY OR NEIGHBORHOOD CENTER
is determined by the width of the commercial, industrial or special use zoning
from the intersection.
      DITCH. An earthen channel typically used for drainage along the side of a
road or street.
      INFILL DEVELOPMENT. The development of a previously undeveloped lot or
tract of land in an existing neighborhood.
      NATURAL DISASTER. An event or force of nature, including fire,
earthquake, flood and tornado.
      NEW DEVELOPMENT. Improving an undeveloped lot or tract of land by
subdividing, site planning, construction or building permitting. Development on
a previously developed lot or tract of land which where the previous
development is removed for the purposes of developing the site shall also be
considered NEW DEVELOPMENT.
      REDEVELOPMENT. The development of a previously developed lot or tract of
land after a total loss.
      TOTAL LOSS. The destruction of a structure as a result of a natural
disaster such that nothing of value remains and the structure cannot be
repaired or restored to its original condition.
   (B)   Residential sidewalks that parallel abutting streets. The following
shall include sidewalks that parallel all abutting streets:
      (1)   New development;
      (2)   Redevelopment or infill development on property used or zoned as
residential (Four-Family R-4A, Townhouse R-5, Multi-Family R-7); and
      (3)   Redevelopment or infill development on property used or zoned as
residential (Estate R-1, Single-Family R-2, Mobile Home Neighborhood R-3,
Duplex R-4), but only if an adjacent property or if a property within the same
residential subdivision has a sidewalk.
   (C)   Commercial, industrial or special use properties. For new
developments, additions, redevelopments and infill developments, sidewalks that
parallel abutting streets, shall be the length of the lot or development,
whichever is less, and will be included in the following locations:
      (1)   Within ETS Enid Town Square Overlay District Boundaries, as set out
in § 11-10C-3;
      (2)   Within a community center at:
         (a)   Willow Road and Cleveland Street;
         (b)   Willow Road and Van Buren Street;
         (c)   Owen K. Garriott and Garland Road;
         (d)   Owen K. Garriott and Cleveland Street; and
         (e)   Rupe Avenue and Van Buren Street.
      (3)   Within a neighborhood center at:
         (a)   Willow Road and Oakwood Road;
         (b)   Willow Road and Grand Avenue;
         (c)   Chestnut Avenue and Garland Road;
         (d)   Chestnut Avenue and Oakwood Road;
         (e)   Chestnut Avenue and Cleveland Street;
         (f)   Chestnut Avenue and 10th Street;
         (g)   Chestnut Avenue and 16th Street;
         (h)   Randolph Avenue and Garland Road;
         (i)   Randolph Avenue and Oakwood Road;
         (j)   Randolph Avenue and 30th Street;
         (k)   Broadway Avenue and 10th Street;
         (l)   Broadway Avenue and 16th Street;
         (m)   Broadway Avenue and University Avenue;
         (n)   Owen K. Garriott and Van Buren Street; and
         (o)   Owen K. Garriott and 10th Street.
      (4)   Along these streets:
         (a)   Owen K. Garriott from Wheatridge Road to 16th Street;
         (b)   Oakwood Road from 0.25 mile north of Owen K. Garriott to 0.30
mile south of Owen K. Garriott;
         (c)   Van Buren Street from Willow Road to Rupe Avenue;
         (d)   Willow Road from Cleveland Street to Grand Avenue;
         (e)   Grand Avenue from Willow Road to Elm Avenue;
         (f)   30th Street from Randolph to Oklahoma Avenue;
         (g)   Randolph Avenue from Van Buren Street to 10th Street;
         (h)   Broadway Avenue from Van Buren Street to 10th Street; and
         (i)   Maine Street from Van Buren Street to 10th Street.
   (D)   Exceptions. Exceptions are as follows:
      (1)   In a ditch if there is less than five feet between the back of the
curb or driving surface and the top of the slope of the ditch, or if there is
less than five feet between the top of the slope of the ditch and the limits of
the right-of-way, or a ditch with a slope greater than 1:3;
      (2)   Placement or construction of an accessory building;
      (3)   Addition, new development, redevelopment or infill development on
agriculturally zoned land;
      (4)   Remodels, maintenance of buildings or after a total loss; and
      (5)   Additions that do not exceed 2,500 square feet.
§ 10-7-2 SIDEWALK SPECIFICATIONS.
   (A)   Sidewalks shall comply with the most current accessibility guidelines
associated with the Americans with Disabilities Act, see 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et
seq.
   (B)   Sidewalks shall be constructed using the minimum specifications
provided in §
12-8-7.
   (C)   Should a conflict arise between guidelines associated with the
Americans with Disabilities Act, see 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq., and the
specifications provided in §
12-8-7, the more restrictive shall apply.
