§ 13-3-1 STATUTORY AUTHORIZATION.
   The Oklahoma Legislature has, in 82 O.S. §§ 1601 through 1618, delegated the
responsibility to local governmental units to adopt regulations designed to
minimize flood losses. Therefore, the City does hereby adopt this stormwater
management chapter.
(Prior Code, § 13-3-1) (Ord. 2009-01, passed 1-6-2009)
§ 13-3-2 FINDINGS OF FACT.
   (A)   The flood hazard areas of the City are subject to periodic inundation,
which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards,
disruption of commerce and governmental services and extraordinary public
expenditures for flood protection and relief, all of which adversely affect the
public health, safety and general welfare.
   (B)   Because of its physical terrain and geographical location, the City is
particularly subject to damage from stormwaters, which, from time to time,
overflow from existing watercourses and drainage facilities.
   (C)   The presently existing stormwater drainage facilities of the City
require continuous operation, maintenance, renewal and replacement.
   (D)   A comprehensive approach to managing stormwater runoff is required to
address existing and future needs.
   (E)   The cost of operating and maintaining all stormwater drainage systems,
and the financing of existing and future necessary repairs, replacement,
improvements and extensions thereof, should, to the extent practicable, be
allocated in relationship to the benefit enjoyed and services received
therefrom.
   (F)   Requiring the construction of regional master drainage plan detention
sites, mitigation of stormwater runoff through on site detention and payment of
stormwater development fees and stormwater utility service charges are the most
equitable methods of implementing a comprehensive stormwater management
program.
(Prior Code, § 13-3-2) (Ord. 2009-01, passed 1-6-2009)
§ 13-3-3 STATEMENT OF PURPOSE.
   (A)   It is the purpose of this chapter to promote public health, safety and
welfare by providing for operating, constructing, equipping, maintaining,
acquiring and owning within the City a stormwater drainage system.
   (B)   The establishment of a stormwater drainage system will:
      (1)   Minimize flood and storm losses and inconveniences from
uncontrolled stormwater runoff in the City;
      (2)   Assure that the movement of emergency vehicles is not prohibited
nor inhibited during storm or flood periods;
      (3)   Preserve the City’s watercourses, improve and preserve purity of
water, minimize water quality degradation and otherwise facilitate urban water
resource management techniques, including both the reduction of pollution and
the enhancement of the urban environment;
      (4)   Establish an overall plan and master plan for stormwater and flood
management and its implementation, including, without limitation, a coordinated
program of creating upstream ponding or temporary detention of stormwaters;
      (5)   Establish stormwater and flood management utility to coordinate,
design, construct, manage, operate and maintain the stormwater and flood
management system;
      (6)   Establish reasonable stormwater utility and flood management fees
based on the use of stormwater drainage system and flood drainage facilities;
and
      (7)   Establish reasonable stormwater and flood management fees based on
the impact or future impact of development on the stormwater drainage system.
(Prior Code, § 13-3-3) (Ord. 2009-01, passed 1-6-2009)
§ 13-3-4 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CHANNEL CAPACITY. The capacity of a specific type of channel as defined in §
12-7-2 (B)(2)(b).
   DEPARTMENT. The stormwater management department as established by the City
Manager, or in absence thereof, the Engineering Department of the City.
   DETENTION OR RETENTION FACILITIES. Facilities designed to hold stormwater
for a short period and then to release it to a watercourse or to hold
stormwater for a sufficient length of time to provide for it to be consumed by
evaporation, infiltration into the soil or other natural means.
   DEVELOPED REAL ESTATE (DEVELOPED PROPERTY). Real property altered from its
natural state by the addition to, or construction of, any impervious surface
such that the hydrology of the property is affected.
   DEVELOPER. The person(s) who improves, subdivides land or alters real
property from its natural state by the addition to, or construction of, any
impervious surface such that the hydrology of the property is affected.
   DIRECTOR. The duly appointed director of the Stormwater Management
Department of the City and/or his designated representative.
   DRAINAGE BASIN PLAN. The plan adopted by the City for managing surface and
stormwater facilities and features within an individual drainage basin.
   IMPACTED CHANNEL. The channel from a development to the main drainage
channel.
   RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY. Any property designed and used principally for
residential single-family, duplex or multi-family purposes and developed
according to, and meeting the bulk and area requirements for, residential
single-family, duplex or apartment zoned property as set forth in the City’s
zoning code at the time of development of such property.
   STORMWATER DEVELOPMENT FEE. The fee levied within the boundaries of the City
against proposed developing real estate to cover development’s cost share of
the stormwater management program.
   STORMWATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM. Any facility, structure, improvement,
development, equipment, property or interest therein, or other structural or
nonstructural element made, constructed, used or acquired for the purpose of
collecting, containing, storing, conveying and controlling stormwater wherever
located, including, but not limited to, storm sewers, conduits, natural and
manmade channels, pipes, culverts and detention ponds whether public or
private.
   STORMWATER MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. The overall strategy and framework for the
stormwater management activities of the City.
   STORMWATER RUNOFF. That portion of the rainfall that is drained into the
stormwater drainage system.
   SUBDIVISION. Land that is separated into tracts, parcels or lots.
   TRACT. A lot, or parcel of land. Properties that are not abutting or
adjoining or are separated by any street, alley or other property shall be
considered separate TRACTS.
   UNDEVELOPED REAL ESTATE (UNDEVELOPED PROPERTY). Real estate unaltered by the
construction or addition of any impervious surface, which would change the
hydrology of the property from its natural state.
(Prior Code, § 13-3-4) (Ord. 2009-01, passed 1-6-2009)
§ 13-3-5 DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   (A)   The Director shall exercise all lawful powers necessary and
appropriate to administer the city stormwater management program.
   (B)   The Director shall have the authority to:
      (1)   Develop and administer all phases of a comprehensive program of
stormwater management, including planning, designing, establishing, acquiring,
constructing, developing, installing, administering, maintaining, operating,
improving, repairing, replacing and reconstructing the stormwater drainage
system of the City;
      (2)   Administer the accounting, budgeting, recordkeeping and support
personnel necessary for the efficient operation of the stormwater management
program;
      (3)   Administer the regulations contained in this chapter;
      (4)   Perform studies and analyses required to establish or modify the
stormwater management program;
      (5)   Provide for public information and awareness that will improve
management and reduce hazards to life and property;
      (6)   Coordinate enforcement of the regulations contained in this chapter
with other city departments; and
      (7)   Seek the cooperation of counties and municipalities within the area
in minimizing the contribution of all storm drainage systems to flooding and,
in particular, cooperate with other affected political jurisdictions in
preparing and implementing master drainage plans.
(Prior Code, § 13-3-5) (Ord. 2009-01, passed 1-6-2009)
§ 13-3-6 STORMWATER DRAINAGE FUND.
   A separate account or accounts shall be maintained for the purpose of
identifying and controlling all revenues to stormwater drainage services. The
costs of administrating, data collection, planning, maintaining, operating and
improving drainage services and facilities shall be paid from these revenues.
(Prior Code, § 13-3-6) (Ord. 2009-01, passed 1-6-2009)
§ 13-3-7 MASTER DRAINAGE PLAN.
   (A)   Plan developed. The Director shall develop a master drainage plan for
the City, based on engineering studies, that indicates the location of all
drainage facilities in the City, including those facilities that currently
exist and those determined to be needed and that are intended to be constructed
in the future. The plan may also show any other information that the Director
deems desirable.
   (B)   Purpose of plan. The purpose of the master drainage plan prescribed by
this section is to identify and propose a system to alleviate present and
future drainage and flooding problems in the City by means of presenting in an
orderly fashion the general data and information essential in understanding the
relationship between rainfall and storm runoff. The master drainage plan serves
as the official designation of drainage facilities, drainageways and basins.
These may be altered, from time to time, to conform to existing conditions or
new information.
   (C)   Cost estimate. The Director may undertake supplementary studies to
determine the estimated cost of constructing the drainage facilities shown on
the master drainage plan, including the expense of any necessary land
acquisition.
   (D)   Individual basin plans. The citywide master drainage plan may include
individual basin plans such as the 1987 master drainage plan northwest area
drainage basin that was adopted by the City Council.
   (E)   Substantial modifications. Substantial modifications to the master
drainage plan shall be adopted by City Commission action.
(Prior Code, § 13-3-7) (Ord. 2009-01, passed 1-6-2009)
§ 13-3-8 SUBDIVISION PLAT, SITE PLAN AND BUILDING PERMIT APPROVAL.
   All subdivision plats, replats, site plans and industrial building permits
shall be approved by the Community Development Department. The review and
approval of any plat, replat, site plan or industrial building permit by the
Community Development Department shall require the submittal and acceptance of
drainage plans in accordance with the city subdivision regulations, standard
construction specifications and details and this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 13-3-8) (Ord. 2009-01, passed 1-6-2009)
§ 13-3-9 STORMWATER MITIGATION.
   (A)   Mitigation required. All development that involves the filing of a
plat, replat, site plan or industrial building permit must mitigate the impact
of that development’s stormwater runoff by performing work on a regional master
drainage plan detention site located within the same basin as the development,
or pay the development fee as outlined in §
13-3-10.
   (B)   Amount of work. The amount of work to be done at the detention site is
the amount necessary to mitigate the entire stormwater runoff caused by the
proposed development.
   (C)   Responsibility to mitigate. This mitigation work does not relieve the
developer from the responsibility to mitigate that development’s stormwater
impact from the development’s site to the main drainage channel of the
stormwater master plan (the impacted channel). If the flow is above the
impacted channel’s capacity anywhere from the development to the main drainage
channel, the proposed development must detain the stormwater on site, or
relieve the impact through mitigation in another manner.
   (D)   Development fee. Where work cannot be done to stormwater master plan
detention sites within the development basin, the developer must pay the
development fee as outlined in §
13-3-10.
   (E)   Developments outside limits of master plan. The drainage study for a
proposed development that is not located within a master drainage plan shall
include a plan to mitigate stormwater impact on the properties located
downstream between the proposed development and the main drainage channel.
Where on site detention is proposed to mitigate the impact, the developer may
make application to amend the master plan to add the proposed on site detention
to the plan as a regional detention site.
      (1)   Application to add on site detention to the master plan shall
include a detailed revised hydrology and hydraulic analysis of the master plan
study showing that the proposed detention will provide adequate protection,
offset certain improvements and not increase the operational maintenance cost,
or otherwise increase the public burden.
      (2)   Credits under §
13-3-10 may issue if the regional detention site provides capacity in excess of
what is required to be offset by the proposed development.
      (3)   If the on site detention is not to serve as a regional detention
site, it does not alleviate the requirement to pay the fee under §
13-3-10.
(Prior Code, § 13-3-10) (Ord. 2009-01, passed 1-6-2009)
§ 13-3-10 DEVELOPMENT FEE REQUIREMENTS; CREDITS.
   (A)   Development fee. Where work is not done to a regional stormwater
detention site, or the amount of work does not offset the impact, the developer
shall be required to pay a stormwater development fee at the time of the
subdivision plat, replat, site plan or industrial building permit approval as
provided for in §
2-6E-10.
   (B)   Obtaining credits. Credits can be obtained by developers to offset
stormwater development fees for a particular tract of land by providing
necessary property for master plan improvements. Credits are calculated in
dollars based on the following.
      (1)   Dollar value of credits for land provided shall be based on the
appraised value, less the cost of appraisal. Only land that provides for
drainage improvements compatible with the master drainage plan may be provided
for credits. The dedication of property or the granting of easements normally
provided as part of the development process cannot be used for credit.
      (2)   Dollar value of improvements provided shall be mutually agreed upon
and shall be based on the beneficial share of a complete project based on the
master drainage plan construction cost. Interim and incidental work such as
erosion protection, engineering, staking, safety measures and access roads
shall not be calculated as a beneficial share. Where detailed construction
plans are not available, an interim construction plan shall be provided by the
developer.
      (3)   Where engineering services are proposed for credit, the dollar
value shall be mutually agreed upon based on a detailed proposal of the
engineering services and conditioned upon acceptance of the construction plan.
   (C)   Issuance of credits. Credits shall issue by letter upon the completion
of the work and/or acceptance of the land by the City Commission.
      (1)   Letter agreements shall establish the value of the credit. Credits
shall be tied to a specific basin but may be transferred to a third party with
notice to the City.
      (2)   Use of credits may be made at the time of approval of a plat,
replat, lot split or building permit. Credits shall be set out on a per acre
basis in the letter agreement.
      (3)   Application to use credit shall include a copy of the letter
agreement and, if applicable, the credit transfer.
      (4)   Any credit amount applied against the stormwater development fee
shall be deducted from the amount of the fee set out for the referenced tract
or tracts.
      (5)   At any time the remaining credit for any tract shall fall below a
value of $500, no further credits can be applied for under the referenced
letter agreement, and the tracking of the use shall be discontinued.
   (D)   Application of credits. A developer may apply credits only to the
development of land within the drainage basin in which the land or work was
provided.
   (E)   Special credits. Special credits shall be established by letter
agreement for the following completed projects:
      (1)   Willow Road detention facility completed in 1984; and
      (2)   Grass lined channel on Bobsfarm Detention referenced by figure 7-
4 of the 1987 master drainage plan.
(Prior Code, § 13-3-10) (Ord. 2009-01, passed 1-6-2009)
